{"uri": "8260883959", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "00:02:34", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T00:02:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T00:01:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://theedgemalaysia.com/node/721785", "title": "Google has an illegal monopoly on search, US judge finds", "body": "WASHINGTON (Aug 6): A US judge ruled on Monday that Google violated antitrust law, spending billions of dollars to create an illegal monopoly and become the world's default search engine, the first big win for federal authorities taking on Big Tech's market dominance.\n\nThe ruling paves the way for a second trial to determine potential fixes, possibly including a breakup of Google parent Alphabet, which would change the landscape of the online advertising world that Google has dominated for years.\n\nIt is also a green light to aggressive US antitrust enforcers prosecuting Big Tech, a sector that has been under fire from across the political spectrum.\n\n\"The court reaches the following conclusion: Google is a monopolist, and it has acted as one to maintain its monopoly,\" district judge Amit Mehta wrote. The search engine giant controls about 90% of the online search market, and 95% on smartphones.\n\nThe \"remedy\" phase could be lengthy, followed by potential appeals to the District of Columbia Circuit and US Supreme Court. The legal wrangling could play out into next year, or even 2026.\n\nShares of Google parent Alphabet fell 4.5% on Monday as part of a broad tech share decline. Google advertising was 77% of Alphabet's total sales in 2023.\n\nAlphabet said it plans to appeal Mehta's ruling. \"This decision recognizes that Google offers the best search engine, but concludes that we shouldn't be allowed to make it easily available,\" Google said in a statement.\n\nUS Attorney General Merrick Garland called the ruling \"a historic win for the American people,\" adding that \"no company -- no matter how large or influential -- is above the law.\"\n\nMehta noted that Google had paid US$26.3 billion (RM116.4 billion) in 2021 alone to ensure that its search engine is the default on smartphones and browsers, and to keep its dominant market share.\n\n\"The default is extremely valuable real estate ... Even if a new entrant were positioned from a quality standpoint to bid for the default when an agreement expires, such a firm could compete only if it were prepared to pay partners upwards of billions of dollars in revenue share and make them whole for any revenue shortfalls resulting from the change,\" Mehta wrote.\n\nHe added, \"Google, of course, recognises that losing defaults would dramatically impact its bottom line. For instance, Google has projected that losing the Safari default would result in a significant drop in queries and billions of dollars in lost revenues.\"\n\nThe ruling is the first major decision in a series of cases taking on alleged monopolies in Big Tech. This case, filed by the Trump administration, went before a judge from September to November of last year.\n\n\"A forced divestiture of the search business would sever Alphabet from its largest source of revenue. But even losing its capacity to strike exclusive default agreements could be detrimental for Google,\" said Emarketer senior analyst Evelyn Mitchell-Wolf, who said a drawn-out legal process would delay any immediate effects for consumers.\n\nIn the past four years, federal antitrust regulators have also sued Meta Platforms, Amazon.com and Apple, claiming the companies have illegally maintained monopolies.\n\nThose cases all began under the administration of former president Donald Trump.\n\nAmy Klobuchar, a Democratic US senator who chairs the Senate Judiciary Committee's antitrust subcommittee, said the fact that the case spanned administrations shows strong bipartisan support for antitrust enforcement.\n\n\"It's a huge victory for the American people that antitrust enforcement is alive and well when it comes to competition,\" she said. \"Google is a rampant monopolist.\"\n\nWhen it was filed in 2020, the Google search case was the first time in a generation that the US government accused a major corporation of an illegal monopoly. Microsoft settled with the Justice Department in 2004 over claims that it forced its Internet Explorer Web browser on Windows users.", "source": {"uri": "theedgemalaysia.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "2024-08-444992666", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "21:09:59", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T21:09:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T20:42:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://www.commondreams.org/news/google-monopoly", "title": "US Court Rules Google a Monopoly in 'Biggest Antitrust Case of the 21st Century' | Common Dreams", "body": "\"Google is a monopolist, and it has acted as one to maintain its monopoly,\" said a federal judge in the decision.\n\nA federal judge left no room for ambiguity Monday in a landmark ruling in a case brought by the Justice Department and states against tech giant Google, in which the government argued the company had illegally monopolized the search engine and advertising market.\n\n\"Google is a monopolist, and it has acted as one to maintain its monopoly,\" said Judge Amit Mehta, who sits of the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia.\n\nIn U.S. et al. v. Google, Mehta found that Google has \"violated Section 2 of the Sherman Act by maintaining its monopoly in two product markets in the United States -- general services and general text advertising -- through its exclusive distribution agreements.\"\n\nThe American Economic Liberties Project (ALEP) called the ruling a \"tremendous win for consumers, innovation, and the entire tech industry.\"\n\nDuring a 10-week trial last year, the DOJ argued Google had used exclusionary contracts to block its competitors from reaching potential users. The company's deals with web firms such as Mozilla and cell phone companies like Apple and Samsung have made Google the default search engine on millions of people's phones and computers, as has its contracts with other major tech firms and service providers.\n\nThe trial revealed that Google shares 36% of its search ad revenues from Safari with Apple and paid the company $20 billion in 2022 to ensure Google's search engine would have default status for Apple customers.\n\nWhile paying billions of dollars per year to maintain its default status, Google has been using its dominance over ad space to collect more data about users and improve its search engine, while its rivals have been cut off from that ad space.\n\n\"If that's what it takes for somebody to dislodge Google as the default search engine, wouldn't the folks that wrote the Sherman Act be concerned about it?\" asked Mehta.\n\nThe Justice Department proved to the court that Google had ensured its search engine would conduct nearly 90% of all web searches.\n\nVanderbilt University law professor Rebecca Haw Allensworth toldThe New York Times the ruling represents \"a very prominent test of the Biden administration's new antitrust enforcement agenda.\"\n\nThe DOJ and the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) have also sued Apple, Meta, and Amazon for monopolizing the smartphone, social media, and online selling markets.\n\nWilliam Kovacic, former chairman of the FTC, told the Times in June that a victory against Google would create \"momentum that supports [the government's] other cases.\"\n\nU.S. Rep. Pramila Jayapal (D-Wash.) was among those who applauded the ruling, saying the unfair practices Mehta outlined \"are the exact behaviors that hurt consumers, competition, and small businesses.\"\n\nLee Hepner, senior legal counsel at ALEP, said the ruling \"strikes at the core of how hundreds of millions of Americans experience the internet.\"\n\n\"It illustrates how Google has become one of the most powerful companies in the world while undermining innovation and degrading the quality of its core product,\" said Hepner. \"The remedy must match the court's striking verdict in this case. At a minimum that means an end to Google's exclusive default agreements and breaking up business lines that have allowed Google to extend its monopoly into every corner of the internet.\"\n\nGoogle is expected to appeal Mehta's decision, but as it faces another antitrust case brought by the DOJ over its advertising technology business -- set to go to trial September 9 -- ALEP interim executive director Nidhi Hegde expressed hope that Monday's ruling \"sends a resounding signal that the antimonopoly movement is here to stay.\"\n\n\"The promise of antitrust enforcement is that it will fully restore competition where it has been lost,\" said Hepner, \"and we'll be advocating that the court use all of its power to do so.\"", "source": {"uri": "commondreams.org", "dataType": "news", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9792713", "eventUri": "eng-9792713", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2024-09-09", "textStart": 3593, "textEnd": {"uri": "8261202788", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "06:03:03", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T06:03:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T06:00:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://mybroadband.co.za/news/internet/553949-google-illegally-monopolised-search-judge-rules.html", "title": "Google illegally monopolised search,  judge rules", "body": "Google illegally monopolized the search market through exclusive deals, a judge ruled Monday, handing the government a win in its first major antitrust case against a tech giant in more than two decades.\n\nJudge Amit Mehta in Washington said that the Alphabet unit's $26 billion (R481 billion) in payments to make its search engine the default option on smartphones and web browsers effectively blocked any other competitor from succeeding in the market.\n\n\"Google's distribution agreements foreclose a substantial portion of the general search services market and impair rivals' opportunities to compete,\" Mehta said in a 286-page ruling.\n\nBy monopolizing distribution on phones and browsers, Google has been able to consistently raise the prices of online advertising without consequences, Mehta said.\n\n\"The trial evidence firmly established that Google's monopoly power, maintained by the exclusive distribution agreements, has enabled Google to increase text ads prices without any meaningful competitive constraint,\" he wrote.\n\nAntitrust enforcers alleged that Google has illegally maintained a monopoly over online search and related advertising.\n\nThe government said that Google has paid Apple, Samsung Electronics and others billions over decades for prime placement on smartphones and web browsers.\n\nThis default position has allowed Google to build up the most-used search engine in the world and fueled more than $300 billion (R5.5 trillion) in annual revenue largely generated by search ads.\n\nAlphabet shares slid almost 4.5% to $159.25 (R2,945) at the close in New York.\n\nApple, which depending on the remedy could stand to lose billions in payments Google makes to have its search engine be the default browser on iPhones, fell 4.8% to $209.27.\n\n\"This victory against Google is a historic win for the American people,\" said Attorney General Merrick Garland.\n\n\"No company -- no matter how large or influential -- is above the law. The Justice Department will continue to vigorously enforce the antitrust laws.\"\n\nGoogle said it plans to appeal the decision.\n\n\"As this process continues, we will remain focused on making products that people find helpful and easy to use,\" Kent Walker, President of Google Global Affairs, said in a statement.\n\nMehta found that Google doesn't have a monopoly in the market for general search advertising, noting that competitors like Amazon.com, Walmart and other retailers have begun to offer advertising related to searches on their own websites.\n\nBut Google does have a monopoly over search text ads, which appear at the top of a search results page to draw users to websites, he said.\n\nMehta's decision focuses solely on Google's liability, nine months after the Justice Department and a group of states held a 10-week trial in federal court. Mehta scheduled a hearing for next month to discuss the timing for a separate trial on the remedy.\n\nThe Justice Department hasn't yet said what changes it will seek, though it presented evidence that efforts by European regulators to require Google to offer users a choice of search engines led few to switch.\n\nThe agency could demand the separation of Alphabet's search business from other products, like Android or Chrome, which -- if ordered by the juge -- would mark the biggest forced breakup of a US company since AT&T was dismantled in 1984.\n\nThe judge could also stop short of ordering a full breakup and chose to unwind the exclusive search deals. Another option could be to require Google to license its search index, which is the data that it uses to build its search results.\n\nAntitrust enforcers separately sued Google for allegedly monopolizing the technology used to buy, sell and serve display advertising online.\n\nIn that case, which is set for trial in Virginia federal court next month, the government is seeking to force Google to sell off some of its advertising technology products.\n\nDan Morgan, a senior portfolio manager at Synovus Trust, said the decision adds to the \"black cloud\" of legal and regulatory uncertainty that has been hovering over the company.\n\n\"It does create some doubt in a company that already kind of disappointed on the quarter,\" he said.\n\nMehta's decision is \"reasonable and balanced,\" accepting some but not all of the government's arguments, which will likely help in any appeals, said William Kovacic, who teaches antitrust at George Washington Law School.\n\n\"His decision is measured and not simply a credulous acceptance of the government's arguments,\" said Kovacic, who served as chair of the Federal Trade Commission during the George W. Bush administration.\n\nSome of the Mehta's analysis about advertising markets may raise difficulties for the government as it pursues its second case against Google, Kovacic said.\n\nBut the opinion will likely be helpful for a number of the government's other antitrust cases awaiting trial against Apple, Amazon and Meta Platforms on how to consider justifications by the companies for their behavior, he said.\n\nMehta's decision is \"bold in a legally careful way that will do well on appeal,\" said Rebecca Allensworth, an antitrust professor at Vanderbilt Law School. It will \"lay the blueprint for other tech cases going forward.\"", "source": {"uri": "mybroadband.co.za", "dataType": "news", "title": "MyBroadband"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8260645907", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "19:31:41", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T19:31:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T19:31:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://www.aol.com/news/u-judge-rules-google-monopoly-185454663.html", "title": "U.S. judge rules Google has a monopoly on search in antitrust case", "body": "U.S. judge rules Google has a monopoly on search in antitrust caseAugust 5, 2024 at 8:54 PM\n\nWASHINGTON (Reuters) -Alphabet's Google broke the law with its monopoly over online searches and related ads, a federal judge ruled on Monday, in the U.S. Justice Department's first victory against a monopoly in more than 20 years.\n\nThe decision is a significant win for the Justice Department, which had sued the search engine giant over its control of about 90% of the online search market, and 95% on smartphones. The judge noted that Google had paid $26.3 billion in 2021 to ensure that its search is the default on smartphones and browsers, and to keep its dominant market share.\n\n\"The court reaches the following conclusion: Google is a monopolist, and it has acted as one to maintain its monopoly,\" U.S. District Judge Amit Mehta wrote.\n\nMehta's ruling against Alphabet's major revenue driver paves the way for a second trial to determine potential fixes, such as requiring the company to stop paying smartphone makers billions of dollars annually to set Google as the default search engine on new phones.\n\nThe ruling is the first major decision in a series of cases taking on alleged monopolies in Big Tech.\n\n(Reporting by Chris Sanders)", "source": {"uri": "aol.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8260719661", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "20:43:32", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T20:43:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T20:42:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://napavalleyregister.com/news/state-regional/google-illegally-maintains-monopoly-over-internet-search-judge-rules/article_40fdb002-aeb4-5213-a43a-ca9b39f73aff.html", "title": "Google illegally maintains monopoly over internet search, judge rules", "body": "FILE - Various Google logos are displayed on a Google search, Monday, Sept. 11, 2023, in New York. U.S. District Judge Amit Mehta ruled Monday, Aug. 5, 2024, that Google's ubiquitous search engine has been illegally exploiting its dominance to squash competition and stifle innovation in a seismic decision that could shake up the internet and hobble one of the world's best-known companies.\n\nBy MATTHEW BARAKAT and MICHAEL LIEDTKE - Associated Press\n\nWASHINGTON (AP) -- A judge on Monday ruled that Google's ubiquitous search engine has been illegally exploiting its dominance to squash competition and stifle innovation in a seismic decision that could shake up the internet and hobble one of the world's best-known companies.\n\nThe highly anticipated decision issued by U.S. District Judge Amit Mehta comes nearly a year after the start of a trial pitting the U.S. Justice Department against Google in the country's biggest antitrust showdown in a quarter century.\n\nAfter reviewing reams of evidence that included testimony from top executives at Google, Microsoft and Apple during last year's 10-week trial, Mehta issued his potentially market-shifting decision three months after the two sides presented their closing arguments in early May.\n\nPeople are also reading... Woman dies after being found near Highway 29 in St. Helena Update: Pedestrian, Calistoga cop involved in crash identified; woman critically injured Napa Main Street downtown block home to Cole's, Ben & Jerry's, others sold for $17.5 million Napa's Soscol Junction makes its partial debut. A Register reporter tests it. Wine attorney Richard Mendelson says Napa Valley can find 'common ground' 'No place in our community,' police and DA say after antisemitic flyers scattered in Napa Register Explainer: A deeper look at Belia Ramos vs. Debra Dommen Interconnected relationships at heart of restraining order case involving Napa supervisor and wine executive Dan Berger On Wine: Hard times in the industry California awards Le Petit Elephant $1.5 million to convert Napa church to day care center St. Helenans cycle from San Francisco to Los Angeles to raise awareness of AIDS CHP: Electric unicyclist suffers major injuries in Carneros hit-and-run Bankrupt owner of Napa Valley wineries announces 377 layoffs Chevron says it is moving its headquarters out of California Letter: A mom's thoughts about Le Petit Elephant\n\n\"After having carefully considered and weighed the witness testimony and evidence, the court reaches the following conclusion: Google is a monopolist, and it has acted as one to maintain its monopoly,\" Mehta wrote in his 277-page ruling.\n\nIt represents a major setback for Google and its parent, Alphabet Inc., which had steadfastly argued that its popularity stemmed from consumers' overwhelming desire to use a search engine so good at what it does that it has become synonymous with looking things up online. Google's search engine currently processes an estimated 8.5 billion queries per day worldwide, nearly doubling its daily volume from 12 years ago, according to a recent study released by the investment firm BOND.\n\nGoogle almost certainly will appeal the decision in a process that ultimately may land in the U.S. Supreme Court.\n\nFor now, the decision vindicates antitrust regulators at the Justice Department, which filed its lawsuit nearly four years ago while Donald Trump was still president, and has been escalating it efforts to rein in Big Tech's power during President Joe Biden's administration.\n\n\"This victory against Google is an historic win for the American people,\" said Attorney General Merrick Garland. \"No company -- no matter how large or influential -- is above the law. The Justice Department will continue to vigorously enforce our antitrust laws.\"\n\nThe case depicted Google as a technological bully that methodically has thwarted competition to protect a search engine that has become the centerpiece of a digital advertising machine that generated nearly $240 billion in revenue last year. Justice Department lawyers argued that Google's monopoly enabled it to charge advertisers artificially high prices while also enjoying the luxury of not having to invest more time and money into improving the quality of its search engine -- a lax approach that hurt consumers.\n\nAs expected, Mehta's ruling focused on the billions of dollars Google spends every year to install its search engine as the default option on new cellphones and tech gadgets. In 2021 alone, Google spent more than $26 billion to lock in those default agreements, Mehta said in his ruling.\n\nGoogle ridiculed those allegations, noting that consumers have historically changed search engines when they become disillusioned with the results they were getting. For instance, Yahoo -- now a minor player on the internet -- was the most popular search engine during the 1990s before Google came along.\n\nMehta said the evidence at trial showed the importance of the default settings. He noted that Microsoft's Bing search engine has 80% share of the search market on the Microsoft Edge browser. The judge said that shows other search engines can be successful if Google is not locked in as the predetermined default option.\n\n\"Advertisers consistently testified that shifting significant ad spending from Google to Bing would be ineffective (and unwise) because of Bing's lack of scale,\" Mehta wrote.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nStill, Mehta credited the quality of Google's product as an important part of its dominance, as well, saying flatly that \"Google is widely recognized as the best (general search engine) available in the United States.\"\n\nMehta's conclusion that Google has been running an illegal monopoly sets up another legal phase to determine what sorts of changes or penalties should be imposed to reverse the damage done and restore a more competitive landscape.\n\n\"The court confirmed what almost everyone in the industry already knew: that Google is a monopoly and is abusing its power to harm consumers and enrich itself,\" said Roger Alford, a law professor at the University of Notre Dame.\n\nThe potential outcome could result in a wide-ranging order requiring Google to dismantle some of the pillars of its internet empire or prevent it from shelling out billions annually to ensure its search engine automatically answers queries on the iPhone and other internet-connected devices. After the next phase, the judge could conclude only modest changes are required to level the playing field.\n\n\"Google's loss in its search antitrust trial could be a huge deal -- depending on the remedy,\" said eMarketer senior analyst Evelyn Mitchell-Wolf. \"A forced divestiture of the search business would sever Alphabet from its largest source of revenue. But even losing its capacity to strike exclusive default agreements could be detrimental for Google. Its ubiquity is its biggest strength, especially as competition heats up among AI-powered search alternatives.\"\n\nRegardless she added, a drawn-out appeals process will delay any immediate effects for both consumers and advertisers.\n\nIf there is a significant shakeup, it could turn out to be a coup for Microsoft, whose own power was undermined during the late 1990s when the Justice Department targeted the software maker in an antitrust lawsuit accusing it of abusing the dominance of its Windows operating system on personal computers to lock out competition.\n\nThat Microsoft case mirrored the one brought against Google in several ways and now the result could also echo similarly. Just as Microsoft's bruising antitrust battle created distractions and obstacles that opened up more opportunities for Google after its 1998 inception, the decision against Google could be a boon for Microsoft, which already has a market value of more than $3 trillion. At one time, Alphabet was worth more than Microsoft, but now trails its rival with a market value of about $2 trillion.\n\nBesides boosting Microsoft's Bing search engine, the outcome could hurt Google at a critical pivot point that is tilting technology in the age of artificial intelligence. Both Microsoft and Google are among the early leaders in AI in a battle that now could be affected by Mehta's market-rattling decision.\n\nMicrosoft CEO Satya Nadella was one of the Justice Department's star witnesses during the testimony that covered his frustration with Google deals with the likes of Apple that made it nearly impossible for the Bing search engine to make any headway, even as Microsoft poured more than $100 billion in improvements since 2009.\n\n\"You get up in the morning, you brush your teeth and you search on Google,\" Nadella said at one point in his testimony. \"Everybody talks about the open web, but there is really the Google web.\"\n\nNadella also expressed fear that it might take an antitrust crackdown to ensure the situation didn't get worse as AI becomes a bigger force in search.\n\n\"Despite my enthusiasm that there is a new angle with A.I., I worry a lot that this vicious cycle that I'm trapped in could get even more vicious,\" Nadella said on the stand.\n\nGoogle faces several other legal threats both in the U.S. and abroad. In September, a federal trial is scheduled to begin in Virginia over the Justice Department's allegations that Google's advertising technology constitutes an illegal monopoly.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. {"uri": "2024-08-445551228", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "10:23:11", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T10:23:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T10:19:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://uk.finance.yahoo.com/news/does-google-monopoly-ruling-us-101936497.html", "title": "What does Google monopoly ruling in US mean for the search engine?", "body": "Google has illegally exploited its dominance in the search engine market to stifle competition, a judge in the US has ruled.\n\nThe case has been seen as a potentially seismic moment for Google and the tech sector given its control of search and its related advertising business.\n\nHere is a closer look at the case and what it could mean for Google and the wider industry.\n\n- What has happened?\n\nIn 2020, Google was sued by the US Department of Justice, which claimed the tech giant has abused its dominance in online search and advertising to stifle competition and harm consumers.\n\nDuring the case, lawyers argued that Google's monopoly enabled it to charge advertisers artificially high prices while also enjoying the luxury of having more time and money to invest in improving its search engine, an approach which impacted consumers.\n\nFor its part, Google dismissed these suggestions, arguing that consumers have historically changed search engines when they become dissatisfied with the results - highlighting how Yahoo had once dominated search in the 1990s before Google appeared.\n\nBut ultimately, after several months of reviewing evidence, the judge ruled that Google had breached US antitrust laws in how it operated.\n\n- What did the judge say?\n\nIn his decision, US District Judge Amit Mehta said Google was a \"monopolist\" that had \"acted as one to maintain its monopoly\".\n\nUS attorney general Merrick Garland said the \"victory against Google is an historic win for the American people\".\n\n\"No company, no matter how large or influential, is above the law. The Justice Department will continue to vigorously enforce our antitrust laws,\" he said.\n\nThe technology giant is widely expected to appeal against the decision, and the process could take it all the way to the US Supreme Court.\n\n- What does the decision mean for Google and the wider tech sector?\n\nThis is the biggest question to come out of the case.\n\nThe decision by the judge sets up another legal phase where it must be decided what changes or penalties should be imposed on Google in order to protect competition.\n\nThe outcome of that decision could have a huge impact on the tech sector, as the changes could be as drastic as asking the company to dismantle parts of its online empire, or stop it spending huge sums of money each year to ensure Google search is the default search engine on the iPhone and other devices.\n\nOr the judge could decide that only more modest changes are needed to protect competition and consumers, leaving Google relatively unscathed.\n\nAny changes imposed would come at a critical time in the sector, as Google battles with Microsoft and others to lead the industry as it enters the age of AI.", "source": {"uri": "uk.finance.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo! {"uri": "2024-08-445131354", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "01:54:53", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T01:54:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T01:44:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://www.financialexpress.com/life/technology-google-has-an-illegal-monopoly-on-search-us-judge-finds-3574657/", "title": "Google has an illegal monopoly on search, US judge finds", "body": "A U.S. judge ruled on Monday that Google violated antitrust law, spending billions of dollars to create an illegal monopoly and become the world's default search engine, the first big win for federal authorities taking on Big Tech's market dominance. The ruling paves the way for a second trial to determine potential fixes, possibly including a breakup of Google parent Alphabet, which would change the landscape of the online advertising world that Google has dominated for years.\n\nIt is also a green light to aggressive U.S. antitrust enforcers prosecuting Big Tech, a sector that has been under fire from across the political spectrum. \"The court reaches the following conclusion: Google is a monopolist, and it has acted as one to maintain its monopoly,\" U.S. District Judge Amit Mehta, Washington, D.C., wrote. Google controls about 90% of the online search market and 95% on smartphones.\n\nAlphabet said it plans to appeal Mehta's ruling. \"This decision recognizes that Google offers the best search engine, but concludes that we shouldn't be allowed to make it easily available,\" Google said in a statement.U.S. Attorney General Merrick Garland called the ruling \"a historic win for the American people,\" adding that \"no company - no matter how large or influential - is above the law.\"White House press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre said the \"pro-competition ruling is a victory for the American people,\" adding that \"Americans deserve an internet that is free, fair, and open for competition.\"\n\nBILLIONS PAID\n\nMehta noted that Google had paid $26.3 billion in 2021 alone to ensure that its search engine is the default on smartphones and browsers, and to keep its dominant market share.\"The default is extremely valuable real estate,\" Mehta wrote. \"Even if a new entrant were positioned from a quality standpoint to bid for the default when an agreement expires, such a firm could compete only if it were prepared to pay partners upwards of billions of dollars in revenue share and make them whole for any revenue shortfalls resulting from the change.\"\n\nHe added, \"Google, of course, recognizes that losing defaults would dramatically impact its bottom line. For instance, Google has projected that losing the Safari default would result in a significant drop in queries and billions of dollars in lost revenues.\" The ruling is the first major decision in a series of cases taking on alleged monopolies in Big Tech. This case, filed by the Trump administration, went before a judge from September to November of last year.\n\n\"A forced divestiture of the search business would sever Alphabet from its largest source of revenue. But even losing its capacity to strike exclusive default agreements could be detrimental for Google,\" said Emarketer senior analyst Evelyn Mitchell-Wolf, who said a drawn-out legal process would delay any immediate effects for consumers.\n\nIn the past four years, federal antitrust regulators have also sued Meta Platforms, Amazon.com and Apple , claiming the companies have illegally maintained monopolies. Those cases all began under the administration of former President Donald Trump.Senator Amy Klobuchar, a Democrat who chairs the Senate Judiciary Committee's antitrust subcommittee, said the fact that the case spanned administrations shows strong bipartisan support for antitrust enforcement.\n\n\"It's a huge victory for the American people that antitrust enforcement is alive and well when it comes to competition,\" she said. \"Google is a rampant monopolist. \"When it was filed in 2020, the Google search case was the first time in a generation that the U.S. government accused a major corporation of an illegal monopoly. Microsoft settled with the Justice Department in 2004 over claims that it forced its Internet Explorer Web browser on Windows users.", "source": {"uri": "financialexpress.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8260737721", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "21:02:50", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T21:02:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T21:01:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://www.mycentraloregon.com/2024/08/05/google-violated-antitrust-laws-to-maintain-dominance-over-online-search-judge-says/", "title": "Google violated antitrust laws to maintain dominance over online search, judge says", "body": "(WASHINGTON) -- Google violated U.S. antitrust laws in maintaining a monopoly over the online search business, a federal judge ruled Monday, in a landmark ruling for the Justice Department in its efforts to rein in big tech giants.\n\nD.C. District judge Amit Mehta declared Google violated Section 2 of the Sherman Act, finding the company illegally secured its dominance in the search market by paying billions of dollars to smartphone carriers like Apple to make Google the automatic search engine for their phones -- effectively locking any rival businesses from being able to compete.\n\n\"Google is a monopolist, and it has acted as one to maintain its monopoly,\" Mehta wrote in his ruling.\n\nThe ruling followed a 10-week trial in Washington, D.C., last year where Justice Department officials and several dozen state attorneys general sought to put on full display Google's anti-competitive tactics that paved the way for it to become the world's leading search engine.\n\nWhile Mehta's ruling does not prescribe any specific remedies, he will now have to decide appropriate steps to address Google's monopoly that experts say could include specific orders to the company to address its business practices or, more drastically, force it to sell off parts of the company.\n\nIn a statement, Google instead chose to focus on the positive comments the judge made in the ruling.\n\n\"This decision recognizes that Google offers the best search engine, but concludes that we shouldn't be allowed to make it easily available,\" Kent Walker, Google's president for global affairs, said in the statement about the ruling. \"We appreciate the Court's finding that Google is 'the industry's highest quality search engine, which has earned Google the trust of hundreds of millions of daily users', that Google 'has long been the best search engine, particularly on mobile devices', 'has continued to innovate in search' and that 'Apple and Mozilla occasionally assess Google's search quality relative to its rivals and find Google's to be superior.'\"\n\nHe continued, confirming the company will appeal, saying, \"Given this, and that people are increasingly looking for information in more and more ways, we plan to appeal. As this process continues, we will remain focused on making products that people find helpful and easy to use.\"\n\nThe Justice Department did not immediately respond to a request for comment on the {"uri": "2024-08-445155396", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "02:47:32", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T02:47:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T22:55:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://arab.news/6t2zh", "title": "Google has an illegal monopoly on search, US judge finds", "body": "US Attorney General Merrick Garland called the ruling \"a historic win for the American people,\" adding that \"no company -- no matter how large or influential -- is above the law\"\n\nWASHINGTON: A US judge ruled on Monday that Google violated antitrust law, spending billions of dollars to create an illegal monopoly and become the world's default search engine, the first big win for federal authorities taking on Big Tech's market dominance.\n\nThe ruling paves the way for a second trial to determine potential fixes, possibly including a breakup of Google parent Alphabet, which would change the landscape of the online advertising world that Google has dominated for years.\n\nIt is also a green light to aggressive US antitrust enforcers prosecuting Big Tech, a sector that has been under fire from across the political spectrum. \"The court reaches the following conclusion: Google is a monopolizt, and it has acted as one to maintain its monopoly,\" District Judge Amit Mehta wrote. The search engine giant controls about 90 percent of the online search market, and 95 percent on smartphones.\n\nThe \"remedy\" phase could be lengthy, followed by potential appeals to the District of Columbia Circuit and US Supreme Court. The legal wrangling could play out into next year, or even 2026. Shares of Google parent Alphabet fell 4.5 percent on Monday as part of a broad tech share decline. Google advertising was 77 percent of Alphabet's total sales in 2023.\n\nAlphabet said it plans to appeal Mehta's ruling. \"This decision recognizes that Google offers the best search engine, but concludes that we shouldn't be allowed to make it easily available,\" Google said in a statement.\n\nUS Attorney General Merrick Garland called the ruling \"a historic win for the American people,\" adding that \"no company -- no matter how large or influential -- is above the law.\"\n\nBILLIONS PAID\n\nMehta noted that Google had paid $26.3 billion in 2021 alone to ensure that its search engine is the default on smartphones and browsers, and to keep its dominant market share.\n\n\"The default is extremely valuable real estate ... Even if a new entrant were positioned from a quality standpoint to bid for the default when an agreement expires, such a firm could compete only if it were prepared to pay partners upwards of billions of dollars in revenue share and make them whole for any revenue shortfalls resulting from the change,\" Mehta wrote.\n\nHe added, \"Google, of course, recognizes that losing defaults would dramatically impact its bottom line. For instance, Google has projected that losing the Safari default would result in a significant drop in queries and billions of dollars in lost revenues.\" The ruling is the first major decision in a series of cases taking on alleged monopolies in Big Tech. This case, filed by the Trump administration, went before a judge from September to November of last year.\n\n\"A forced divestiture of the search business would sever Alphabet from its largest source of revenue. But even losing its capacity to strike exclusive default agreements could be detrimental for Google,\" said Emarketer senior analyst Evelyn Mitchell-Wolf, who said a drawn-out legal process would delay any immediate effects for consumers.\n\nIn the past four years, federal antitrust regulators have also sued Meta Platforms, Amazon.com and Apple , claiming the companies have illegally maintained monopolies. Those cases all began under the administration of former President Donald Trump.\n\nAmy Klobuchar, a Democratic US senator who chairs the Senate Judiciary Committee's antitrust subcommittee, said the fact that the case spanned administrations shows strong bipartisan support for antitrust enforcement.\n\n\"It's a huge victory for the American people that antitrust enforcement is alive and well when it comes to competition,\" she said. \"Google is a rampant monopolizt.\"\n\nWhen it was filed in 2020, the Google search case was the first time in a generation that the US government accused a major corporation of an illegal monopoly. Microsoft settled with the Justice Department in 2004 over claims that it forced its Internet Explorer Web browser on Windows users.", "source": {"uri": "arab.news", "dataType": "news", "title": "Arab {"uri": "8260895359", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "00:16:11", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T00:16:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T00:15:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/world/us/google-illegally-maintains-monopoly-over-internet-search-judge-rules/articleshow/112302371.cms", "title": "Google illegally maintains monopoly over internet search, US judge rules in landmark antitrust case - Times of India", "body": "US district judge Amit Mehta said that Google's dominant search engine has been unlawfully leveraged to stifle competition and innovation. The decision, which could significantly disrupt the internet landscape, marks one of the most consequential antitrust rulings in recent history.\n\nThe ruling follows nearly a year of litigation in a trial that pitted the US Justice Department against Google, marking the largest antitrust case in the US in over 25 years.After reviewing extensive evidence and testimony from high-profile executives at Google, Microsoft, and Apple, Judge Mehta issued his 277-page decision three months after final arguments were presented.\n\n'Google is a Monopolist'\n\nJudge Mehta's ruling was unequivocal: \"Google is a monopolist, and it has acted as one to maintain its monopoly.\" The judge underscored Google's overwhelming control of the search market, citing its 89.2% share of general search services, which soars to 94.9% on mobile devices.\n\nThis decision delivers a significant blow to Google and its parent company, Alphabet Inc., which has long maintained that its market dominance is a result of consumer preference. Google's search engine processes an estimated 8.5 billion queries daily, nearly doubling its volume over the past decade.\n\nDespite the setback, Google plans to appeal the ruling. Kent Walker, Google's president of global affairs, defended the company's practices, saying, \"This decision recognizes that Google offers the best search engine, but concludes that we shouldn't be allowed to make it easily available.\"\n\nA victory for antitrust regulators\n\nFor the US Justice Department, the ruling represents a substantial victory in its efforts to curb Big Tech's power. Attorney General Merrick Garland hailed the decision as \"an historic win for the American people,\" emphasizing that no company, regardless of size or influence, is above the law.\n\nThe trial cast Google as a technological bully, using its dominance to extract artificially high prices from advertisers while curbing competition. Prosecutors argued that Google's monopoly not only hurt competitors but also diminished the quality of its own service by reducing incentives to innovate.\n\nJudge Mehta's ruling pointed to Google's billions of dollars spent annually to secure its search engine as the default option on devices as a key factor in maintaining its monopoly. In 2021 alone, Google spent over $26 billion to lock in these agreements.\n\nThe path forward\n\nMehta's conclusion sets the stage for a new legal phase focused on determining the remedies required to restore competition. A hearing is scheduled for September 6 to begin discussing potential measures, which could range from dismantling parts of Google's operations to banning default search agreements.\n\nHowever, any significant changes are likely to be delayed by a lengthy appeals process, which experts predict could last up to five years. During this time, Google may fend off immediate restrictions, though it could still face class-action lawsuits from advertisers.\n\nThe ruling also poses potential risks for Apple, which benefits from Google's payments to make its search engine the default on iPhones. Google reportedly paid Apple around $20 billion in 2022 alone, a figure that has doubled since 2020.\n\nImplications for the tech industry\n\nThis decision could have broader implications for the tech industry, particularly for Microsoft, which has been positioning itself as a counterweight to Google in the search market. If Mehta enforces limits on Google's default search agreements, it could open up opportunities for Microsoft's Bing, which currently dominates searches on the Microsoft Edge browser.\n\nThe ruling also reflects the Biden administration's aggressive stance against Big Tech, with the Justice Department pursuing cases against other giants like Apple, Ticketmaster, and even exploring the role of companies like Microsoft, Nvidia, and OpenAI in the burgeoning AI sector.\n\nAt TOI World Desk, our dedicated team of seasoned journalists and passionate writers tirelessly sifts through the vast tapestry of global events to bring you the latest news and diverse perspectives round the clock. With an unwavering commitment to accuracy, depth, and timeliness, we strive to keep you informed about the ever-evolving world, delivering a nuanced understanding of international affairs to our readers. {"uri": "8260963041", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "01:46:13", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T01:46:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T01:44:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://www.chinadailyasia.com/hk/article/589900", "title": "Google has an illegal monopoly on search, US judge finds", "body": "WASHINGTON - A US judge ruled on Monday that Google violated antitrust law, spending billions of dollars to create an illegal monopoly and become the world's default search engine, the first big win for federal authorities taking on Big Tech's market dominance.\n\nThe ruling paves the way for a second trial to determine potential fixes, possibly including a breakup of Google parent Alphabet, which would change the landscape of the online advertising world that Google has dominated for years.\n\nIt is also a green light to aggressive US antitrust enforcers prosecuting Big Tech, a sector that has been under fire from across the political spectrum.\n\nALSO READ: Google scraps plan to remove cookies from Chrome\n\n\"The court reaches the following conclusion: Google is a monopolist, and it has acted as one to maintain its monopoly,\" US District Judge Amit Mehta, Washington, DC, wrote. Google controls about 90 percent of the online search market and 95 percent on smartphones.\n\nThe \"remedy\" phase could be lengthy, followed by potential appeals to the US Court of Appeals, District of Columbia Circuit and the US Supreme Court. The legal wrangling could play out into next year, or even 2026.\n\nShares of Alphabet fell 4.5 percenton Monday amid a broad decline in tech shares as the wider stock market cratered on recession fears. Google advertising was 77 percent of Alphabet's total sales in 2023.\n\nAlphabet said it plans to appeal Mehta's ruling. \"This decision recognizes that Google offers the best search engine, but concludes that we shouldn't be allowed to make it easily available,\" Google said in a statement.\n\nREAD MORE: Amazon says consumers cautious, forecasts revenue below Wall Street targets\n\nUS Attorney General Merrick Garland called the ruling \"a historic win for the American people,\" adding that \"no company - no matter how large or influential - is above the law.\"\n\nWhite House press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre said the \"pro-competition ruling is a victory for the American people,\" adding that \"Americans deserve an internet that is free, fair, and open for competition.\"\n\nBillions paid\n\nMehta noted that Google had paid $26.3 billion in 2021 alone to ensure that its search engine is the default on smartphones and browsers, and to keep its dominant market share.\n\n\"The default is extremely valuable real estate,\" Mehta wrote. \"Even if a new entrant were positioned from a quality standpoint to bid for the default when an agreement expires, such a firm could compete only if it were prepared to pay partners upwards of billions of dollars in revenue share and make them whole for any revenue shortfalls resulting from the change.\"\n\nALSO READ: Apple used Google's chips to train two AI models, research paper shows\n\nHe added, \"Google, of course, recognizes that losing defaults would dramatically impact its bottom line. For instance, Google has projected that losing the Safari default would result in a significant drop in queries and billions of dollars in lost revenues.\"\n\nThe ruling is the first major decision in a series of cases taking on alleged monopolies in Big Tech. This case, filed by the Trump administration, went before a judge from September to November of last year.\n\n\"A forced divestiture of the search business would sever Alphabet from its largest source of revenue. But even losing its capacity to strike exclusive default agreements could be detrimental for Google,\" said Emarketer senior analyst Evelyn Mitchell-Wolf, who said a drawn-out legal process would delay any immediate effects for consumers.\n\nIn the past four years, federal antitrust regulators have also sued Meta Platforms, Amazon.com and Apple, claiming the companies have illegally maintained monopolies.\n\nThose cases all began under the administration of former President Donald Trump.\n\nREAD MORE: Italy's antitrust launches probe into Google over unfair commercial practices\n\nSenator Amy Klobuchar, a Democrat who chairs the Senate Judiciary Committee's antitrust subcommittee, said the fact that the case spanned administrations shows strong bipartisan support for antitrust enforcement.\n\n\"It's a huge victory for the American people that antitrust enforcement is alive and well when it comes to competition,\" she said. \"Google is a rampant monopolist.\"\n\nWhen it was filed in 2020, the Google search case was the first time in a generation that the US government accused a major corporation of an illegal monopoly. Microsoft settled with the Justice Department in 2004 over claims that it forced its Internet Explorer Web browser on Windows users.", "source": {"uri": "chinadailyasia.com", "dataType": "news", Discovery 3 days ago\n\nGoogle broke the law by inking multibillion-dollar deals to make its search engine the default on smartphone web browsers including those from Apple and Samsung, a federal judge ruled Monday.\n\nJudge Amit Mehta of U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia said Google's payments -- estimated to be more than $26 billion in 2021 -- effectively blocked any other competitor from succeeding in the market. In a 277-page ruling Monday, he wrote that Google had abused its monopoly in the internet search business.\n\n\"Google is a monopolist, and it has acted as one to maintain its monopoly,\" Judge Mehta wrote in the ruling.\n\nGoogle did not immediately respond to a request for comment.\n\nIn 2020, the Justice Department, joined by several state attorneys general, filed an antitrust lawsuit against Google, alleging that the company had a virtual monopoly on search and search advertising to the detriment of consumers and competitors.", "source": {"uri": "variety.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Variety"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Google", "type": "org", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Google"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Warner_Bros._Discovery", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Warner Bros. {"uri": "8261661263", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "11:07:56", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T11:07:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T11:07:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://www.rt.com/news/602226-google-illegal-monopoly-court/", "title": "Google is an illegal monopoly - court ruling  --  RT World News", "body": "American tech giant Google broke the law by establishing a monopoly on online searches, a federal judge ruled on Monday.\n\nThe decision is seen as a major victory for US antitrust authorities, who have filed several lawsuits against big tech firms in a bid to strengthen competition in the industry, Reuters noted.\n\nThe case, initiated by the US Department of Justice in 2020, argued that Google has maintained its dominance of the search market by creating barriers to entry for other providers.\n\n\"After having carefully considered and weighed the witness testimony and evidence, the court reaches the following conclusion: Google is a monopolist, and it has acted as one to maintain its monopoly,\" states the ruling issued by US District Court for the District of Columbia.\n\nGoogle \"enjoys an 89.2% share of the market for general search services, which increases to 94.9% on mobile devices,\" the ruling reads.\n\nGoogle has paid billions of dollars to device manufacturers to ensure its position as the default search engine on smartphones and browsers, Judge Amit Mehta said.\n\nThe Department of Justice has hailed the decision as \"an historic win for the American people,\" noting that \"no company - no matter how large or influential - is above the law.\"\n\nThe ruling \"recognizes that Google offers the best search engine,\" Kent Walker, president of global affairs at Google's parent company Alphabet, said in a statement on X (formerly Twitter). The company plans to appeal, Walker added.\n\nIt is unclear what penalties Alphabet will face. According to Reuters, a second trial may be held to determine potential fixes, possibly including a breakup of the tech giant.\n\nThe company faces a separate lawsuit over its advertising technology, scheduled to go to trial in September.\n\nGoogle has also been fined billions of euros in monopoly cases in the EU.\n\nOther Big Tech companies, including Facebook owner Meta Platforms, Amazon and Apple, have also been sued by federal antitrust regulators for allegedly operating unlawful monopolies.", "source": {"uri": "rt.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "RT"}, "authors": [], "concepts": {"uri": "8260664909", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "19:50:36", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T19:50:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T19:50:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://www.pbs.org/newshour/nation/court-rules-googles-search-engine-dominance-is-antitrust-violation-and-illegal", "title": "Court rules Google's search engine dominance is antitrust violation and illegal", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- A judge on Monday ruled that Google's ubiquitous search engine has been illegally exploiting its dominance to squash competition and stifle innovation in a seismic decision that could shake up the internet and hobble one of the world's best-known companies.\n\nThe highly anticipated decision issued by U.S. District Judge Amit Mehta comes nearly a year after the start of a trial pitting the U.S. Justice Department against Google in the country's biggest antitrust showdown in a quarter century.\n\nWATCH: Why the Google antitrust trial could change how we use the internet\n\nAfter reviewing reams of evidence that included testimony from top executives at Google, Microsoft and Apple during last year's 10-week trial, Mehta issued his potentially market-shifting decision three months after the two sides presented their closing arguments in early May.\n\nIt represents a major setback for Google and its parent, Alphabet Inc., which had steadfastly argued that its popularity stemmed from consumers' overwhelming desire to use a search engine so good at what it does that it has become synonymous with looking things up online. Google's search engine currently processes an estimated 8.5 billion queries per day worldwide, nearly doubling its daily volume from 12 years ago, according to a recent study released by the investment firm BOND.\n\nGoogle almost certainly will appeal the decision in a process that ultimately may land in the U..S. Supreme Court.\n\nFor now, the decision vindicates antitrust regulators at the Justice Department, which filed its lawsuit nearly four years ago while Donald Trump was still president, and has been escalating it efforts to rein in Big Tech's power during President Joe Biden's administration.\n\nThe case depicted Google as a technological bully that methodically has thwarted competition to protect a search engine that has become the centerpiece of a digital advertising machine that generated nearly $240 billion in revenue last year. Justice Department lawyers argued that Google's monopoly enabled it to charge advertisers artificially high prices while also enjoying the luxury of having to invest more time and money into improving the quality of its search engine -- a lax approach that hurt consumers.\n\nGoogle ridiculed those allegations, noting that consumers have historically changed search engines when they become disillusioned with the results they were getting. For instance, Yahoo -- now a minor player on the internet -- was the most popular search engine during the 1990s before Google came along.\n\nMehta's conclusion that Google has been running an illegal monopoly sets up another legal phase to determine what sorts of changes or penalties should be imposed to reverse the damage done and restore a more competitive landscape.\n\nThe potential outcome could result in a wide-ranging order requiring Google to dismantle some of the pillars of its internet empire or prevent it from shelling out more than $20 billion annually to ensure its search engine automatically answers queries on the iPhone and other internet-connected devices. After the next phase, the judge could conclude only modest changes are required to level the playing field.\n\nIf there is a significant shakeup, it could turn out to be a coup for Microsoft, whose own power was undermined during the late 1990s when the Justice Department targeted the software maker in an antitrust lawsuit accusing it of abusing the dominance of its Windows operating system on personal computers to lock out competition.\n\nThat Microsoft case mirrored the one brought against Google in several ways and now the result could also echo similarly. Just as Microsoft's bruising antitrust battle created distractions and obstacles that opened up more opportunities for Google after its 1998 inception, the decision against Google could be a boon for Microsoft, which already has a market value of more than $3 trillion. At one time, Alphabet was worth more than Microsoft, but now trails its rival with a market value of about $2 trillion.\n\nWATCH: Why the DOJ and 16 states are suing Apple in a landmark antitrust case\n\nBesides boosting Microsoft's Bing search engine, the outcome could hurt Google at a critical pivot point that is tilting technology in the age of artificial intelligence. Both Microsoft and Google are among the early leaders in AI in a battle that now could be affected by Mehta's market-rattling decision.\n\nMicrosoft CEO Satya Nadella was one of the Justice Department's star witnesses during the testimony that covered his frustration with Google deals with the likes of Apple that made it nearly impossible for the Bing search engine to make any headway, even as Microsoft poured more than $100 billion in improvements since 2009.\n\n\"You get up in the morning, you brush your teeth and you search on Google,\" Nadella said at one point in his testimony. \"Everybody talks about the open web, but there is really the Google web.\"\n\nNadella also expressed fear that it might take an antitrust crackdown to ensure the situation didn't get worse as AI becomes a bigger force in search.\n\n\"Despite my enthusiasm that there is a new angle with A.I., I worry a lot that this vicious cycle that I'm trapped in could get even more vicious,\" Nadella said on the stand.\n\nGoogle still faces other legal threats besides this one, both in the U.S. and abroad. any antitrust lawsuits brought against Google domestically and abroad. In September, a federal trial is scheduled to begin in Virginia over the Justice Department's allegations that Google's advertising technology constitutes an illegal monopoly.", "source": {"uri": "pbs.org", "dataType": "news", "title": "PBS.org"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@pbs.org", "name": "Associated Press", "type": "author", "isAgency": true}, {"uri": "matthew_barakat@pbs.org", "name": "Matthew Barakat", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}, {"uri": "michael_liedtke@pbs.org", "name": "Michael Liedtke", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": {"eng": "Internet"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Google", "type": "org", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Google"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alphabet_Inc.", "type": "org", {"uri": "2024-08-445637457", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "11:38:09", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T11:38:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T11:30:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://www.thedailystar.net/tech-startup/news/us-judge-rules-google-monopolist-3670816", "title": "US judge rules that Google is a 'monopolist'", "body": "In light of Google's current emphasis on cost efficiency, discontinuing cached links could result in significant resource savings by allowing the deletion of cache data. Image: Pawel Czerwinski/ Unsplash.\n\nA federal judge has ruled that Google violated US antitrust law by maintaining a monopoly in the search and advertising markets. This decision marks a significant victory for the Department of Justice (DOJ) in its ongoing battle against the tech giant.\n\nIn his ruling, Judge Amit Mehta stated, \"After having carefully considered and weighed the witness testimony and evidence, the court reaches the following conclusion: Google is a monopolist, and it has acted as one to maintain its monopoly. It has violated Section 2 of the Sherman Act.\"\n\nMajor victory for the DOJ\n\nJudge Mehta's decision represents a major win for the DOJ, which accused Google of illegally monopolizing the online search market. However, the judge did not support all of the government's claims. He rejected the argument that Google holds monopoly power in a specific segment of the advertising market. Nevertheless, he agreed that Google has a monopoly in \"general search services\" and \"general search text advertising.\"\n\nThe ruling's implications for Google's future remain unclear, as it addresses only the company's liability, not potential remedies. The next phase of proceedings will determine what actions Google must take, which could range from altering business practices to possibly breaking up its search business.\n\nGoogle plans to appeal\n\nGoogle has announced plans to appeal the ruling. Kent Walker, Google's president of global affairs, stated, \"This decision recognizes that Google offers the best search engine, but concludes that we shouldn't be allowed to make it easily available. As this process continues, we will remain focused on making products that people find helpful and easy to use.\"\n\nReactions from key players\n\nDOJ antitrust chief Jonathan Kanter hailed the ruling as a landmark decision. \"This landmark decision holds Google accountable. It paves the path for innovation for generations to come and protects access to information for all Americans,\" Kanter said.\n\nDuckDuckGo, a smaller competitor whose CEO testified against Google, also welcomed the ruling. Kamyl Bazbaz, the company's senior vice president for public affairs, remarked, \"The journey ahead will be long. As we are seeing in the EU and other places, Google will do anything it can to avoid changing its conduct. However, we know there is pent-up demand for alternatives in search and this ruling will support access to more options.\"\n\nExamination of Google's practices\n\nJudge Mehta dismissed Google's defense that its contracts with phone and browser makers like Apple were not exclusionary. He highlighted how Google's guaranteed revenue dissuades Apple from launching its own search engine, even though it has the capacity to do so. Mehta drew parallels with the landmark US v. Microsoft case, stating that the same conduct can be exclusionary when performed by a dominant player, regardless of whether it was consistent before and after achieving market dominance.\n\n\"Google's monopoly in general search\" was described as \"remarkably durable,\" with its market share increasing from about 80 percent in 2009 to 90 percent by 2020. In comparison, Bing holds less than 6 percent of the market share. Mehta noted that despite the appearance of competition, Google remains the only real choice for a default general search engine.\n\nImpact on the digital advertising market\n\nMehta's ruling also addressed Google's exclusive agreements in search text advertising, allowing it to raise prices without significant competitive pressure. Google's argument that ad prices, adjusted for quality, had decreased was deemed weak by the judge. He pointed out that Google's practices primarily aimed to drive long-term revenues rather than reflecting principled pricing.\n\nNo sanctions for evidence destruction\n\nAlthough the DOJ requested sanctions against Google for not preserving relevant chat messages, Mehta declined to impose them. He noted that while Google avoided sanctions this time, future cases might not be as lenient.\n\nThis decision is the first in a series of tech monopoly cases initiated by the US government in recent years. Amazon, Apple, and Meta also face monopolization lawsuits. Google is set for another trial in September, focusing on whether it has illegally monopolized digital advertising technology. Mehta's decision may influence how other judges apply antitrust laws to modern digital markets.\n\nThe next steps in this landmark case will determine the future landscape of competition in the search and advertising markets, as the court moves forward to decide on appropriate remedies.", "source": {"uri": "thedailystar.net", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Daily Star"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8260671774", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "19:58:46", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T19:58:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T19:56:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://www.channelnewsasia.com/business/google-has-illegal-monopoly-search-us-judge-finds-4528311", "title": "Google has an illegal monopoly on search, US judge finds", "body": "WASHINGTON :Alphabet's Google broke the law with monopolistic behavior over online search and related advertising, a federal judge ruled on Monday, the first victory for U.S. antitrust authorities who have filed numerous lawsuits challenging Big Tech's market dominance.\n\nThe decision is a significant win for the Justice Department, which had sued the search engine giant over its control of about 90 per cent of the online search market, and 95 per cent on smartphones.\n\n\"The court reaches the following conclusion: Google is a monopolist, and it has acted as one to maintain its monopoly,\" U.S. District Judge Amit Mehta wrote.\n\nHis ruling against Google paves the way for a second trial to determine potential fixes, such as breaking up the company or requiring the company to stop paying smartphone makers billions of dollars annually to set Google as the default search engine on new phones.\n\nUltimately, Google will have a chance to appeal the court's rulings to the U.S. District Court of Appeal for the D.C. Circuit.\n\nShares of Google parent Alphabet fell 4.3 per cent on Monday as part of a broad tech share decline.\n\nMehta noted that Google had paid $26.3 billion in 2021 alone to ensure that its search engine is the default on smartphones and browsers, and to keep its dominant market share.\n\n\"The default is extremely valuable real estate... Even if a new entrant were positioned from a quality standpoint to bid for the default when an agreement expires, such a firm could compete only if it were prepared to pay partners upwards of billions of dollars in revenue share and make them whole for any revenue shortfalls resulting from the change,\" Mehta wrote.\n\nHe noted \"Google, of course, recognizes that losing defaults would dramatically impact its bottom line. For instance, Google has projected that losing the Safari default would result in a significant drop in queries and billions of dollars in lost revenues.\"\n\nThe ruling is the first major decision in a series of cases taking on alleged monopolies in Big Tech.\n\n\"A forced divestiture of the search business would sever Alphabet from its largest source of revenue. But even losing its capacity to strike exclusive default agreements could be detrimental for Google,\" said Emarketer senior analyst Evelyn Mitchell-Wolf, who noted a drawn out legal process will delay any immediate effects for consumers.\n\nIn the past four years, federal antitrust regulators have also sued Meta Platforms, Amazon.com, and Apple Inc, claiming the companies have illegally maintained monopolies. Another case against Google over its advertising technology is scheduled to go to trial in September.\n\nWhen it was filed in 2020, the Google search case was the first time in a generation that the U.S. government accused a major corporation of an illegal monopoly. Microsoft settled with the Justice Department in 2004 over claims that it forced its Internet Explorer web browser on Windows users.", "source": {"uri": "channelnewsasia.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8261275065", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "06:56:59", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T06:56:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T06:56:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/us-judge-rules-google-is-monopoly-in-key-anti-trust-case-199225", "title": "US judge rules Google is monopoly in key anti-trust case - Latest News", "body": "A U.S. judge on Monday handed Google a major legal blow, ruling in a landmark anti-trust case that it has maintained a monopoly with its dominant search engine.\n\nThe court decision against a \"big tech\" giant could alter how the sector operates in future.\n\nDistrict Court Judge Amit Mehta found that Google had a monopoly for search and for text ads through exclusive distribution agreements that made it the \"default\" option that people were likely to use on devices.\n\n\"After having carefully considered and weighed the witness testimony and evidence, the court reaches the following conclusion: Google is a monopolist, and it has acted as one to maintain its monopoly,\" Mehta wrote in his ruling.\n\nThe internet behemoth \"has a major, largely unseen advantage over its rivals: default distribution,\" he wrote.\n\nThe anti-trust trial pitting U.S. prosecutors and nearly a dozen states against Google ended in May.\n\n\"This victory against Google is an historic win for the American people,\" said U.S. Attorney General Merrick Garland. \"No company -- no matter how large or influential -- is above the law.\"\n\nGoogle will appeal the verdict, according to global affairs president Kent Walker.\n\nWalker pointed out that Mehta concludes Google is the industry's highest quality search engine, particularly on mobile devices.\n\n\"Given this, and that people are increasingly looking for information in more and more ways, we plan to appeal,\" Walker said.\n\n\"As this process continues, we will remain focused on making products that people find helpful and easy to use.\"\n\nDamages?\n\nIt remained to be seen what remedies or damages the judge might order in the case.\n\nIn one possible good sign for Google, Mehta concluded in his ruling that the tech titan's violation of the Sherman Act did not have \"anticompetitive effects.\"\n\n\"Google's loss in its search antitrust trial could be a huge deal -- depending on the remedy,\" said Emarketer senior analyst Evelyn Mitchell-Wolf.\n\n\"A forced divestiture of the search business would sever Alphabet from its largest source of revenue,\" she added, referring to Google's parent company.\n\nEven losing the option of making exclusive deals to be the default option on browsers, smartphones or computers would hurt Google, according to the analyst.\n\nGoogle's search business would be hampered as generative artificial intelligence wielded by Microsoft's Bing and OpenAI budding \"SearchGPT\" ramp up competition.\n\n\"The biggest winner from today's ruling isn't consumers or little tech, it's Microsoft,\" said Chamber of Progress CEO Adam Kovacevich.\n\n\"Microsoft has underinvested in search for decades, but today's ruling opens the door to a court mandate of default deals for Bing.\"\n\nMitchell-Wolf expected a drawn-out appeals process to delay any immediate effects of the verdict on consumers or advertisers.\n\nThe trial was the first time the U.S. Department of Justice has faced a big tech company in court since Microsoft was targeted more than two decades ago over the dominance of its Windows operating system.\n\nMehta presided over several months of testimony late last year that saw Google CEO Sundar Pichai and other top executives take the stand.\n\nAt the heart of the government's case was the massive payments made by Google to Apple and other companies to keep its world-leading search engine as the default on iPhones, web browsers and other products.\n\nCourt testimony revealed that these payments reach the tens of billions of dollars every year to keep its prime real estate on Apple hardware or the Safari and Mozilla browsers.\n\nJustice department lawyers argued that Google achieved and perpetuated its dominance -- and strangled rivals -- through these default deals that also expanded to Samsung and other device makers.", "source": {"uri": "hurriyetdailynews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Hurriyet Daily News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Competition_law", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Competition law"}}, {"uri": {"uri": "8261451596", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "08:56:52", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T08:56:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T08:55:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://www.newsweek.com/letitia-james-celebrates-victory-google-1935031", "title": "Letitia James celebrates \"major victory\" against Google", "body": "\"This decision is a major victory in our efforts to ensure all companies, no matter how powerful or influential, are held accountable when they harm others,\" James said in a statement.\n\n\"For too long, Google has used its power to limit consumer choice in search, paying billions to ensure its competitors had no path to succeed, and profiting enormously from its monopoly. As Attorney General, I will not allow any business or corporation to take advantage of New Yorkers and exploit their position to grow their influence,\" she continued.\n\nJames had coled a bipartisan coalition of 38 attorneys general in suing Google on allegations of what they described as \"illegal, anticompetitive conduct.\"\n\nThey accused the company of spending tens of billions of dollars each year on contracts with Apple, Samsung and other companies to make Google the default search provider on smartphones and web browsers.\n\nOn Monday, Judge Amit P. Mehta of the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia ruled that Google violated U.S. antitrust laws and created an illegal monopoly to become the world's default search engine.\n\nGoogle is the most popular search engine in the world by far, controlling about 90 percent of the online search market and 95 percent on smartphones.\n\nNewsweek has contacted Google via email for comment outside regular working hours.\n\nOn Monday, Kent Walker, the president of global affairs at Google and its parent company, Alphabet Inc., responded to the decision in a statement to Newsweek.\n\nHe said: \"This decision recognizes that Google offers the best search engine, but concludes that we shouldn't be allowed to make it easily available. We appreciate the Court's finding that Google is 'the industry's highest quality search engine, which has earned Google the trust of hundreds of millions of daily users,' that Google 'has long been the best search engine, particularly on mobile devices,' 'has continued to innovate in search' and that 'Apple and Mozilla occasionally assess Google's search quality relative to its rivals and find Google's to be superior.\"\n\n\"Given this, and that people are increasingly looking for information in more and more ways, we plan to appeal. As this process continues, we will remain focused on making products that people find helpful and easy to use,\" the statement continued.\n\nMonday's ruling paves the way for a second trial to explore potential remedies, which could include the breakup of Alphabet. This could be a long process, possibly involving multiple appeals in various courts.", "source": {"uri": "newsweek.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Newsweek"}, "authors": [{"uri":
