{"uri": "8260989207", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "02:18:52", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T02:18:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T02:17:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://www.pymnts.com/antitrust/2024/tech-industry-braces-for-fallout-from-google-antitrust-verdict/", "title": "Tech Industry Braces for Fallout From Google Antitrust Verdict", "body": "By now, you know that Google lost its landmark antitrust case, pending what is sure to be a dogfight of an appeal. In the balance, there are more antitrust cases in the tech sector involving Meta and Amazon, among others.\n\nWith that in mind it's important to focus on the details in the judge's decision, which concludes that Google's business practices violated antitrust laws, specifically the Sherman Act, by maintaining and abusing its monopoly power in the search and search advertising markets.\n\nAccording to several legal opinions in the immediate aftermath of the decision, consumers will not be affected any time soon. However, before the decision, several legal firms played \"what if\" with the anticipated decision, including this speculation from the Lanier Law Firm -- which had filed one of the many suits against Google -- in January.\n\n\"Casual web and smartphone users, for example, will see a wider variety of search engines available for use if Google loses in these antitrust lawsuits. Instead of being directed to Google by default, many more users will search the internet using privacy-focused search engines such as DuckDuckGo,\" the firm posted.\n\n\"When booking travel, looking for hotels, or searching for activities on your next vacation, Google's loss in these antitrust cases would place vertical search websites higher in the search results. Instead of seeing services such as Google Flights or Google Hotels above the fold, you'll begin to see more companies like Tripadvisor, Yelp or Kayak.\"\n\nThe case, formally known as United States of America et al. v. Google LLC, centered on Google's extensive and complex business practices that, according to the plaintiffs, stifled competition and innovation. The ruling, detailed in a comprehensive 286-page opinion by U.S. District Judge Amit Mehta, outlines how Google's practices created barriers to entry for competitors, thereby maintaining what he called its monopolistic status.\n\nThe decision marks a turning point in a nearly four-year legal battle between Google and U.S. antitrust enforcers. The Department of Justice, joined by 11 states, filed the original lawsuit in October 2020, alleging that Google used anticompetitive tactics to preserve its dominance in search and search advertising. A separate lawsuit filed by a coalition of state attorneys general was later consolidated with the federal case.\n\nAfter a nine-week bench trial that concluded in November 2023, Mehta ruled that Google's distribution agreements with mobile device manufacturers, wireless carriers and web browser developers foreclosed rivals from key distribution channels and allowed Google to unlawfully maintain its monopoly power.\n\nThe court defined two relevant antitrust markets in which Google was found to have monopoly power:\n\n1. General search services: Mehta rejected Google's argument for a broader \"query responses\" market that would have included specialized vertical providers like Amazon. Instead, he concluded that general search engines like Google and Bing constitute a distinct product market.\n\n2. General search text advertising: The court found that text ads on general search engines are a separate market from other forms of online advertising, including product listing ads and display ads.\n\nIn both markets, the court determined that Google possesses monopoly power based on its dominant market share and the existence of significant barriers to entry. The ruling notes that Google has held over 80% share of general search queries since 2009, reaching nearly 90% by 2020. In general search text advertising, Google's market share was found to be 88%.\n\nAt the core of the case were Google's revenue-sharing agreements that make Google the preset default search engine on Apple's Safari browser, Mozilla's Firefox browser and on Android mobile devices. Mehta concluded these agreements are exclusive deals that hinder rivals from critical distribution channels.\n\nThe court found the agreements produce three main anticompetitive effects:\n\n1. Market foreclosure: The agreements were found to foreclose about 50% of general search queries and 45% of the general search text ad market from competitors.\n\n2. Depriving rivals of scale: By locking up default search placements, the agreements deny Google's competitors access to search queries and user data needed to improve their products and ad platforms.\n\n3. Reduced incentives to invest and innovate: The ruling states that Google's exclusive grip on key distribution channels has diminished incentives for both Google and its rivals to invest in search and search advertising capabilities.\n\nMehta rejected Google's arguments that the agreements produce offsetting procompetitive benefits. He found that Google failed to show that deals enhance user experience, incentivize competition, or produce other benefits that justify their exclusionary effects.\n\nNotably, the court dismissed Google's contention that it faces robust competition for queries from specialized vertical providers and social media platforms. Mehta determined these are largely complementary services rather than substitutes for general search.\n\nA key finding in the ruling is that Google's monopoly power has enabled it to charge supracompetitive prices for search text ads without facing meaningful competitive constraints. The court cited evidence that Google has used various \"pricing knobs\" to steadily increase text ad prices over time, often seeing about 50% of price hikes stick long-term.\n\nMehta found Google makes these pricing decisions without regard for competitors' pricing. He stated this ability to profitably raise prices substantially above competitive levels is clear evidence of monopoly power.\n\nWhile finding Google liable for monopolization, the ruling does not specify remedies at this stage. Mehta indicated the court will address relief in subsequent proceedings.\n\nThe Department of Justice had previously suggested potential remedies could include barring Google from entering into exclusionary agreements, unwinding existing deals, and potentially requiring divestitures. However, the exact scope of relief remains to be determined.\n\nA few other notable elements of Mehta's decision:\n\n* The court rejected a proposed market for \"general search advertising\" that would have included both text ads and product listing ads. It found insufficient evidence to support this as a relevant antitrust market.\n\n* Mehta dismissed claims related to Google's search advertising tool SA360, finding Google had no duty to provide feature parity between its own ad platform and Microsoft's.\n\n* The ruling declined to impose sanctions on Google for failing to preserve certain employee chat messages, though it criticized the company's practices around document retention.\n\n* While focused on competitive effects rather than intent, the judge expressed concern over \"the lengths to which Google goes to avoid creating a paper trail for regulators and litigants.\"", "source": {"uri": "pymnts.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "PYMNTS.com"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8261647017", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "10:59:40", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T10:59:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T10:59:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://winbuzzer.com/2024/08/06/federal-court-finds-google-guilty-of-monopolistic-practices-xcxwbn/", "title": "Federal Court Finds Google Guilty of Monopolistic Practices - WinBuzzer", "body": "Google has been found to be unfairly maintaining its dominance in search, although the wider DoJ trial is ongoing.\n\nA federal court has ruled that Google has engaged in monopolistic practices within the search and advertising sectors, violating United States antitrust laws. The verdict, delivered by Judge Amit Mehta, marks a significant legal victory for the Department of Justice (DOJ), which has continuously charged Google with using anti-competitive tactics to maintain its market dominance.\n\nJudge Mehta's assessment concluded that Google has intentionally maintained its monopoly in \"general search services\" and \"general search text advertising.\" The court's judgment indicates that Google's actions breach Section 2 of the Sherman Act, a primary antitrust law. Nonetheless, not all of the government's claims were supported; particularly, the court dismissed the assertion of Google's monopoly power in a specific segment of the advertising market.\n\nThe ruling determines Google's liability but does not specify remedies. These will be decided in subsequent legal proceedings. Potential outcomes may include required changes to Google's business practices or possibly a breakup of its search operations. Google has stated it plans to appeal the ruling. Kent Walker, President of Global Affairs at Google, acknowledged the decision but contended that it penalizes the company for providing a superior service.\n\nDOJ's antitrust chief, Jonathan Kanter, hailed the decision as a significant step towards fostering innovation and safeguarding access to information. Competing search engine DuckDuckGo also welcomed the ruling but stressed that the battle against Google's practices continues. The court refuted Google's claims that its contracts with phone and browser makers, like Apple, were non-exclusionary. Judge Mehta noted that substantial revenue intake from Google discourages Apple from creating its own search engine.\n\nJudge Mehta drew comparisons with the US v. Microsoft case, emphasizing that such conduct can be exclusionary when executed by a dominant firm like Google. He pointed out Google's enduring monopoly, highlighting an increase in market share from 80% in 2009 to 90% by 2020, while Bing's share remained under 6%. The judge stressed that even major US companies lack viable alternatives to Google, with changing default search engines leading to considerable financial losses.\n\nIn the search text advertising market, Judge Mehta identified that Google's exclusive agreements enabled it to raise prices without facing genuine competition. Google claimed its ad prices, when adjusted for quality, have decreased over time, but Mehta found this evidence unconvincing, suggesting Google's primary goal is long-term revenue.\n\nThis ruling is part of a broader antitrust lawsuit led by the DOJ, accusing Google of anti-competitive behavior to uphold its market superiority. The case is ongoing, with potential implications for Google's business practices and the regulatory framework surrounding digital markets.\n\nThe decision for the wider DoJ investigation was made last September and could have a huge impact on Google and its parent Alphabet. Last year, the DoJ accused the company of destroying evidence by deleting chats between employees. In November 2022, Google agreed to pay hundreds of millions of dollars to 40 states in the biggest anti-trust settlement in U.S. law.\n\nGoogle argued that the failure of rivals such as Microsoft Bing was not down to its own practices but rather the failures of Microsoft. The trial also looked into Google's search ad practices. As we reported in September, the DOJ alleges that Google's market dominance allows it to hike ad prices without significant consequences. This claim is substantiated by Jerry Dischler, a Google ads executive, who testified about the company's ad pricing strategies.\n\nAlphabet CEO Sundar Pichai and Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella have both given testimonies during the landmark trial. In his testimonies to the court, Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella suggested Google stifles Bing. Nadella revealed that Microsoft has poured a staggering $100 billion into Bing, its proprietary search engine. Nadella candidly admitted Microsoft's unsuccessful attempts to dethrone Google from this position, even after offering Apple more favorable terms.\n\nGoogle reportedly pays Apple up to $20 billion per year to keep its Search engine on iPhone and other devices. However, Pichai claims this drives competition not blocks it. He reasoned that the cost-effectiveness of contending with a potential Apple-powered rival search engine or another competitor weighed in favor of retaining Google's default status on iPhones.", {"uri": "2024-08-445410458", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "08:21:01", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T08:21:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T08:03:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://www.aol.co.uk/news/u-judge-rules-google-broke-080331277.html", "title": "Google has an illegal monopoly on search, US judge finds", "body": "Google has an illegal monopoly on search, US judge finds\n\nDavid Shepardson and Mike Scarcella\n\n6 August 2024 at 10:03 am\n\nBy David Shepardson and Mike Scarcella\n\nWASHINGTON (Reuters) -A U.S. judge ruled on Monday that Google violated antitrust law, spending billions of dollars to create an illegal monopoly and become the world's default search engine, the first big win for federal authorities taking on Big Tech's market dominance.\n\nThe ruling paves the way for a second trial to determine potential fixes, possibly including a breakup of Google parent Alphabet, which would change the landscape of the online advertising world that Google has dominated for years.\n\nIt is also a green light to aggressive U.S. antitrust enforcers prosecuting Big Tech, a sector that has been under fire from across the political spectrum.\n\n\"The court reaches the following conclusion: Google is a monopolist, and it has acted as one to maintain its monopoly,\" U.S. District Judge Amit Mehta, Washington, D.C., wrote. Google controls about 90% of the online search market and 95% on smartphones.\n\nThe \"remedy\" phase could be lengthy, followed by potential appeals to the U.S. Court of Appeals, District of Columbia Circuit and the U.S. Supreme Court. The legal wrangling could play out into next year, or even 2026.\n\nShares of Alphabet fell 4.5% on Monday amid a broad decline in tech shares as the wider stock market cratered on recession fears. Google advertising was 77% of Alphabet's total sales in 2023.\n\nAlphabet said it plans to appeal Mehta's ruling. \"This decision recognizes that Google offers the best search engine, but concludes that we shouldn't be allowed to make it easily available,\" Google said in a statement.\n\nU.S. Attorney General Merrick Garland called the ruling \"a historic win for the American people,\" adding that \"no company - no matter how large or influential - is above the law.\"\n\nWhite House press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre said the \"pro-competition ruling is a victory for the American people,\" adding that \"Americans deserve an internet that is free, fair, and open for competition.\"\n\nBILLIONS PAID\n\nMehta noted that Google had paid $26.3 billion in 2021 alone to ensure that its search engine is the default on smartphones and browsers, and to keep its dominant market share.\n\n\"The default is extremely valuable real estate,\" Mehta wrote. \"Even if a new entrant were positioned from a quality standpoint to bid for the default when an agreement expires, such a firm could compete only if it were prepared to pay partners upwards of billions of dollars in revenue share and make them whole for any revenue shortfalls resulting from the change.\"\n\nHe added, \"Google, of course, recognizes that losing defaults would dramatically impact its bottom line. For instance, Google has projected that losing the Safari default would result in a significant drop in queries and billions of dollars in lost revenues.\"\n\nThe ruling is the first major decision in a series of cases taking on alleged monopolies in Big Tech. This case, filed by the Trump administration, went before a judge from September to November of last year.\n\n\"A forced divestiture of the search business would sever Alphabet from its largest source of revenue. But even losing its capacity to strike exclusive default agreements could be detrimental for Google,\" said Emarketer senior analyst Evelyn Mitchell-Wolf, who said a drawn-out legal process would delay any immediate effects for consumers.\n\nIn the past four years, federal antitrust regulators have also sued Meta Platforms, Amazon.com and Apple, claiming the companies have illegally maintained monopolies.\n\nThose cases all began under the administration of former President Donald Trump.\n\nSenator Amy Klobuchar, a Democrat who chairs the Senate Judiciary Committee's antitrust subcommittee, said the fact that the case spanned administrations shows strong bipartisan support for antitrust enforcement.\n\n\"It's a huge victory for the American people that antitrust enforcement is alive and well when it comes to competition,\" she said. \"Google is a rampant monopolist.\"\n\nWhen it was filed in 2020, the Google search case was the first time in a generation that the U.S. government accused a major corporation of an illegal monopoly. Microsoft settled with the Justice Department in 2004 over claims that it forced its Internet Explorer Web browser on Windows users.\n\n(Reporting by David Shepardson and Mike Scarcella in Washington and Jody Godoy in New York; Writing by Chris Sanders; Additional reporting by Arsheeya Singh Bajwa in Bengaluru; Editing by Peter Henderson, Matthew Lewis and Leslie Adler)", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8261401981", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "08:23:12", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T08:23:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T08:22:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://www.computing.co.uk/news/4343479/google-monopolist-us-judge-landmark-antitrust-ruling", "title": "'Google is a monopolist' US judge says in landmark antitrust ruling", "body": "A US district judge has declared Google a monopolist that has illegally stifled competition to maintain its dominance in the search engine market.\n\nThe decision, handed down on Monday, marks a significant victory for the US Department of Justice (DOJ) and could lead to far-reaching consequences for the tech giant.\n\nUS district judge Amit Mehta found that Google had systematically used its market power to crush rivals, spending billions of dollars to ensure its search engine became the default on smartphones and other devices.\n\nThe company's 89.2% share of the general search market and 94.9% dominance on mobile devices were cited as clear evidence of its monopoly.\n\n\"After having carefully considered and weighed the witness and evidence, the court reaches the following conclusion: Google is a monopolist, and it has acted as one to maintain its monopoly,\" Judge Mehta wrote in his 277-page ruling [pdf].\n\nThe DOJ filed the lawsuit against Google in 2020, accusing the company of controlling approximately 90% of the online search market.\n\nIt argued that Google's anti-competitive behaviour enabled the company to charge excessive advertising rates while neglecting to improve its search quality.\n\nThe company's immense financial resources, derived largely from its advertising business, were instrumental in its ability to outmanoeuvre competitors.\n\nGoogle denies the allegations and has vowed to appeal the ruling. The company maintains that its success is a result of superior product innovation and consumer preference.\n\nReaction to the ruling against Google\n\n\"People are increasingly looking for information in more and more ways,\" said Kent Walker, Google's global affairs president.\n\n\"This decision recognises that Google offers the best search engine, but concludes that we shouldn't be allowed to make it easily available,\" he said. \"As this process continues, we will remain focused on making products that people find helpful and easy to use.\"\n\nAttorney general Merrick Garland described the victory against Google \"a historic win for the American people.\"\n\n\"No company - no matter how large or influential - is above the law. The Justice Department will continue to vigorously enforce our antitrust laws,\" he said.\n\nAssistant attorney general Jonathan Kanter stated: \"This landmark decision holds Google accountable. It paves the path for innovation for generations to come and protects access to information for all Americans.\n\n\"This victory is a reflection on the tireless efforts of the dedicated public servants at the Antitrust Division and our state law enforcement partners whose work made today's decision possible.\"\n\nWhile the ruling is a setback for Google, the legal battle is far from over. The appeals process could take years, and it remains unclear what remedies the court will ultimately impose. Potential options include hefty fines or behavioural remedies.\n\nThe government has requested \"structural relief,\" which could potentially lead to the company being broken up.\n\nImplications of the ruling against Google\n\nThe implications of the ruling extend beyond Google. It signals a potential shift in the government's approach to regulating Big Tech companies, with similar antitrust cases pending against Meta, Amazon and Apple.\n\nIn March, the DOJ accused Apple of monopolising the US smartphone market and driving up prices.\n\nAttorney general Garland said Apple had violated section two of the Sherman Antitrust Act, forcing higher prices and fees for \"lower quality smartphones\" and apps, and privileging its own apps against third-party apps by selectively restricting access to iOS operating system features.\n\nIn June, a UK tribunal ruled that Google must face a \u00a313.6 billion lawsuit that alleges tech giant wields undue power over the online advertising market.\n\nRipples from the ruling will be felt outside of Google, including at Apple, which received $20 billion per year for making Google the default on its devices, and Firefox-maker Mozilla.\n\nIn 2021-2022 financial statement $510 million out of the Mozilla Foundation's $593 million revenues derived from Google search.", "source": {"uri": "computing.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Computing"}, "authors": [{"uri": "dev_kundaliya@computing.co.uk", "name": "Dev {"uri": "8260765951", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "21:32:36", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T21:32:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T21:32:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://lacrossetribune.com/news/nation-world/business/google-antitrust-case-search-engine-monopoly/article_de789fa6-8fc0-5974-aa59-ec3b6684e9b2.html", "title": "Google illegally maintains monopoly over internet search, judge rules", "body": "WASHINGTON -- A judge on Monday ruled that Google's ubiquitous search engine has been illegally exploiting its dominance to squash competition and stifle innovation in a seismic decision that could shake up the internet and hobble one of the world's best-known companies.\n\nThe highly anticipated decision issued by U.S. District Judge Amit Mehta comes nearly a year after the start of a trial pitting the U.S. Justice Department against Google in the country's biggest antitrust showdown in a quarter century.\n\nAfter reviewing reams of evidence that included testimony from top executives at Google, Microsoft and Apple during last year's 10-week trial, Mehta issued his potentially market-shifting decision three months after the two sides presented their closing arguments in early May.\n\n\"After having carefully considered and weighed the witness testimony and evidence, the court reaches the following conclusion: Google is a monopolist, and it has acted as one to maintain its monopoly,\" Mehta wrote in his 277-page ruling.\n\nPeople are also reading... Onalaska man faces felony charge after injury hit-and-run in La Crosse Valley View Mall in La Crosse closed for third consecutive day following power outage New public hearing date set to discuss overnight unsheltered sleeping areas in La Crosse Finnottes Candies owner marks end of 37-year business with final sales and memories Steve Cahalan: Red Lobster building to be razed to make way for car wash Steve Cahalan: Blair Meat Market expands, Red Lobster restaurant to be razed for new car wash Homeless and dying: La Crosse veteran diagnosed with heart failure finds peace in final weeks La Crosse man faces charges for driving under the influence of marijuana 'The truck is their house': Onalaska trucking instructor offers free CDL classes for homeless jobseekers La Crosse County Jail inmate faces felony charge for jail assault VP Kamala Harris to visit western Wisconsin with running mate next week Defense attorney raises insanity plea for man accused of killing his wife in their town of Shelby home La Crosse man charged with felony drug possession after cocaine seized during traffic stop Child neglect charges filed against La Crosse couple after baby's fentanyl death John Paul Gillespie\n\nIt represents a major setback for Google and its parent, Alphabet Inc., which had steadfastly argued that its popularity stemmed from consumers' overwhelming desire to use a search engine so good at what it does that it has become synonymous with looking things up online. Google's search engine currently processes an estimated 8.5 billion queries per day worldwide, nearly doubling its daily volume from 12 years ago, according to a recent study released by the investment firm BOND.\n\nGoogle almost certainly will appeal the decision in a process that ultimately may land in the U.S. Supreme Court.\n\nFor now, the decision vindicates antitrust regulators at the Justice Department, which filed its lawsuit nearly four years ago while Donald Trump was still president, and has been escalating it efforts to rein in Big Tech's power during President Joe Biden's administration.\n\n\"This victory against Google is an historic win for the American people,\" said Attorney General Merrick Garland. \"No company -- no matter how large or influential -- is above the law. The Justice Department will continue to vigorously enforce our antitrust laws.\"\n\nThe case depicted Google as a technological bully that methodically has thwarted competition to protect a search engine that has become the centerpiece of a digital advertising machine that generated nearly $240 billion in revenue last year. Justice Department lawyers argued that Google's monopoly enabled it to charge advertisers artificially high prices while also enjoying the luxury of not having to invest more time and money into improving the quality of its search engine -- a lax approach that hurt consumers.\n\nAs expected, Mehta's ruling focused on the billions of dollars Google spends every year to install its search engine as the default option on new cellphones and tech gadgets. In 2021 alone, Google spent more than $26 billion to lock in those default agreements, Mehta said in his ruling.\n\nGoogle ridiculed those allegations, noting that consumers have historically changed search engines when they become disillusioned with the results they were getting. For instance, Yahoo -- now a minor player on the internet -- was the most popular search engine during the 1990s before Google came along.\n\nMehta said the evidence at trial showed the importance of the default settings. He noted that Microsoft's Bing search engine has 80% share of the search market on the Microsoft Edge browser. The judge said that shows other search engines can be successful if Google is not locked in as the predetermined default option.\n\n\"Advertisers consistently testified that shifting significant ad spending from Google to Bing would be ineffective (and unwise) because of Bing's lack of scale,\" Mehta wrote.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | Stitcher | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nStill, Mehta credited the quality of Google's product as an important part of its dominance, as well, saying flatly that \"Google is widely recognized as the best (general search engine) available in the United States.\"\n\nMehta's conclusion that Google has been running an illegal monopoly sets up another legal phase to determine what sorts of changes or penalties should be imposed to reverse the damage done and restore a more competitive landscape.\n\n\"The court confirmed what almost everyone in the industry already knew: that Google is a monopoly and is abusing its power to harm consumers and enrich itself,\" said Roger Alford, a law professor at the University of Notre Dame.\n\nThe potential outcome could result in a wide-ranging order requiring Google to dismantle some of the pillars of its internet empire or prevent it from shelling out billions annually to ensure its search engine automatically answers queries on the iPhone and other internet-connected devices. After the next phase, the judge could conclude only modest changes are required to level the playing field.\n\n\"Google's loss in its search antitrust trial could be a huge deal -- depending on the remedy,\" said eMarketer senior analyst Evelyn Mitchell-Wolf. \"A forced divestiture of the search business would sever Alphabet from its largest source of revenue. But even losing its capacity to strike exclusive default agreements could be detrimental for Google. Its ubiquity is its biggest strength, especially as competition heats up among AI-powered search alternatives.\"\n\nRegardless she added, a drawn-out appeals process will delay any immediate effects for both consumers and advertisers.\n\nIf there is a significant shakeup, it could turn out to be a coup for Microsoft, whose own power was undermined during the late 1990s when the Justice Department targeted the software maker in an antitrust lawsuit accusing it of abusing the dominance of its Windows operating system on personal computers to lock out competition.\n\nThat Microsoft case mirrored the one brought against Google in several ways and now the result could also echo similarly. Just as Microsoft's bruising antitrust battle created distractions and obstacles that opened up more opportunities for Google after its 1998 inception, the decision against Google could be a boon for Microsoft, which already has a market value of more than $3 trillion. At one time, Alphabet was worth more than Microsoft, but now trails its rival with a market value of about $2 trillion.\n\nBesides boosting Microsoft's Bing search engine, the outcome could hurt Google at a critical pivot point that is tilting technology in the age of artificial intelligence. Both Microsoft and Google are among the early leaders in AI in a battle that now could be affected by Mehta's market-rattling decision.\n\nMicrosoft CEO Satya Nadella was one of the Justice Department's star witnesses during the testimony that covered his frustration with Google deals with the likes of Apple that made it nearly impossible for the Bing search engine to make any headway, even as Microsoft poured more than $100 billion in improvements since 2009.\n\n\"You get up in the morning, you brush your teeth and you search on Google,\" Nadella said at one point in his testimony. \"Everybody talks about the open web, but there is really the Google web.\"\n\nNadella also expressed fear that it might take an antitrust crackdown to ensure the situation didn't get worse as AI becomes a bigger force in search.\n\n\"Despite my enthusiasm that there is a new angle with A.I., I worry a lot that this vicious cycle that I'm trapped in could get even more vicious,\" Nadella said on the stand.\n\nGoogle faces several other legal threats both in the U.S. and abroad. In September, a federal trial is scheduled to begin in Virginia over the Justice Department's allegations that Google's advertising technology constitutes an illegal monopoly.\n\nKids, screen time and despair: An expert in the economics of happiness echoes psychologists' warnings about tech Kids, screen time and despair: An expert in the economics of happiness echoes psychologists' warnings about tech Greater number of young people are reporting despair Love 0 Funny 0 Wow 0 Sad 0 Angry 0\n\nThe business news you need\n\nGet the latest local business news delivered FREE to your inbox "dataType": "news", "title": "La Crosse Tribune"}, "authors": [{"uri": "matthew_barakat@lacrossetribune.com", "name": "Matthew Barakat", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8260857449", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "23:24:25", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T23:24:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T23:23:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://www.straitstimes.com/tech/tech-news/google-has-an-illegal-monopoly-on-search-us-judge-finds", "title": "Google has an illegal monopoly on search, US judge finds", "body": "WASHINGTON - Alphabet's Google broke the law with an illegal monopoly on online search, a federal judge ruled on Aug 5, the first big win for US antitrust authorities who have filed several lawsuits challenging Big Tech's market dominance.\n\nThe ruling paves the way for a second trial to determine potential fixes, possibly including a break-up of Alphabet, that would change the landscape of the online advertising world that Google has dominated for years.\n\nIt is also a green light to aggressive US antitrust enforcers prosecuting Big Tech, which faces criticism from across the political spectrum.\n\n\"The court reaches the following conclusion: Google is a monopolist, and it has acted as one to maintain its monopoly,\" District Judge Amit Mehta wrote. The search engine giant controls about 90 per cent of the online search market, and 95 per cent on smartphones.\n\nThe \"remedy\" phase could be lengthy, followed by potential appeals to the D.C. Circuit and US Supreme Court. The legal wrangling could play out into next year, or even 2026.\n\nShares of Google parent Alphabet fell 4.3 per cent on Aug 5 as part of a broad tech share decline. Google advertising was 77 per cent of Alphabet's total sales in 2023.\n\nAlphabet said it plans to appeal Judge Mehta's ruling. \"This decision recognises that Google offers the best search engine, but concludes that we shouldn't be allowed to make it easily available,\" Google said in a statement.\n\nUS Attorney General Merrick Garland called the ruling \"a historic win for the American people\", adding that \"no company - no matter how large or influential - is above the law\".\n\nJudge Mehta noted that Google had paid US$26.3 billion (S$34.8 billion) in 2021 alone to ensure that its search engine is the default on smartphones and browsers, and to keep its dominant market share.\n\n\"The default is extremely valuable real estate... Even if a new entrant were positioned from a quality standpoint to bid for the default when an agreement expires, such a firm could compete only if it were prepared to pay partners upwards of billions of dollars in revenue share and make them whole for any revenue shortfalls resulting from the change,\" the judge wrote.\n\nHe noted \"Google, of course, recognises that losing defaults would dramatically impact its bottom line. For instance, Google has projected that losing the Safari default would result in a significant drop in queries and billions of dollars in lost revenues\".\n\nThe ruling is the first major decision in a series of cases taking on alleged monopolies in Big Tech. This case, filed by the Trump administration, went before a judge from September to November.\n\n\"A forced divestiture of the search business would sever Alphabet from its largest source of revenue. But even losing its capacity to strike exclusive default agreements could be detrimental for Google,\" said Emarketer senior analyst Evelyn Mitchell-Wolf, who noted a drawn out legal process will delay any immediate effects for consumers.\n\nIn the past four years, federal antitrust regulators have also sued Meta Platforms, Amazon.com, and Apple, claiming the companies have illegally maintained monopolies. Those cases all began under the administration of former President Donald Trump.\n\nMs Amy Klobuchar, a Democratic US senator who chairs the Senate Judiciary Committee's antitrust subcommittee, said the fact that the case spanned administrations shows strong bipartisan support for antitrust enforcement.\n\n\"It's a huge victory for the American people that antitrust enforcement is alive and well when it comes to competition,\" she said. \"Google is a rampant monopolist.\"\n\nWhen it was filed in 2020, the Google search case was the first time in a generation that the US government accused a major corporation of an illegal monopoly. Microsoft settled with the Justice Department in 2004 over claims that it forced its Internet Explorer web browser on Windows users. {"uri": "8260705157", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "20:29:53", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T20:29:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T20:29:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://forums.macrumors.com/threads/google-and-apples-search-engine-deal-violates-antitrust-law.2433000/", "title": "Google and Apple's Search Engine Deal Violates Antitrust Law", "body": "You are using an out of date browser. It may not display this or other websites correctly.\n\nYou should upgrade or use an alternative browser.\n\nThe paid agreement that Google has with Apple to be the default search engine on the iPhone and other Apple devices violates antitrust law, a federal judge ruled today (via Bloomberg).\n\nGoogle has long paid Apple billions of dollars a year to be the default Safari search engine, and this relationship has been under scrutiny as Google battles antitrust allegations made by the United States Justice Department. The court today found in favor of the DoJ, and said that Google is indeed shutting out competition by paying smartphone makers for default status.\n\nGoogle's agreements with Apple and other smartphone makers have a \"significant effect\" maintaining Google's search monopoly, keeping other search engines from competing and reinforcing Google's dominant position. Google has a search market share of around 95 percent on smartphones, in part due to the money that it pays.\n\nIn 2022, Google paid Apple $20 billion, an amount that incentivizes Apple to stick with the status quo. Apple does not provide opportunities to other search engines, nor does it develop its own search product due to the money that it receives from Google, according to the DoJ.\n\nAfter considering testimony from Apple, Google, Microsoft, and other companies, the court decided that Google has a search monopoly. \"Google is a monopolist, and it has acted as one to maintain its monopoly. It has violated Section 2 of the Sherman Act,\" reads the ruling.\n\nThe court will need to decide on the next actions to take to address Google's anticompetitive practices, and injunctions could be forthcoming.\n\nGoogle and Apple could in the future be barred from entering into search agreements, which will result in a revenue loss for both companies. Apple will not get billions for promoting Google Search, and Google will lose out on being the default option across billions of Apple devices.\n\nGoogle is likely to appeal the decision.\n\nArticle {"uri": "8261411683", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "08:30:31", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T08:30:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T08:29:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://www.mobileworldlive.com/google/us-judge-finds-google-search-violates-antitrust-law/", "title": "US judge finds Google search violates antitrust law", "body": "A US judge found Google broke antitrust law by creating a monopoly through payments to companies to make its search engine the default setting on mobile phones and browsers.\n\nThe court's 276-page ruling found \"Google is a monopolist, and it has acted as one to maintain its monopoly\" by working to ensure its online search and related advertising capabilities are featured over rivals such as Microsoft's Bing.\n\nAlphabet-owned Google has search engine deals in place with smartphone companies Apple and Samsung as well as browsers such as Mozilla to make its search engine the default across their products. It also has agreements in place with mobile operators.\n\nGoogle makes its search engine the default across some of the apps on its Play Store for phone OEMs using its Android operating system.\n\nBloomberg reported Google paid $26.3 billion in 2021 to companies to ensure default placements of its search engine through distribution contracts.\n\nA representative for Google told Mobile World Live the company plans to appeal the ruling.\n\n\"This decision recognizes that Google offers the best search engine but concludes that we shouldn't be allowed to make it easily available,\" according to a statement from Kent Walker, president of Google global affairs.\n\nHe noted the ruling finds that Google is \"the industry's highest quality search engine, which has earned Google the trust of hundreds of millions of daily users,\" and that it \"has long been the best search engine, particularly on mobile devices\".\n\nWhile the ruling is in the US Department of Justice's favour, it did not include possible remedies or actions.", "source": {"uri": "mobileworldlive.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Mobile World Live"}, "authors": [{"uri": "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://www.verdict.co.uk/us-judge-rules-googles-search-monopoly-is-illegal/", "title": "US judge rules Google's search monopoly is illegal", "body": "A judge ruled on Monday that Google has violated antitrust law in the US by illegally squashing competition and stifling innovation.\n\nThe ruling found that Google had paid $26.3bn in 2021 to ensure its search engine is the default on smartphones and browsers, to maintain its dominant market share.\n\nUS District Judge Amit Mehta wrote in his 277-page ruling: \"The court reaches the following conclusion: Google is a monopolist, and it has acted as one to maintain its monopoly.\"\n\nThe ruling comes after the 10-week trial which took place last year including testimony from senior leaders at Google, Microsoft and Apple.\n\nClosing arguments took place in May this year in the first of several cases filed by the US Government accusing Big Tech of holding monopolies.\n\nThe case was filed by the Trump administration and is the first of four similar cases filed against tech giants Amazon and Meta, as well as a further case filed by President Biden's administration against Google.\n\nAll of which deal with antitrust laws.\n\nGoogle controls around 90% of the market for online search queries with a 95% share on mobile devices - evidence, the ruling claims of its monopoly.\n\nKent Walker, Google's president of global affairs, said the company intends to appeal Mehta's findings.\n\nHe said: \"This decision recognises that Google offers the best search engine but concludes that we shouldn't be allowed to make it easily available.\"\n\nAppeals after this ruling could be made to the US Court of Appeals, the District of Columbia Circuit and the Supreme Court leading to a lengthy 'remedy' phase.\n\nThis case is a victory for antitrust enforcers at the US Justice Department who filed the case almost four years ago and have since been escalating efforts to regulate Big Tech.\n\nWhile this could signify a sizeable shift in the online search market the ruling in the federal court did not state what penalties Google will face for violating antitrust law, leaving open Judge rules  --  National Accord Newspaper", "body": "A Federal judge from the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia ruled that Google has violated the U.S. antitrust law by maintaining a monopoly in the online search market.\n\nJudge, Amit Mehta on Tuesday agreed with the U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ) that Google has a monopoly in \"general search services\" and the general search text ads market.\n\n\"After having carefully considered and weighed the witness testimony and evidence, the court reached the following conclusion.\n\n\"Google is a monopolist, and it has acted as one to maintain its monopoly,\" according to the court's ruling.\n\nIt has violated Section 2 of the Sherman Act.\n\nGoogle controls about 90 per cent of the online search market and 95 per cent on smartphones, said the ruling, capping a years long case.\n\nThe DOJ reportedly sued in 2020 over Google's dominance in online search, which was the first time in a generation that the U.S. government accused a major corporation of an illegal monopoly.\n\nThis landmark decision holds Google accountable, DOJ antitrust Assistant Attorney General Jonathan Kanter said this in a statement.\n\nIt said that it paves the path for innovation for generations to come and protects access to information for all Americans.\n\nKent Walker, Google's president of Global Affairs, said the company intended to appeal to Mehta's ruling.\n\nThis decision recognised that Google offered the best search engine, but concluded that we shouldn't be allowed to make it easily available, according to the statement.\n\n\"As this process continues, we will remain focused on making products that people find helpful and easy to use.\"\n\nGoogle's fate will be decided in the next phase of proceedings, which could determine potential fixes possibly including a breakup of Google's parent Alphabet.\n\nThe next separate antitrust trial between the DOJ and Google would start on Sept. 9 in Virginia.\n\nHowever, the case would focus on whether Google has illegally monopolised advertising technology.\n\nAmazon, Apple, and Meta will now all face monopolisation lawsuits from the U.S. government. {"uri": "8260668357", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "19:53:37", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T19:53:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T19:53:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://www.nbcnews.com/business/business-news/google-loses-antitrust-case-search-rcna165246", "title": "Google loses antitrust case over search", "body": "Sundar Pichai, CEO of Alphabet, Google's parent company, in 2023.Boris Streubel / Getty Images for DFB\n\nA federal U.S. judge ruled Monday that Google has illegally held a monopoly in two market areas: search and text advertising.\n\nThe landmark case from the government, filed in 2020, alleged that Google has kept its share of the general search market by creating strong barriers to entry and a feedback loop that sustained its dominance. The court found that Google violated Section 2 of the Sherman Act, which outlaws monopolies.\n\nThe ruling marks the first anti-monopoly decision against a tech company in decades.\n\n\"Google is a monopolist, and it has acted as one to maintain its monopoly,\" Judge Amit Mehta of the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia wrote in the decision.\n\nThe court homed in on Google's exclusive search arrangements on Android and Apple's iPhone and iPad devices, saying that they helped to cement Google's anticompetitive behavior and dominance over the search markets.\n\nGeneral search services, according to the court, applies to Google's core search engine, where it traditionally competed with Yahoo. General search text advertising refers to the text ads that run alongside search results. The court ruled that in both of those areas, Google has operated as a monopoly. However, the ruling found that general search advertising is not a market so there can be no monopoly control.\n\nThe court also declined to sanction Google for failing to preserve chat messages from employees.\n\nThe Department of Justice and a bipartisan group of attorneys general from 38 states and territories, led by Colorado and Nebraska, filed similar but separate antitrust suits against Google in 2020. The suits were combined for pretrial purposes, such as discovery of evidence.\n\nAlphabet shares fell more than 4% on Monday, dragged down by a broad decline in stocks worldwide.\n\nThe Justice Department didn't immediately have a comment. on Monday.\n\nThe judge concluded that Google has \"violated Section 2 of the Sherman Act by maintaining its monopoly in two product markets in the United States general search services and general text advertising-through its exclusive distribution agreements.\"\n\nThe ruling, which can be appealed, marked a major win for the DoJ, who had argued that Google's agreements with companies including Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL) and others to make Google search default search engine on smartphones violated antitrust laws.\n\nAlphabet and the DoJ didn't immediately respond to Investing.com's request for {"uri": "8260892996", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "00:12:43", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T00:12:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T00:12:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://www.pehalnews.in/latest/judge-finds-google-guilty-of-antitrust-violations-in-effort-to-maintain-control-of-online-search-market/5079/", "title": "Judge finds Google guilty of antitrust violations in effort to maintain control of online search market - Pehal News", "body": "The Justice Department achieved a victory on Monday as a federal judge ruled that Google breached U.S. antitrust laws by upholding a monopoly in the online search sector.\n\nAmit Mehta, a D.C. District judge, found Google guilty of violating Section 2 of the Sherman Act, concluding that the company unlawfully solidified its dominance in the search market by paying substantial amounts to smartphone carriers like Apple to establish Google as the default search engine on their devices, effectively preventing any competing businesses from entering the market.\n\nIn his ruling, Mehta stated, \"Google is a monopolist and has behaved as such to preserve its monopoly.\"\n\nFollowing a 10-week trial in Washington, D.C. last year, where Justice Department officials and dozens of state attorneys general aimed to expose Google's anti-competitive strategies that led to its dominance as the top search engine globally.\n\nAlthough Mehta's ruling does not specify any particular remedies, he will need to determine appropriate actions to address Google's monopoly, which experts suggest could involve specific directives to the company to rectify its business practices or potentially divest parts of the corporation.\n\nIn a statement, Google opted to highlight the positive remarks made by the judge in the ruling.\n\nKent Walker, Google's president for global affairs, remarked, \"This ruling acknowledges that Google provides the top search engine but argues that we should not be permitted to make it readily accessible. We are grateful for the Court's recognition that Google is 'the industry's highest quality search engine, which has earned Google the trust of hundreds of millions of daily users', that Google 'has long been the best search engine, particularly on mobile devices', 'has continued to innovate in search' and that 'Apple and Mozilla occasionally evaluate Google's search quality compared to its competitors and find Google's to be superior.'\n\nHe further stated that the company will appeal the ruling, stating, \"Given this, and that people are increasingly seeking information in various ways, we intend to appeal. As this process unfolds, we will concentrate on creating products that people find useful and easy to use.\"\n\nThe Justice Department celebrated the groundbreaking ruling, with Attorney General Merrick Garland declaring in a statement, \"This triumph against Google is a historic victory for the American people. No corporation, regardless of its size or influence, is exempt from the law. The Justice Department will continue to vigorously uphold our antitrust laws.\"\n\nAssistant Attorney General Jonathan Kanter added in a statement, \"This significant ruling holds Google responsible. It opens the door to innovation for future generations and safeguards access to information for all Americans. This victory is a testament to the relentless efforts of the dedicated public servants at the Antitrust Division and our state law enforcement partners who made today's ruling possible.\"", "source": One potential remedy could be offering consumers a choice of default search engines when setting up new phones, a practice Google has implemented in Europe without losing market share.\n\nApple, although not directly sued, is heavily involved. Google pays Apple significant sums to remain the default iPhone search engine, with the ruling mentioning a $20 billion estimate for 2022, constituting 17% of Apple's operating profit. Should Google lose its exclusive status, it might stop these payments, impacting both companies.\n\n\"This decision recognizes that Google offers the best search engine, but concludes that we shouldn't be allowed to make it easily available,\" said President of global affairs Kent Walker in a public statement.\n\nALSO READ| How Google produces its search results, US court documents show: 'Not by happenstance'\n\nUS stocks suffered a brutal bloodbath last week as the Dow Jones Industrial Average plummeted over 1,000 points, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq sinking more than 3%. {"uri": "2024-08-445005873", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "21:31:41", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T21:31:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T21:13:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://www.guerillastocktrading.com/\ud83d\udca5-judge-rules-google-maintained-a-monopoly-in-search-and-ads-market-could-this-lead-to-a-google-breakup/", "title": "\ud83d\udca5 Judge rules Google maintained a monopoly in search and ads market! Could this lead to a Google breakup?", "body": "Image depicting Google as a powerful monopoly, with a giant Google logo overshadowing a cityscape of struggling businesses. Source: GuerillaStockTrading.com\n\nA federal judge ruled that Google violated US antitrust law by maintaining a monopoly in the search and advertising markets. Judge Amit Mehta concluded that Google is a monopolist and has acted to maintain this monopoly, violating Section 2 of the Sherman Act. This ruling is a significant victory for the Department of Justice, although Mehta did not agree with all their arguments. He confirmed that Google monopolizes \"general search services\" and \"general search text advertising,\" but not a specific part of the ads market. The ruling focuses on Google's liability, with future proceedings to determine possible remedies, which could range from mandated business practice changes to a breakup of Google's search business.\n\nMehta dismissed Google's argument that its contracts with phone and browser makers were non-exclusionary. He stated that Google's monopoly in general search has been consistent and durable, growing from 80% in 2009 to 90% in 2020. The judge emphasized that major companies have no viable alternative to Google for general search services. Google's exclusive agreements have allowed it to raise prices on search text advertising without competitive constraints. Mehta also addressed Google's failure to preserve relevant chat messages but did not impose sanctions.\n\nCourt's Ruling and Its Implications\n\nJudge Mehta's ruling states unequivocally, \"Google is a monopolist, and it has acted as one to maintain its monopoly.\" The court found that Google violated Section 2 of the Sherman Act, a crucial piece of antitrust legislation. This decision is a pivotal moment in the ongoing battle against monopolistic practices in the tech industry.\n\nWhile the ruling is a major victory for the DOJ, Judge Mehta did not agree with all of the government's arguments. Notably, he rejected the claim that Google holds monopoly power in a specific segment of the advertising market. However, he concurred with the assertion that Google has a monopoly in \"general search services\" and \"general search text advertising.\"\n\nPotential Consequences for Google\n\nThe ruling's immediate impact on Google's business is still unclear. The next phase of proceedings will determine the consequences, which could range from mandated changes in business practices to a potential breakup of Google's search business. This phase will be crucial in shaping the future landscape of the online search and advertising markets.\n\nGoogle's Defense and the Court's Rejection\n\nGoogle argued that its contracts with phone and browser makers like Apple were not exclusionary and should not qualify it for liability under the Sherman Act. However, Judge Mehta dismissed this argument, stating that the substantial revenue Apple receives from Google disincentivizes it from launching its own search engine. \"The prospect of losing tens of billions in guaranteed revenue from Google -- which presently comes at little to no cost to Apple -- disincentivizes Apple from launching its own search engine when it otherwise has built the capacity to do so,\" Mehta wrote.\n\nThe court also referenced the framework from the landmark tech monopoly case, US v. Microsoft, highlighting its relevance to the current case against Google. Despite Google's claim that its actions remained consistent before and after achieving market dominance, Judge Mehta emphasized that such conduct can be exclusionary when performed by a dominant player, even if it is not when done by a smaller entity.\n\nGoogle's Durable Monopoly\n\nJudge Mehta described Google's monopoly in general search as \"remarkably durable,\" noting that its market share increased from about 80 percent in 2009 to 90 percent by 2020. In comparison, Bing holds less than 6 percent of the market share. \"If there is genuine competition in the market for general search, it has not manifested in familiar ways, such as fluid market shares, lost business, or new entrants,\" Mehta stated.\n\nThe ruling underscores the lack of viable alternatives to Google for general search engines. Judge Mehta cited a quote from Apple SVP Eddy Cue, who testified that there was \"no price that Microsoft could ever offer [Apple] to preload Bing.\" This sentiment reflects the broader market reality that even the largest businesses in the US have no real alternative to Google.\n\nSearch Text Advertising and Pricing Practices\n\nRegarding search text advertising, Judge Mehta found that Google's exclusive agreements allowed it to raise prices without meaningful competitive constraints. Although Google argued that the price of its search text ads, when adjusted for quality, has decreased, Mehta found this evidence weak. He noted that Google itself recognized the difficulty in determining \"the value of an ad to its buyer.\" The judge concluded that Google's pricing practices were primarily aimed at driving long-term revenues rather than reflecting principled, quality-adjusted pricing.\n\nNo Sanctions for Destroying Evidence\n\nJudge Mehta declined to impose sanctions on Google for failing to preserve chat messages relevant to the case, despite the DOJ's characterization of this as evidence destruction. While he acknowledged Google's failure to preserve chat evidence, he determined that the requested sanctions did not affect the court's assessment of Google's liability. However, Mehta cautioned that Google's avoidance of sanctions in this case does not guarantee similar leniency in future cases.\n\nFuture Remedies: The judgment currently addresses Google's liability, with future proceedings to decide on possible remedies, including business practice changes or a breakup of its search operations.\n\nMonopoly Maintenance: Google has maintained its monopoly in search and advertising markets through exclusionary contracts and dominant market practices.\n\nLegal Findings: Judge Mehta found Google guilty of violating the Sherman Act, specifically Section 2, by monopolizing general search services and search text advertising.\n\nImpact on Market: The ruling highlights the lack of genuine competition in the search market, with Google's dominance being unchallenged by competitors like Bing.\n\nThe price is currently at $160.10, down -6.56 for the day. The 50-day moving average (MA) is at $179.74, while the 200-day MA is at $154.58. The stock is trading below the 50-day MA, indicating a short-term bearish trend, but above the 200-day MA, suggesting a long-term bullish trend.\n\nThe volume shows a spike, indicating increased trading activity, which often precedes significant price movements.\n\nThe Relative Strength IndexIn the world of technical analysis, the Relative Strength Index (RSI) stands as a cornerstone tool for traders seeking insights into market momentum. Developed by J. Welles Wilder ... More (RSI) is at 28.28, which is in the oversold territory, suggesting the stock may be due for a rebound.\n\nThe On Balance VolumeThe On Balance Volume indicator (OBV) is a technical analysis tool used to measure the flow of money into and out of a security over a specified period of time. It is a cumulative ... More (OBV) is trending upwards, indicating that the volume on up days is higher than on down days, suggesting buying pressure.\n\nThe Stochastic RSIIn the realm of technical analysis, the Stochastic RSI (StochRSI) emerges as a powerful tool for traders seeking to navigate market dynamics with precision. Developed by Tushar S. ... More is at 0, indicating extreme oversold conditions, further supporting the potential for a rebound.\n\nThe Chaikin OscillatorNamed after its creator Marc Chaikin, the Chaikin Oscillator stands as a formidable tool in the arsenal of technical analysts. This oscillator is designed to measure the accumulati... More is at -17,824,561, showing a strong negative money flow, indicating that money is flowing out of the stock.\n\nThe MACDThe MACD indicator is essentially a momentum indicator that shows the relationship between two different moving averages of price. The MACD is the difference between the 12-period ... More Oscillator shows the MACD line at -7.54, the signal line at -4.48, and the histogram at -3.06. This indicates a bearish crossover with the MACD line below the signal line, suggesting a bearish momentum.\n\nTime-Frame Signals:\n\n12 Months: Buy. Long-term indicators and the 200-day MA position suggest bullish prospects. The current oversold conditions may provide a good entry point for long-term investors.\n\n3 Months: Hold. The oversold indicators suggest a potential rebound, but bearish momentum and negative money flow suggest caution.\n\n6 Months: Buy. The stock is above the 200-day MA, indicating long-term bullish potential. The oversold conditions support a potential upward move.\n\nFor the past year, the stock shows a strong upward trend from September 2022 to July 2023, characterized by higher highs and higher lows. This bullish trend reaches a peak around July 2023, after which a correction begins. The price currently shows signs of stabilizing above the 200-day moving average, which acts as a significant support level. Volume analysis indicates consistent trading activity, with on-balance volume (OBV) reflecting a steady accumulation phase, suggesting that buyers have been dominant overall. However, recent declines in OBV indicate some distribution as the price corrected.\n\nIn the two-year time frame, the stock has recovered from the lower levels seen in late 2022 and established a clear upward trajectory. The anchored volume-weighted average price (VWAP) from August 2023 is currently at 147.75, indicating the average price investors have paid over this period. The stock price being above this level suggests positive investor sentiment and overall gains. The volume profile shows significant buying interest, particularly during the upward movements.\n\nFor the three-year time frame, the stock has shown resilience, bouncing back from the lows experienced in 2022. The long-term uptrend is intact, with the stock maintaining higher support levels and exhibiting a steady climb. The current retracement appears to be a healthy correction within a larger bullish framework.\n\nTime-Frame Signals:\n\nPast performance is not an indication of future results. This analysis should not be considered as investment advice. Always conduct your own research and consider consulting with a financial advisor before making any investment decisions. \ud83e\udde1\n\nBroader Implications\n\nThis decision is the first in a series of tech monopoly cases initiated by the US government in recent years. While two decades passed between the DOJ's antitrust lawsuit against Microsoft and its next tech anti-monopoly case against Google, filed in 2020, several more such cases have followed swiftly. This ruling sets a significant precedent and signals a renewed commitment by the US government to challenge monopolistic practices in the tech industry.\n\nIn conclusion, Judge Mehta's ruling against Google represents a critical juncture in the ongoing efforts to regulate and ensure fair competition in the tech sector. The next phase of proceedings will be pivotal in determining the full extent of the ruling's impact on Google's business and the broader market dynamics.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8260692617", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "20:16:51", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T20:16:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T20:16:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://www.thurrott.com/google/306697/google-loses-u-s-antitrust-case", "title": "Google Loses U.S. Antitrust Case, Search is Illegal Monopoly", "body": "A federal judge ruled that Google's search engine is a monopoly and that the firm's agreement with Apple, Mozilla, and others violates U.S. antitrust laws.\n\n\"Google is a monopolist, and it has acted as one to maintain its monopoly,\" U.S. district court judge Amit Mehta writes in his 286-page ruling. \"It has violated Section 2 of the Sherman Act.\"\n\nThe U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ) and 8 U.S. states-California, Colorado, Connecticut, New Jersey, New York, Rhode Island, Tennessee, and Virginia-sued Google in January 2023, alleging that the online giant violated the Sherman Antitrust Act by engaging in illegal behavior to protect its search monopoly. 9 more states-Arizona, Illinois, Michigan, Minnesota, Nebraska, New Hampshire, North Carolina, Washington, and West Virginia-joined the suit in April 2023, though Judge Mehta also narrowed the case somewhat that month to focus it on Google's cozy arrangements with device makers-especially Apple-and web browser makers.\n\nThis focus was devastating to Google and Apple: During the subsequent trial in late 2023, it came to light that the online giant paid Apple over $10 billion a year to be the default search engine on the iPhone, and that payment exceeded $23 billion in 2023. The revelation shocked Apple's fans, who were told that \"everything that happens on iPhone stays on iPhone.\" But with this guilty verdict, it's going to be further damaging to both companies. It could also harm Mozilla, which relies on Google search engine payments to stay in business.\n\n\"Google has thwarted true competition by foreclosing its rivals from the most effective channels of search distribution,\" Judge Mehta writes in the ruling, comparing the company and its behavior to Microsoft, which used similar tactics in the late 1990s to harm Netscape. \"Google's distribution agreements are exclusionary contracts that violate Section 2 [of the Sherman Act] because they ensure that half of all [online search] users in the United States will receive Google as the preloaded default on all Apple and Android devices, as well as cause additional anticompetitive harm. The agreements 'clearly have a significant effect in preserving [Google's] monopoly'.\"\n\nWhat Google is doing with its search agreements-with Apple, Mozilla, and others-is paying for placement at such a high price that it prevents potential competitors from even trying. This is the \"barrier to entry\" argument common to antitrust, as it skews what would otherwise be a healthy competitive environment by skewing the choices in its favor. The ruling notes that Google spent over $26 billion on traffic acquisition costs in 2021 alone, four times the cost of all of Google's other search-related costs, including R&D, combined.\n\nThis is bad enough for web browser makers, but it's incredible for Apple and the iPhone: At $20 billion per year or more, Google is probably contributing over 25 percent of Apple's total Services revenues and at no cost to Apple. The ruling notes Apple executive Eddy Cue's testimony explaining that Microsoft literally couldn't pay enough to get Apple to switch from Google to Bing: Google Search was superior because Google could improve its results using the massive amount of data it got from Apple's users. Or, as Judge Mehta put it, \"Google's distribution agreements have constrained the query volumes of its rivals, thereby inoculating Google against any genuine competitive threat.\"\n\n\"No profit-driven firm in Microsoft's position would invest the substantial sums required to enhance its search product when there is little to no genuine opportunity for a default distribution deal,\" the ruling continues. \"Google's distribution agreements thus appear reasonably capable of having significantly contributed to disincentivizing Microsoft from enlarging its investment in search.\"\n\nThe ruling verifies that Google paid Apple $20 billion in 2022, 17.5 percent of Apple's annual profits, so its payment last year would have been higher. And that Apple was financially disincentivized from creating its own search engine, as Google's huge annual payments were all profit, with no risk or expenses.\n\nGoogle did win on some minor points, and Judge Mehta declined to sanction the company. But because Google was found to have violated U.S. antitrust laws, it must terminate its exclusive distribution agreements, subject to a separate penalties phase and an expected appeal. If this ruling is upheld, Google, Apple, and Mozilla could all suffer greatly. Microsoft could find that its fruitless investments in Bing will suddenly pay off in a regulated market for search. And in an extreme outcome, Google might even face a breakup order, which the DOJ indicated was a possibility.\n\nMore soon: I need some time to analyze this ruling. The key question then is this: Do Google's exclusive distribution contracts reasonably appear capable of significantly contributing to maintaining Google's monopoly power in the general search services market? The answer is 'yes,'\" the judge wrote.\n\nGoogle took in $146 billion in advertising revenue in 2021 and had captured 90% of all search queries in 2020, according to the court documents. Microsoft's Bing was the second-most used search engine with 6% of search queries.\n\nMore from this section USA stroll past Puerto Rico to stay unbeaten at Olympics Taiwanese rally behind 'brave' boxer Lin at centre of gender brawl Harris set to name VP pick ahead of swing state tour\n\n\"This victory against Google is an historic win for the American people,\" said Attorney General Merrick Garland in a media release. \"No company -- no matter how large or influential -- is above the law. The Justice Department will continue to vigorously enforce our antitrust laws.\"\n\nMehta said he would not sanction Google for not preserving chat messages among its employees involving discussion on the topic. Google had a long-standing practice of deleting employees' chat messages after 24 hours unless a setting was changed to preserve them. The court documents stated that even two years after filing suit, Google still was not preserving chat messages of its employees that were under a legal hold. In February 2023, the plaintiffs moved for sanctions and only then Google changed its policy.\n\nGoogle did not immediately respond to an email seeking comment.\n\n\"Google was just handed a MASSIVE defeat in court over its search business,\" said internet personality Nick Sortor on X. \"Hopefully this will lead to accountability for Google, since they've been manipulating search results in favor of the Kamala Harris campaign.\"\n\nThe media reported on Aug. 2 that the internet tech giant was criticized over claims of election interference. "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://english.news.cn/20240806/d39e40381ba24980bec6af814fcbc0d9/c.html", "title": "Judge rules Google has illegal monopoly in Internet search", "body": "SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 6 (Xinhua) -- Google has violated the U.S. antitrust law by maintaining a monopoly in the online search market, a federal judge from the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia ruled on Monday.\n\nJudge Amit Mehta agreed with the U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ) that Google has a monopoly in \"general search services\" and \"the general search text ads market.\"\n\n\"After having carefully considered and weighed the witness testimony and evidence, the court reaches the following conclusion: Google is a monopolist, and it has acted as one to maintain its monopoly,\" according to the court's ruling. \"It has violated Section 2 of the Sherman Act.\"\n\nGoogle controls about 90 percent of the online search market and 95 percent on smartphones, said the ruling, capping a yearslong case.\n\nThe DOJ reportedly sued in 2020 over Google's dominance in online search, which was the first time in a generation that the U.S. government accused a major corporation of an illegal monopoly.\n\n\"This landmark decision holds Google accountable,\" DOJ antitrust Assistant Attorney General Jonathan Kanter said in a statement. \"It paves the path for innovation for generations to come and protects access to information for all Americans.\"\n\nKent Walker, Google's president of Global Affairs, said the company intends to appeal Mehta's ruling.\n\n\"This decision recognizes that Google offers the best search engine, but concludes that we shouldn't be allowed to make it easily available,\" he said in a statement. \"As this process continues, we will remain focused on making products that people find helpful and easy to use.\"\n\nGoogle's fate will be decided in the next phase of proceedings, which could determine potential fixes possibly including a breakup of Google's parent Alphabet, according to media reports.\n\nThe next separate antitrust trial between the DOJ and Google is set to begin on Sept. 9 in Virginia. That case will focus on whether Google has illegally monopolized advertising technology.\n\nAmazon, Apple, and Meta now all face monopolization lawsuits from the U.S. government. \u25a0", "source": The decision was issued by US District Judge Amit Mehta in a trial that marks the country's biggest antitrust showdown. Here's everything you need to know about the trial and and what the judge ruled:\n\n1. The evidence included testimony from top executives at Google, Microsoft and Apple and lasted 10 weeks.\n\n2. Judge Amit Mehta said in the 277-page ruling, \"After having carefully considered and weighed the witness testimony and evidence, the court reaches the following conclusion: Google is a monopolist, and it has acted as one to maintain its monopoly.\"\n\n3. Google \"enjoys an 89.2% share of the market for general search services, which increases to 94.9% on mobile devices,\" the ruling noted.\n\n4. The ruling is a major setback for Google which has said that it is popular among consumers as they wish to use the search engine. Google's search engine processes an estimated 8.5 billion queries per day worldwide, nearly a double from 12 years ago.\n\n5. Kent Walker, Google's president of global affairs, said, \"This decision recognizes that Google offers the best search engine, but concludes that we shouldn't be allowed to make it easily available.\"\n\n6. US Attorney General Merrick Garland called the ruling \"a historic win for the American people\" and said that \"no company - no matter how large or influential - is above the law.\"\n\n7. White House press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre said the \"pro-competition ruling is a victory for the American people.
