{"uri": "2024-08-445040344", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "22:33:13", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T22:33:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T22:31:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://www.kansascity.com/news/business/article290776814.html", "title": "Federal judge calls Google 'monopolist,' says it violates U.S. antitrust laws", "body": "Aug. 5 (UPI) -- A federal judge on Monday ruled that Google violated U.S. antitrust law as a monopoly in search and text advertising.\n\nIn 2020, the government alleged that Google has kept its share of the general search market by creating strong barriers to entry and a feedback loop that sustained its dominance.\n\nDistrict Court Judge Amit Mehta in the District of Columbia ruled Google violated Section 2 of the Sherman Act, which outlaws monopolies, in a 277-page opinion.\n\n\"After having carefully considered and weighed the witness testimony and evidence, the court reaches the following conclusion: Google is a monopolist, and it has acted as one to maintain its monopoly,\" he wrote.\n\nThe company has exclusive contracts for a dominant position, including with Apple, as the world's default search provider on smartphones and web browsers.\n\nRivals include Microsoft's Bing and DuckDuckGo and others.\n\n\"This victory against Google is an historic win for the American people,\" Attorney General Garland said in a statement. \"No company -- no matter how large or influential -- is above the law. The Justice Department will continue to vigorously enforce our antitrust laws.\"\n\nAssistant Attorney General Kanter said: \"This landmark decision holds Google accountable. It paves the path for innovation for generations to come and protects access to information for all Americans. This victory is a reflection on the tireless efforts of the dedicated public servants at the Antitrust Division and our state law enforcement partners whose work made today's decision possible.\"\n\nKent Walker, Google's president of global affairs, said in a statement that the company plans to appeal the ruling.\n\n\"This decision recognizes that Google offers the best search engine, but concludes that we shouldn't be allowed to make it easily available,\" Walker wrote. \"As this process continues, we will remain focused on making products that people find helpful and easy to use.\"\n\nRemedies have not been determined, including fines.\n\nThe court could force Google to implement a \"choice screen\" letting users know about other available search engines, Vanderbilt University law professor Rebecca Allensworth told CNN.\n\nAttorneys general from 38 states and territories, led by Colorado and Nebraska, joined the DOJ in the lawsuit.\n\nIn December, a federal jury in California said that Google runs an illegal monopoly with its proprietary app store. The court is still deliberating possible remedies.\n\nA separate antitrust suit brought by the Biden administration against Google in 2023 is related to the company's advertising technology business. That case is slated to head to trial in early September.\n\nAmazon and Apple are also facing antitrust lawsuits.\n\nAlphabet is the parent company of Google, which was founded on Sept. 4, 1998, in Menlo Park, and went public in 2004. Alphabet's shares were down 4.61%, $7.41 to $159.25, as the stock market was down sharply among economic fears. {"uri": "2024-08-445029701", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "22:13:47", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T22:13:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T20:19:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://qnewshub.com/technology/google-loses-antitrust-case-over-search/", "title": "Google Loses Antitrust Case Over Search | QNewsHub", "body": "A federal U.S. judge ruled Monday that Google has illegally held a monopoly in two market areas: search and text advertising.\n\nThe landmark case from the government, filed in 2020, alleged that Google has kept its share of the general search market by creating strong barriers to entry and a feedback loop that sustained its dominance. The court found that Google violated Section 2 of the Sherman Act, which outlaws monopolies.\n\nThe ruling marks the first anti-monopoly decision against a tech company in decades.\n\n\"Google is a monopolist, and it has acted as one to maintain its monopoly,\" Judge Amit Mehta of the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia wrote in the decision.\n\nThe Department of Justice and a bipartisan group of attorneys general from 38 states and territories, led by Colorado and Nebraska, filed similar but separate antitrust suits against Google in 2020. The suits were combined for pretrial purposes, such as discovery of evidence.\n\nAttorney General Merrick Garland called the decision a \"historic win for the American people.\"\n\n\"No company -- no matter how large or influential -- is above the law,\" Garland wrote in a statement. \"The Justice Department will continue to vigorously enforce our antitrust laws.\"\n\nIn its ruling, the court homed in on Google's exclusive search arrangements on Android and Apple's iPhone and iPad devices, saying that they helped to cement Google's anticompetitive behavior and dominance over the search markets.\n\nGeneral search services, according to the court, applies to Google's core search engine, where it traditionally competed with Yahoo. General search text advertising refers to the text ads that run alongside search results. The court ruled that in both of those areas, Google has operated as a monopoly. However, the ruling found that general search advertising is not a market so there can be no monopoly control.\n\nKent Walker, Google's president of global affairs, said in a statement that the company plans to appeal the ruling. He highlighted the court's emphasis on the quality of Google's products.\n\n\"This decision recognizes that Google offers the best search engine, but concludes that we shouldn't be allowed to make it easily available,\" Walker wrote. \"As this process continues, we will remain focused on making products that people find helpful and easy to use.\"\n\nAlphabet shares fell more than 4% on Monday, {"uri": "8260804648", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "22:16:58", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T22:16:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T22:16:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://www.laptopmag.com/google-antirust-ruling-money", "title": "The most revealing stat in the Google antitrust ruling was revealed in October 2023", "body": "On Monday, Google was the subject of a history-making decision. It's the first major tech company since Microsoft in 2001 to be found guilty of antitrust-like behaviors.\n\nIn a lengthy ruling, Judge Amit Mehta in a federal court in Washington, D.C., writes that Google abused its monopoly on search.\n\nHaving a monopoly is not illegal, but acting to keep one, in whatever form those actions take, often is illegal.\n\nThe most interesting number in the trial, however, concerns where most people do their Googling: on their phones.\n\nIf you live in the U.S., there's more than half a chance you use an iPhone: An estimate in a Department of Justice complaint puts the number at 60% for Apple's iPhone market share in the U.S.\n\nThe amount of money that Google paid Apple to be the default search engine on iPhones in 2021 is an eye-wateringly high number, but if your phone controls more than half of the U.S. market, you can command a very high sum from Google.\n\nMonday's ruling (read the full PDF of the ruling here) is the most significant part of a trial that ran from September to November 2023, and illustrates just how important one enormous sum -- first revealed in October 2023 during the trial -- became to the judgment.\n\nThe most interesting and essential part of the trial might be this number: $26.3 billion. In a slide revealed at the trial on October 27, 2023, Google paid $26.3 billion to browser companies, phone makers, and wireless carriers to be the default search engine.\n\nThe New York Times reported that \"around $18 billion\" was to Apple. The rest went to other companies like Samsung, L.G., Motorola, and phone carriers like AT&T, T-Mobile, Verizon, and web browsers like Mozilla and Opera.\n\nIf you're curious, dig into the 2020 federal complaint against Google. It explains revenue-sharing agreements, or RSAs, wherein \"Google generally requires exclusive distribution as the sole preset default general search service on an ever-expanding list of search access points.\"\n\nIn return, Google would pay those companies a percentage of advertising revenue from searches. It should be noted here that Google also benefited from the data it collected on user behaviors and macro-search trends, which it could monetize via miscellaneous methods.\n\nMehta in his ruling, is clear: \"Google is a monopolist, and it has acted as one to maintain its monopoly.\"\n\nIn response to the ruling on Monday, Google's President of Global Affairs, Kent Walker, struck a slightly defiant tone:\n\n\"This decision recognizes that Google offers the best search engine, but concludes that we shouldn't be allowed to make it easily available,\" Walker said in a statement released to the press. \"As this process continues, we will remain focused on making products that people find helpful and easy to use.\"\n\nGoogle has had a grip on search for more than a decade. In 2009, the ruling notes, nearly 80% of internet searches in the U.S. were through Google.\n\n\"Follow the money,\" that old journalism phrase borne out of the Watergate scandal, also rings true in the ruling: Where large sums are being exchanged, scrutiny may follow.\n\nWhat's next? For Google, a lot.\n\nFor one, a new trial will be held to determine Google's punishment in this trial.\n\nAnd in September, a new, different federal trial is scheduled to start, as the Department of Justice argues that Google's advertising tech is an illegal monopoly.", "source": {"uri": "laptopmag.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "LaptopMag"}, "authors": [{"uri": "nick_lucchesi@laptopmag.com", {"uri": "8260866052", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "23:36:58", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T23:36:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T23:35:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://dnyuz.com/2024/08/05/theres-a-30-billion-reason-the-google-antitrust-ruling-will-have-the-search-giant-very-worried-right-now/", "title": "There's a $30 billion reason the Google antitrust ruling will have the search giant very worried right now", "body": "Google's agreements with Apple and other companies to be their default search engine have violated antitrust law, a federal judge ruled on Monday.\n\n\"Google is a monopolist,\" wrote US District Judge Amit P. Mehta in the ruling, \"and it has acted as one to maintain its monopoly.\"\n\nThe Department of Justice's case centered on Google's payments to other companies, like Apple and Samsung, to give its search engine prominence on their devices.\n\nFor Google, there's apparently a very good reason to keep these payments coming, as the search revenue generated is worth billions.\n\nAccording to Monday's filing, the company estimated in 2017 that its default placements across Safari, Firefox, and other browsers drove 54% of its search revenue. That number has only increased.\n\nIn particular, Google has a major deal with Apple to keep Google the default search engine on Safari, which runs on iPhones, iPads, and Mac computers worldwide.\n\nIn 2020, Google projected that it would lose between 60% and 80% of its search volume on Apple devices if it were replaced as the default general search engine, the filing said. That accounts for between $28.2 billion and $32.7 billion in net revenue losses, it added.\n\n\"Google's distribution agreements are exclusive and have anticompetitive effects,\" Mehta wrote.\n\nEddy Cue, senior vice president of services at Apple, revealed in court documents earlier this year that Google paid $20 billion in 2022 to secure this spot, which amounted to 17.5% of Apple's operating income. So, any remedy that stops or reduces Google's search payments would be bad news for Apple, too.\n\nThe landmark decision on Monday marked the near-conclusion of the DOJ's lawsuit against the search company, which was filed in 2020.\n\nWhat happens next is still unknown, as the ruling did not include remedies.\n\nGoogle's president of global affairs, Kent Walker, told Business Insider in a statement that the company plans to appeal; this could be drawn out for a while longer.\n\nThe ruling will undoubtedly have Google leaders concerned, particularly if remedies include forcing it to break up with Apple.\n\nSome experts previously floated a worst-case scenario for Google where it's barred from bidding for the default position on devices while competitors still can, although this may be an extreme scenario.\n\nEven so, anything that pushes Google out of that default spot on Apple's devices could be very bad news for the search giant -- and it knows it.\n\nAre you a Google employee? Got a tip? {"uri": "8261659363", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "11:08:16", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T11:08:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T11:06:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://www.ndtvprofit.com/technology/us-district-court-judges-ruling-against-google-could-have-cascading-effect-say-experts", "title": "US District Court Judge's Ruling Against Google Could Have Cascading Effect, Say Experts", "body": "US District Court Judge Amit Mehta's ruling that Google's exclusivity agreements to make its search engine the default has violated anti-trust laws could have a cascading effect, according to Dr AK Garg, director and head of digital technology and law at Anand and Anand.\n\nOn Aug. 5, Judge Mehta ruled that Google had violated Section 2 of the Sherman Act (An antitrust law published in 1980) by maintaining its unfettered dominance in two product markets in the United States. The search giant had breached law by using exclusivity agreements to maintain a monopoly on general search services and general text advertising.\n\n\"Google is a monopolist, and it has acted as one to maintain its monopoly,\" Judge Mehta noted in the ruling. While Google's market share in 2009 was nearly 80% in the search engine, it had only increased further to 90% by 2020, the judge noted. By comparison, its closest competitors, Bing and Yahoo, hold less than 6% and 2.5% market share, respectively. There's also privacy browser Duck Duck Go, which currently holds a market share of just 2.1%.\n\nGoogle plans to appeal the ruling.\n\n\"We appreciate the court's finding that Google is 'the industry's highest quality search engine, which has earned Google the trust of hundreds of millions of daily users,' that Google 'has long been the best search engine, particularly on mobile devices,' 'has continued to innovate in search' and that 'Apple and Mozilla occasionally assess Google's search quality relative to its rivals and find Google's to be superior'. Given this, and that people are increasingly looking for information in more and more ways, we plan to appeal,\" said a statement released by the company's President of Global Affairs Kent Walker on X, formerly Twitter.\n\n\"Other competition commissions will take note and that will be the way they will be ruling, at least in the case of Google,\" said Garg.", "source": {"uri": "ndtvprofit.com", According to Judge Amit Metha and after a ten-week trial, Google has been ruled to be in breach of Section 2 of the Sherman Act.\n\n\"Google is a monopolist, and it has acted as one to maintain its monopoly,\" the ruling states.\n\nThe ruling means the court agrees with the DOJ's accusation of Google acting as an illegal monopoly in the search market as well as in online advertising. However, the ruling only determines Google's liability, and not any fines or other restitution.\n\nThis is not the only DOJ lawsuit Google faces in 2024. {"uri": "2024-08-444956867", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "20:15:27", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T20:15:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T18:54:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://gazette.com/news/us-world/google-has-an-illegal-monopoly-on-search-us-judge-finds/article_d20afa4e-6bda-587c-8bcd-ef5da5c62a14.html", "title": "Google has an illegal monopoly on search, US judge finds", "body": "By David Shepardson and Mike Scarcella\n\nWASHINGTON (Reuters) -Alphabet's Google broke the law with monopolistic behavior over online search and related advertising, a federal judge ruled on Monday, the first victory for U.S. antitrust authorities who have filed numerous lawsuits challenging Big Tech's market dominance.\n\nThe decision is a significant win for the Justice Department, which had sued the search engine giant over its control of about 90% of the online search market, and 95% on smartphones.\n\n\"The court reaches the following conclusion: Google is a monopolist, and it has acted as one to maintain its monopoly,\" U.S. District Judge Amit Mehta wrote.\n\nHis ruling against Google paves the way for a second trial to determine potential fixes, such as breaking up the company or requiring the company to stop paying smartphone makers billions of dollars annually to set Google as the default search engine on new phones.\n\nUltimately, Google will have a chance to appeal the court's rulings to the U.S. District Court of Appeal for the D.C. Circuit.\n\nShares of Google parent Alphabet fell 4.3% on Monday as part of a broad tech share decline.\n\nMehta noted that Google had paid $26.3 billion in 2021 alone to ensure that its search engine is the default on smartphones and browsers, and to keep its dominant market share.\n\n\"The default is extremely valuable real estate... Even if a new entrant were positioned from a quality standpoint to bid for the default when an agreement expires, such a firm could compete only if it were prepared to pay partners upwards of billions of dollars in revenue share and make them whole for any revenue shortfalls resulting from the change,\" Mehta wrote.\n\nHe noted \"Google, of course, recognizes that losing defaults would dramatically impact its bottom line. For instance, Google has projected that losing the Safari default would result in a significant drop in queries and billions of dollars in lost revenues.\"\n\nThe ruling is the first major decision in a series of cases taking on alleged monopolies in Big Tech.\n\n\"A forced divestiture of the search business would sever Alphabet from its largest source of revenue. But even losing its capacity to strike exclusive default agreements could be detrimental for Google,\" said Emarketer senior analyst Evelyn Mitchell-Wolf, who noted a drawn out legal process will delay any immediate effects for consumers.\n\nIn the past four years, federal antitrust regulators have also sued Meta Platforms, Amazon.com, and Apple Inc, claiming the companies have illegally maintained monopolies. Another case against Google over its advertising technology is scheduled to go to trial in September.\n\nWhen it was filed in 2020, the Google search case was the first time in a generation that the U.S. government accused a major corporation of an illegal monopoly. Microsoft settled with the Justice Department in 2004 over claims that it forced its Internet Explorer web browser on Windows users.\n\n(Reporting by David Shepardson, Mike Scarcella and Chris Sanders in Washington; additional reporting by Arsheeya Singh Bajwa; editing by Peter Henderson)\n\nCLICK HERE TO READ MORE FROM THE GAZETTE", "source": {"uri": "gazette.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8260929969", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "01:03:00", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T01:03:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T01:02:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://www.avclub.com/google-monopoly-federal-court", "title": "In a banner ruling for Bing, federal judge deems Google a monopoly", "body": "As Google continues to impair its revolutionary search engine, a federal judge has determined that the company's market domination is improper. Per The Washington Post, Google illegally abused its power to maintain its massive market share. In other words, [Googles \"word for company illegally abusing power to maintain market dominance\"], \"Google is a monopolist,\" wrote Judge Amit Mehta, U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia, \"and it has acted as one to maintain its monopoly.\"\n\nPutting aside all the obvious, user-specific reasons why Google sucks now (the ads, lack of precise and helpful search results, bogus summaries encouraging one to eat glue, etc.), the basis of Judge Mehta's argument is how Google maintains its market share. Ironically, the company doesn't keep customers by forcing them to lament, \"I can't believe how bad Google is these days.\" Actually, it's Google's quashing and gatekeeping competition. Judge Mehta finds Google's penchant for paying Apple an estimated $19 billion to make Google the default search engine for Apple products to be out of bounds, unfairly bending market forces in Google's direction. Mehta also found that despite no real competition (sorry, Bing), Google consistently and incrementally raised prices. By increasing its prices over a protracted period, Google avoided the \"pitfalls\" of \"potential advertiser outcry and bad publicity\" because \"many advertisers do not even realize that Google is responsible for the changes in price.\"\n\nOf course, Google argued that it's successful because it's the best and not because it's the default on every device people buy. However, any Googler who has Googled in that last year knows Google isn't Googling as well as it used to. Most of this stems from Google placing its Head of Ads, Prabhakar Raghavan, in charge of Search, leading to one of those \"number go up,\" \"growth at any cost situations\" that has created such a sustainable economy for us to suffer. Per the ruling, Google may have to live up to its reputation or find another way to quash and gatekeep competition.\n\nThe judge has yet to rule on \"remedies\" for the internet's untenable Google problem. Most likely outcomes include a court blockage on Google's search placement payments to Apple. The Washington Post suggests that users could select Google as one of several search engines when they start their device. Apple may not like losing out on the $19 billion a year, but, uh, who cares? What's $19 billion to a company worth $3 trillion? Speaking of the world's most popular cellphone company, Apple is also under antitrust investigation with several other tech firms, including Amazon and Meta. Oh, no, please leave Facebook alone. That's our most valuable resource of A.I.-generated images of flight attendants saluting a shrimp Jesus. Amen.\n\nThis is the first time antitrust has been invoked against a major tech platform since Microsoft was deemed a monopoly for forcing users to use Internet Explorer, probably amounting to war crimes in certain nations. {"uri": "8261185066", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "05:45:12", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T05:45:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T05:44:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "http://theconversation.com/a-us-court-has-ruled-google-is-an-illegal-monopoly-and-the-internet-might-never-be-the-same-236227", "title": "A US Court has ruled Google is an illegal monopoly - and the internet might never be the same", "body": "Australian National University provides funding as a member of The Conversation AU.\n\nOn Monday a US federal judge ruled Google has violated antitrust laws, saying the organisation\n\nis a monopolist, and it has acted as one to maintain its monopoly.\n\nGoogle disputes the ruling. Its president of global affairs, Kent Walker, said \"this decision recognises that Google offers the best search engine, but concludes that we shouldn't be allowed to make it easily available\".\n\nNevertheless, the landmark decision has shaken the foundation of Google's business, its search engine. For well over a decade, Google has been the dominant search engine in the market. The tech giant reportedly controls around 90% of the US online search market, leaving little room for competitors to make any claim.\n\nGoogle has been able to maintain this dominance through exclusive contracts with companies such as Apple and Samsung, which enable Google to be the default search engine on their platforms.\n\nThese monopolistic practices have allowed Google to charge high prices for search advertising. Being the default browser across many platforms, this search engine has become the easiest, quickest and most reliable resource for most people. This has reinforced the company's online advertising business, leaving little room for competitors to offer comparable services at more reasonable prices.\n\nWhat does this mean for Google?\n\nA separate proceeding will be held to determine what penalties Google and its parent company, Alphabet, will face. However, it is likely the tech giant will be hit with both monetary penalties and enforced mitigations aimed at reducing its dominance.\n\nHistorically, fines have not been the sole method of enforcing antitrust laws as they do not demonstrate long-term impacts. This is especially true for a multi-trillion-dollar organisation such as Google.\n\nSome of the mitigations which may be imposed include the implementation of a \"choice screen\". This would allow users to pick between other available search engines, instead of having Google as the default option.\n\nThis is not the first time Google has been found guilty of breaching antitrust laws. Over the past decade it has been fined a total of \u20ac8.25 billion (A$13.6 billion) by the European Union for three separate breaches of the union's antitrust laws.\n\nAntitrust laws are enforced at domestic levels, and breaches of these laws are specific to domestic markets. This is why Google is facing these charges across two different continents.\n\nGoogle has continued to appeal the EU fines over the years. Walker has already confirmed that the company will appeal the US decision.\n\nWhat does this mean for internet users?\n\nAntitrust laws are designed to enhance competition. They exist to protect consumers by prohibiting business practices that promote unfair monopolies, suppress competition and enforce dominance or power.\n\nThe dominance that Google has held over other search engines has created a concentrated market that has prevented smaller competitors from operating equitably.\n\nThis is why Google can charge high advertising prices, because there is slim competition in terms of visibility.\n\nThe recent US ruling, alongside the EU rulings, may be the first steps towards opening the tech market up to other competitors. In turn, this may promote more equitable competition, which would be a win for consumers.\n\nCompetition fuels incentives for innovation. When there is only one option available, as often seems to be the case with search engines, this incentive is suffocated under the dominance of one monopolistic player.\n\nWhile antitrust laws are only enforced at domestic levels, hopefully the outcomes of the EU and US rulings will have flow-on effects that extend beyond these markets.\n\nWhat does this mean for the race for AI supremacy?\n\nDuring the trial, some concerns were raised around how Google's monopolised position as the default search engine has unfairly benefited it in the artificial intelligence (AI) race.\n\nThe default agreements and terms of conditions of the Google search engine has enabled the organisation to access enormous amounts of user search data, which can be used to train AI models. The easy access to this data may act as a gateway for Google to establish a position of dominance in AI.\n\nDismantling Google as the default search engine on platforms such as Apple and Samsung could shift Google's position in the race for AI supremacy.\n\nAs such, it may also shift the future trajectory of the entire internet.", "source": {"uri": "theconversation.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8261102285", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "04:30:06", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T04:30:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T04:29:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://www.firstpost.com/tech/googles-monopolist-ruling-for-search-and-ads-may-change-how-we-browse-the-internet-13801387.html", "title": "Google's 'monopolist' ruling for search and ads may change how we browse the internet", "body": "Sundar Pichai, Google CEO, is at the helm of the company during one of its most turbulent times. Image Credit: Reuters\n\nIn a major development that can potentially change the dynamics of how we as users browse the internet, Google has been found guilty of violating US antitrust laws.\n\nA federal judge ruled that Google monopolised both the advertising and search markets, marking a crucial moment in the US Department of Justice's (DOJ) antitrust lawsuit against Alphabet, Google's parent company.\n\nThis decision came after an extensive ten-week trial overseen by Judge Amit Metha, who concluded that Google breached Section 2 of the Sherman Act.\n\nThe ruling supports the DOJ's claims that Google operated as an illegal monopoly, particularly in the search and online advertising sectors.\n\nHowever, this verdict only addresses Google's liability, with no immediate decisions on fines or other penalties. This case is just one of several legal challenges Google faces in 2024, with another trial set for September to address its advertising technology practices.\n\nGoogle's Response and Plans for Appeal\n\nIn response to the ruling, Kent Walker, Google's President of Global Affairs, acknowledged the decision while defending Google's position. Walker noted that while the court recognised Google as the highest-quality search engine, it concluded that Google's methods of maintaining its monopoly were unacceptable.\n\n\"We appreciate the Court's finding that Google is 'the industry's highest quality search engine, which has earned Google the trust of hundreds of millions of daily users,' that Google 'has long been the best search engine, particularly on mobile devices,' 'has continued to innovate in search' and that 'Apple and Mozilla occasionally assess Google's search quality relative to its rivals and find Google's to be superior,\" he said.\n\nThe court highlighted Google's consistent superiority in search quality, particularly on mobile devices, and its ongoing innovations in the field. Despite this acknowledgement, Google plans to appeal the decision, emphasising its commitment to creating user-friendly and helpful products as the legal process continues.\n\nDetails of the DOJ's Case Against Google\n\nThe DOJ's lawsuit argued that Google maintained its monopoly status by making substantial payments to other companies to ensure its dominance as the default search engine. Notably, Google paid Apple $20 billion in 2022 to keep Google as the default search engine on Apple devices.\n\nThis substantial payment was revealed during the trial, where several Apple executives were called to testify. Despite attempts by Apple to avoid the subpoenas, high-ranking officials such as Eddy Cue, John Giannandrea, and Adrian Perica provided crucial evidence.\n\nThe trial also uncovered that Microsoft had attempted to replace Google as the default search engine on Apple's Safari browser by offering Apple 90 per cent of its advertising revenue. Microsoft even proposed selling Bing to Apple in 2020, highlighting the competitive dynamics within the search engine market.\n\nPotential Implications for Google's Financial Arrangements\n\nThe regular billion-dollar payments from Google to Apple have been highly lucrative for the latter, accounting for a significant portion of Google's ad revenue from searches conducted via Safari on iPhones.\n\nHowever, this financial arrangement may be in jeopardy following the DOJ's legal victory. Google's potential break-up, as hinted by Judge Metha, could disrupt these payments, creating financial uncertainties for both companies.\n\nFurthermore, in July, reports indicated that Google sought to reduce its reliance on Apple for search traffic and revenue, suggesting a shift in strategy amidst mounting legal pressures.\n\nThe future of these annual payments remains uncertain, and the It is likely to appeal against the ruling in a process that could go to the Supreme Court. The case depicted Google as a technological bully that has methodically thwarted competition to protect a search engine that has become the centrepiece of a digital advertising machine that generated \u00a3188 billion in revenue last year.\n\nJustice Department lawyers argued that Google's monopoly enabled it to charge advertisers artificially high prices while enjoying the luxury of having more time and money to invest in improving the quality of its search engine -- a lax approach that affected consumers.\n\nGoogle ridiculed the allegations noting that consumers have historically changed search engines when they became disillusioned with the results they were getting. For instance, Yahoo -- now a minor player -- was the most popular search engine in the Nineties.\n\nJudge Mehta's conclusion that Google has been running an illegal monopoly sets up another legal {"uri": "2024-08-445014648", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "21:47:31", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T21:47:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T21:47:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://www.quiverquant.com/news/U.S.%20Antitrust%20Win:%20Google%20Guilty%20of%20Search%20Market%20Monopoly", "title": "U.S. Antitrust Win: Google Guilty of Search Market Monopoly", "body": "Alphabet's Google broke the law with monopolistic behavior over online search and related advertising, a federal judge ruled on Monday, marking the first victory for U.S. antitrust authorities challenging Big Tech's market dominance. This significant win for the Justice Department comes after it sued the search engine giant over its control of about 90% of the online search market, and 95% on smartphones.\n\n\"The court reaches the following conclusion: Google is a monopolist, and it has acted as one to maintain its monopoly,\" U.S. District Judge Amit Mehta wrote. His ruling paves the way for a second trial to determine potential remedies, such as breaking up the company or requiring it to stop paying smartphone makers billions of dollars annually to set Google as the default search engine on new phones. This phase could be lengthy, followed by potential appeals to the D.C. Circuit and U.S. Supreme Court, possibly stretching into 2026.\n\nShares of Google parent Alphabet fell 4.3% on Monday amid a broad tech share decline. Alphabet announced plans to appeal Judge Mehta's ruling. Mehta noted that Google paid $26.3 billion in 2021 to ensure its search engine remains the default on smartphones and browsers, maintaining its dominant market share.\n\nThe ruling is the first major decision in a series of cases taking on alleged monopolies in Big Tech. Filed by the Trump administration, the case was heard from September to November. \"A forced divestiture of the search business would sever Alphabet (GOOG) from its largest source of revenue. But even losing its capacity to strike exclusive default agreements could be detrimental for Google,\" said Emarketer senior analyst Evelyn Mitchell-Wolf. {"uri": "2024-08-445022437", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "22:00:48", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T22:00:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T20:24:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://www.ccenterdispatch.com/news/national/article_622adf70-ccda-5570-8517-35c9090d42c5.html", "title": "US judge rules Google is monopoly in key anti-trust case", "body": "A US judge on Monday handed Google a major legal blow, ruling in a closely-watched anti-trust case that it has a monopoly with its dominant search engine.\n\nThe landmark decision against a \"big tech\" giant could alter how the sector operates in future.\n\nDistrict Court Judge Amit Mehta found that Google maintained a monopoly for search and for text ads through exclusive distribution agreements that made it the \"default\" option that people were likely to use on devices.\n\n\"After having carefully considered and weighed the witness testimony and evidence, the court reaches the following conclusion: Google is a monopolist, and it has acted as one to maintain its monopoly,\" Mehta wrote in his ruling.\n\nThe internet behemoth \"has a major, largely unseen advantage over its rivals: default distribution,\" he added.\n\nThe anti-trust trial pitting US prosecutors against Google ended in May with a two-day hearing.\n\nThe case was the first of five major lawsuits by the US government to reach trial, with Meta, Amazon, Apple and a separate case against Google also heading for federal courtrooms.\n\nHeld in Washington, the trial was the first time the US Department of Justice has faced a big tech company in court since Microsoft was targeted more than two decades ago over the dominance of its Windows operating system.\n\nMehta presided over several months of testimony late last year that saw Google CEO Sundar Pichai and other top executives take the stand.\n\nAt the heart of the government's case was the massive payments made by Google to Apple and other companies to keep its world-leading search engine as the default on iPhones, web browsers and other products.\n\nCourt testimony revealed that these payments reach the tens of billions of dollars every year to keep its prime real estate on Apple hardware or the Safari and Mozilla browsers.\n\nThe Department of Justice lawyers argued that Google achieved and perpetuated its dominance -- and strangled rivals -- through these default deals that also expanded to Samsung and other device makers.\n\nMehta concluded, however, that Google's violation of the Sherman Act did not have \"anticompetitive effects.\"\n\ngc/bgs", "source": {"uri": "ccenterdispatch.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Clay Center Dispatch On-Line"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8261729952", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "11:57:03", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T11:57:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T11:50:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://www.ndtv.com/world-news/google-loses-antitrust-case-all-you-need-to-know-6276139", "title": "Explained: The Google Antitrust Case", "body": "The ruling comes after a 10-week trial and is a major victory for the US Justice Department, which filed the lawsuit nearly four years ago.\n\nIn a landmark decision, US District Judge Amit Mehta has ruled that Google's dominance in the search market is a result of illegal monopolistic practices. The judge found Google's actions have stifled competition and innovation, and that the company's default search agreements with device manufacturers and browsers are a key factor in its market dominance.\n\nHere is a breakdown of what happened:\n\nThe case against Google\n\nThe ruling comes after a 10-week trial and is a major victory for the US Justice Department, which filed the lawsuit nearly four years ago. Google has announced plans to appeal the decision. The core accusation is that Google spent billions on exclusive deals to maintain its dominance in the search engine market, violating US antitrust laws.\n\nWhat are antitrust laws?\n\nAntitrust laws are regulations that promote fair competition by preventing monopolies, anti-competitive practices, and other activities that could harm consumers or other businesses.\n\nIn the United States, key laws include the Sherman Antitrust Act of 1890, which prohibits monopolies and actions that restrain trade, and the Clayton Antitrust Act of 1914, which addresses specific unfair practices. The Federal Trade Commission Act of 1914 established the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) to investigate and prevent unfair competition.\n\nThe FTC and the Antitrust Division of the Department of Justice (DOJ) enforce these laws. They investigate companies and take action if they find any violations.\n\nThe DoJ's arguments\n\nThe DoJ argued that Google's agreements with wireless carriers, browser developers, and device manufacturers, especially Apple, were anti-competitive. In 2021, Google reportedly paid over $26 billion to companies like Apple to make its search engine the default option on devices like iPhones and browsers like Safari and Mozilla.\n\nGoogle's search-based advertising is a major revenue source, generating $175 billion in 2022. For comparison, Microsoft's Bing made about $12 billion.\n\nGoogle has an 89.2 per cent share of the market for general search services, increasing to 94.9 per cent on mobile devices.\n\nGoogle's defence\n\nGoogle argued its dominance was due to the quality of its search engine. They plan to appeal the decision, stating that while the ruling recognises their search engine's quality, it restricts their ability to make it readily available.\n\nDistrict Judge's verdict\n\nThe trial spanned several months, with testimonies from Google CEO Sundar Pichai and other top executives. Judge Amit Mehta's 277-page decision labelled Google a \"monopolist\" and highlighted the sheer volume of Google's search queries compared to rivals. Mehta noted that Google \"enjoys an 89.2% share of the market for general search services, which increases to 94.9% on mobile devices.\" He concluded that while Google violated antitrust laws, it did not have \"anticompetitive effects.\"\n\nThe judge acknowledged that while Google's search engine is widely recognised as the best available, its market share is significantly bolstered by these agreements. The judge pointed out that other search engines, like Microsoft's Bing, can capture significant market share when not overshadowed by Google's default status. For instance, Bing holds an 80% share of the search market on the Microsoft Edge browser. He then ruled against the tech giant.\n\nUS Attorney General Merrick Garland called the decision an \"historic win for the American people,\" saying that no company is above the law.\n\nImplications\n\nFollowing the ruling, Google's parent company Alphabet's shares fell by 4.6%.\n\nThe court will now decide on the remedies Google must undertake. This could include restrictions on Google's ability to enter into exclusive deals.\n\nGoogle's president of global affairs, Kent Walker, said the company intends to appeal the decision.\n\nPromotedListen to the latest songs, only on JioSaavn.com\n\nJonathan Kanter, head of the DoJ's antitrust division, believes the ruling will pave the way for innovation and protect access to information. Meanwhile, the Consumer Choice Centre, a lobbying group, criticised the decision as a step in the wrong direction.\n\nThe ruling is part of a broader crackdown on Big Tech. The DoJ has another pending case against Google related to digital advertising, and the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) has filed lawsuits against Amazon and Meta.", "source": {"uri": "ndtv.com", {"uri": "2024-08-444955542", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "20:13:57", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T20:13:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T20:11:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://qz.com/google-loses-tech-antitrust-case-1851613659", "title": "Google just lost the biggest tech antitrust case in decades", "body": "A federal judge ruled on Monday that Google monopolized online search and advertising markets, violating U.S. antitrust laws.\n\nThe DOJ sued Google in 2020 for allegedly monopolizing digital search, pushing out competitors such as DuckDuckGo and Microsoft's Bing. It was the first major tech antitrust lawsuit since U.S. v. Microsoft, a 1998 case that found Microsoft monopolized computer operating systems. The trial concluded in May.\n\n\"Google's dominance has gone unchallenged for well over a decade,\" wrote Judge Amit Mehta in his 277-page ruling Tuesday. \"Google is a monopolist, and it has acted as one to maintain its monopoly. It has violated Section 2 of the Sherman Act.\"\n\nMehta said Google's exclusive agreements with companies like Apple have allowed it to hike prices for advertisers without any blowback. He wrote \"there is no evidence that any rival constrains Google's pricing decisions\" and that those unconstrained pricing decisions \"have fueled Google's dramatic revenue growth and allowed it to maintain high and remarkably stable operating profits.\" The judge noted that nearly 90% of all search queries went through Google in 2020.\n\nThe Google case has been likened to the U.S. v. Microsoft case, which alleged Microsoft held a similarly overwhelming share -- more than 90% -- of the computer operating system market.\n\nRegulators in the last several years have ramped up their antitrust scrutiny of Big Tech. This year, the U.S. Federal Trade Commission and Department of Justice have collectively filed major lawsuits against Amazon, Apple, and Meta, as well as a second antitrust case against Google, which alleges monopolistic practices in the digital advertising market.\n\nMehta's ruling has major implications for Google and consumers across the globe. Google will likely have to make substantial changes to its search engine business to comply with antitrust laws, which could open up a path for OpenAI's new search engine as well as other rivals.", {"uri": "8261543431", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "09:54:42", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T09:54:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T09:53:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://bobrtimes.com/why-google-might-no-longer-appear-as-the-default-search-engine-on-your-smartphone/", "title": "Why Google Might No Longer Appear as the Default Search Engine on Your Smartphone ? - The Bobr Times", "body": "This Monday, August 5, Google was found guilty by a Washington judge of anti-competitive practices.\n\nGoogle was found guilty on Monday, August 5, of abusing its dominant position in online searches and advertising in its lawsuit against the US government. The ruling sets the stage for a second trial to determine potential remedies, such as requiring the company to end its contracts with smartphone companies so that Google will no longer be the default search engine on new phones.\n\n\"This ruling recognizes that Google offers the best search engine, but concludes that we should not be allowed to make it easily accessible,\", the tech giant said in a statement.\n\nThe \"remediation phase\" could be lengthy, followed by possible appeals, and could last into next year or even 2026. U.S. Attorney General Merrick Garland called the decision a \"historic victory for the American people,\" adding that \"no company, no matter how big or influential, is above the law.\"\n\nThe decision is a major victory for the Justice Department, the first against a monopolistic company in more than 20 years, which has been suing the search engine giant for its control of about 90% of the online search market, and 95% of smartphones.\n\nFederal Judge Amit Mehtaa recalled that Google paid $26.3 billion (\u20ac24.01 billion) in 2021 to ensure that its search engine appeared by default on smartphones and internet browsers, and to maintain its dominant market share.\n\n\"The court concluded: Google is a monopolistic company, and it acted as such to maintain its monopoly,\", Amit Mehta wrote.\n\nAccording to Evelyn Mitchell-Wolf, an analyst at Emarketer, \"the loss of its ability to enter into agreements \"default exclusivity could hurt Google,\" she said. A drawn-out court case would delay any immediate impact on consumers.\n\nOver the past four years, federal antitrust regulators have also sued Meta Platforms, Amazon.com and Apple Inc for abusing its dominant position. Another trial against Google, over its advertising technology, is scheduled for September.\n\nThe last such high-profile ruling came in 2004, when Microsoft settled with the U.S. Justice Department {"uri": "8261849009", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "13:05:05", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T13:05:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T13:04:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://www.exchangewire.com/blog/2024/08/06/google-is-a-monopoly-whats-next/", "title": "Google IS a Monopoly: What's Next? - ExchangeWire.com", "body": "The verdict is in, and in one of the most significant legal battles in recent years, Google has officially been deemed to be a search monopoly.\n\nThis landmark ruling, brought by the U.S. Department of Justice (DoJ), alongside several states, judged that Google has engaged in anticompetitive practices to preserve its dominance, thereby stifling competition and innovation.\n\nSo how did we get here? And what's next?\n\nThe DoJ, along with 11 states, filed a lawsuit against Google in October 2020. The primary accusation is that Google has used its dominance in the search engine market to unfairly protect its position and suppress competitors.\n\nWith Google controlling about 90% of the online search market and 95% on smartphones, the launch of the most significant antitrust case since the Microsoft trial in the late 1990s, was bound to come eventually, and the trial began in late 2023.\n\nOn August 5th 2024, US District Judge Amit Mehta ruled that Google acted illegally to maintain a monopoly on search and related advertising. In his ruling, Mehta wrote: \"After having carefully considered and weighed the witness testimony and evidence, the court reaches the following conclusion: Google is a monopolist, and it has acted as one to maintain its monopoly.\"\n\nThe in-depth ruling covers a lot of ground, the crux of it being that Google has massively stifled competition in search through default agreements with the likes of Apple, and subsequent artificial price raises and contractual strong-arming. \"Once monopoly has been achieved and assuming significant entry barriers, the monopolist can set a profit-maximizing price without excessive concern about the behavior of other firms in the market.\" (discussing pricing power following price predation to drive out competitors). That is precisely how Google has approached its ad pricing... With less ad revenue, Google's rivals are limited in their ability to reinvest in quality improvements (both as to search and general search text ads) to attract more users and more ad dollars.\"\n\nThe ruling was heralded by US Attorney General Merrick Garland, the country's top prosecutor, as a \"historic win for the American people\". He continued: \"No company - no matter how large or influential - is above the law,\" Mr Garland said in a statement on Monday. \"The Justice Department will continue to vigorously enforce our antitrust laws.\"\n\nNo punishments have been meted out by the DoJ. Yet. 'Remedies' to the situation will be discussed in further court sessions, however the ruling is expected to have significant repercussions:\n\nAlphabet will, of course, appeal the result. In a company statement, Alphabet looked at the positives while biting back at the ruling: \"This decision recognises that Google offers the best search engine, but concludes that we shouldn't be allowed to make it easily available.\"\n\nHowever, the robust ruling from Mehta raises questions as to the legal arguments Google could make to overturn the judgment. As he put simply, \"The fact that Google makes product changes without concern that its users might go elsewhere is something only a firm with monopoly power could do.\"\n\nIn short, more legal wranglings. After this ruling, Google are back in court against the DoJ on September 9th, facing charges relating to the company's ad stack. As per ExchangeWire's Mat Broughton: \"The DOJ's next case alleges that Google, via a host of acquisitions and subsequent manipulative self-preferencing actions, forced as many transactions as possible through its own ad tech stack, to the detriment of players across the entire digital advertising supply chain.\"\n\nMuch like the antirust search trial, the case will be tried by a single judge (US District Judge Leonie Brinkema) in a bench trial rather than by jury. Google managed to avoid a jury trial by paying USD$2.3m (\u00a31.8m), the maximum damages payable to the government.\n\nHowever, as Judge Mehta's ruling has shown, the lack of jury is no guarantee of success for Google; the DoJ are showing their teeth these days, and this week's ruling will ramp up the tension at the company heading towards the next case. "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://www.thenationalnews.com/business/2024/08/05/google-loses-major-anti-trust-case-over-its-search-dominance/", "title": "Google loses major anti-trust case over its search dominance | The National", "body": "A judge on Monday ruled that Google's search engine has been illegally exploiting its dominance to stifle competition and innovation, in a decision that could shake up the internet and hobble one of the world's best-known companies.\n\nThe highly anticipated decision by District Judge Amit Mehta comes nearly a year after the start of a trial pitting the Justice Department against Google in the country's biggest anti-trust showdown in a quarter century.\n\nAfter reviewing evidence that included testimony from top executives at Google, Microsoft and Apple during last year's 10-week trial, Mr Mehta issued his decision three months after the two sides presented their closing arguments in early May.\n\nIt represents a major setback for Google and its parent, Alphabet, which had argued that its popularity came from that fact that it was so good.\n\nGoogle's search engine processes an estimated 8.5 billion queries a day worldwide, nearly doubling its daily volume from 12 years ago, according to a recent study released by the investment firm Bond.\n\nGoogle will almost certainly appeal against the decision in a process that may land in the US Supreme Court.\n\nFor now, the decision vindicates anti-trust regulators at the Justice Department, which filed its lawsuit nearly four years ago while Donald Trump was still president.\n\nIt has been increasing its efforts to rein in Big Tech's during President Joe Biden's administration.\n\nThe case showed Google as a bully that methodically thwarted competition to protect a search engine that has become the centrepiece of a digital advertising machine, which generated nearly $240 billion in revenue last year.\n\nJustice Department lawyers said that Google's monopoly enabled it to charge advertisers high prices while enjoying the luxury of having to invest more time and money into improving the quality of its search engine - an approach that hurt consumers.\n\nGoogle responded that consumers have historically changed search engines when they become disillusioned with the results they were getting.\n\nFor instance, Yahoo - now a minor player on the internet - was the most popular search engine during the 1990s before Google.\n\nMr Mehta's conclusion that Google has been running an illegal monopoly sets up another phase to determine what types of changes or penalties should be imposed to reverse the damage done and restore a more competitive landscape.\n\nThe outcome could result in a wide-ranging order requiring Google to dismantle parts of its internet empire or stop it paying more than $20 billion annually to ensure its search engine automatically answers queries on the iPhone and other internet-connected devices.\n\nAfter the next phase, the judge "body": "Judge, Amit Mehta on Tuesday agreed with the U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ) that Google has a monopoly in \"general search services\" and the general search text ads market.\n\n\"After having carefully considered and weighed the witness testimony and evidence, the court reached the following conclusion.\n\n\"Google is a monopolist, and it has acted as one to maintain its monopoly,\" according to the court's ruling.\n\nIt has violated Section 2 of the Sherman Act.\n\nGoogle controls about 90 per cent of the online search market and 95 per cent on smartphones, said the ruling, capping a years long case.\n\nThe DOJ reportedly sued in 2020 over Google's dominance in online search, which was the first time in a generation that the U.S. government accused a major corporation of an illegal monopoly.\n\nThis landmark decision holds Google accountable, DOJ antitrust Assistant Attorney General Jonathan Kanter said this in a statement.\n\nIt said that it paves the path for innovation for generations to come and protects access to information for all Americans.\n\nKent Walker, Google's president of Global Affairs, said the company intended to appeal to Mehta's ruling.\n\nThis decision recognised that Google offered the best search engine, but concluded that we shouldn't be allowed to make it easily available, according to the statement.\n\n\"As this process continues, we will remain focused on making products that people find helpful and easy to use.\"\n\nGoogle's fate will be decided in the next phase of proceedings, which could determine potential {"uri": "8260674053", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "20:00:31", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T20:00:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T19:59:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://www.ntd.com/federal-court-rules-against-google-in-landmark-antitrust-case_1009132.html?utm_source=facebook&utm_medium=Social&utm_campaign=ntdtelevision", "title": "Federal Court Rules Against Google in Landmark Antitrust Case", "body": "The Google logo at the Google headquarters in Mountain View, Calif., on Sept. 2, 2015. (Justin Sullivan/Getty Images)\n\nIn a landmark legal decision, a federal judge has ruled that Google has violated antitrust laws by maintaining its monopoly power in the markets for general search services and general search text advertisements.\n\nThe ruling, issued on Aug. 5 by Judge Amit Mehta, concludes a lengthy legal battle initiated by the U.S. Department of Justice and a coalition of state attorneys general.\n\nThe case against Google, filed in October 2020, alleged that the tech giant engaged in anti-competitive practices by establishing exclusive agreements with browser developers, mobile device manufacturers, and wireless carriers, according to the ruling.\n\nThese agreements ensured that Google's search engine was the default option on most devices, effectively limiting consumer choice and stifling competition.\n\nThe court's findings indicate that Google is a monopolist in the relevant markets and has unlawfully used its dominant position to sustain its monopoly.\n\n\"The court has found that Plaintiffs have proven that Google has monopoly power in two relevant product markets: general search services and general search text advertising,\" the ruling stated.\n\n\"After having carefully considered and weighed the witness testimony and evidence, the court reaches the following conclusion: Google is a monopolist, and it has acted as one to maintain its monopoly. It has violated Section 2 of the Sherman Act.\"\n\nThe court determined that Google's distribution agreements were exclusive and had significant anti-competitive effects, preventing rivals from gaining market share and reducing innovation and consumer choice.\n\nDespite Google's arguments that its practices were pro-competitive and justified by the quality of its services, the court found these justifications insufficient.\n\nIt emphasized that Google's conduct allowed the company to charge \"supracompetitive prices for general search text ads,\" enabling it to earn substantial monopoly profits.\n\nThe court is expected to impose measures to restore competitive conditions in the affected markets.\n\nGoogle has not yet announced whether it will appeal the decision, but the ruling will likely prompt significant changes in how the company conducts its business in the future.\n\nThe Epoch Times has reached out to Google for comment.", "source": {"uri": "ntd.com", {"uri": "2024-08-444980949", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "20:52:44", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T20:52:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T20:43:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://ca.finance.yahoo.com/news/google-abused-power-maintain-monopoly-204312547.html", "title": "Google abused its power to maintain monopoly on search, US court rules", "body": "Google abused its power to maintain an illegal monopoly over the online search market, a US judge has ruled.\n\nJudge Amit Metha said on Monday that the company had unfairly blocked rivals by paying $26bn to ensure it was the default search engine on smartphones and web browsers.\n\n\"After having carefully considered and weighed the witness testimony and evidence, the court reaches the following conclusion: Google is a monopolist, and it has acted as one to maintain its monopoly,\" Judge Metha said in legal documents.\n\nThe verdict is a significant blow for Google and may pave the way for more competition in the market, undermining the core pillar of the company's business model.\n\nShares in Alphabet, Google's parent company, were down more than 4.5pc in the wake of the ruling, though the company was also caught up in a broader stock market sell-off.\n\nKent Walker, president of Google global affairs, said the company planned to appeal and said: \"This decision recognizes that Google offers the best search engine, but concludes that we shouldn't be allowed to make it easily available.\"\n\nThe case was bought by the US Justice Department and the decision is a victory for the Biden administration. While it was originally filed under President Donald Trump, Joe Biden has been stepping up efforts to rein in the power of Big Tech and the Google case was seen as a key test of this approach.\n\nThe ruling comes after a four-year legal battle during which the US Department of Justice argued that Google's domination of search was the result of freezing out potential rivals, rather than because it offered the best service.\n\nIt argued that billions of dollars in payments made to the likes of Apple, Samsung and others for prime placement on smartphones and web browsers violated antitrust laws.\n\n\"Most devices in the United States come preloaded exclusively with Google,\" Judge Mehta noted. \"These distribution deals have forced Google's rivals to find other ways to reach users.\"\n\nGoogle's lawyers argued during the case that this argument was \"deeply flawed\", claiming that people use its services by choice, not because they cannot find alternatives.\n\nThe legal battle marks the first US antitrust tech case since the government sued Microsoft in the 1990s over its domination of the personal computer market.\n\nMicrosoft chief executive Satya Nadella was one of the Justice Department's star witnesses this time around, saying Google's deals effectively blocked his company's Bing search engine.\n\nMr Nadella told the court: \"You get up in the morning, you brush your teeth and you search on Google. Everybody talks about the open web, but there is really the Google web.\"\n\nThe ruling is likely to set a precedent for further legal battles with other tech giants, as legislators grapple with the ways the modern internet has changed society and seek to limit its excesses.", "source": {"uri": "ca.finance.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo! {"uri": "8261247065", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "06:37:27", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T06:37:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T06:34:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://foreignaffairs.co.nz/2024/08/06/mil-evening-report-a-us-court-has-ruled-google-is-an-illegal-monopoly-and-the-internet-might-never-be-the-same/", "title": "MIL-Evening Report: A US Court has ruled Google is an illegal monopoly - and...", "body": "Source: The Conversation (Au and NZ) - By Zena Assaad, Senior Lecturer, School of Engineering, Australian National University\n\nOn Monday a US federal judge ruled Google has violated antitrust laws, saying the organisation\n\nis a monopolist, and it has acted as one to maintain its monopoly.\n\nGoogle disputes the ruling. Its president of global affairs, Kent Walker, said \"this decision recognises that Google offers the best search engine, but concludes that we shouldn't be allowed to make it easily available\".\n\nNevertheless, the landmark decision has shaken the foundation of Google's business, its search engine. For well over a decade, Google has been the dominant search engine in the market. The tech giant reportedly controls around 90% of the US online search market, leaving little room for competitors to make any claim.\n\nGoogle has been able to maintain this dominance through exclusive contracts with companies such as Apple and Samsung, which enable Google to be the default search engine on their platforms.\n\nThese monopolistic practices have allowed Google to charge high prices for search advertising. Being the default browser across many platforms, this search engine has become the easiest, quickest and most reliable resource for most people. This has reinforced the company's online advertising business, leaving little room for competitors to offer comparable services at more reasonable prices.\n\nA separate proceeding will be held to determine what penalties Google and its parent company, Alphabet, will face. However, it is likely the tech giant will be hit with both monetary penalties and enforced mitigations aimed at reducing its dominance.\n\nHistorically, fines have not been the sole method of enforcing antitrust laws as they do not demonstrate long-term impacts. This is especially true for a multi-trillion-dollar organisation such as Google.\n\nSome of the mitigations which may be imposed include the implementation of a \"choice screen\". This would allow users to pick between other available search engines, instead of having Google as the default option.\n\nThis is not the first time Google has been found guilty of breaching antitrust laws. Over the past decade it has been fined a total of \u20ac8.25 billion (A$13.6 billion) by the European Union for three separate breaches of the union's antitrust laws.\n\nAntitrust laws are enforced at domestic levels, and breaches of these laws are specific to domestic markets. This is why Google is facing these charges across two different continents.\n\nGoogle has continued to appeal the EU fines over the years. Walker has already confirmed that the company will appeal the US decision.\n\nAntitrust laws are designed to enhance competition. They exist to protect consumers by prohibiting business practices that promote unfair monopolies, suppress competition and enforce dominance or power.\n\nThe dominance that Google has held over other search engines has created a concentrated market that has prevented smaller competitors from operating equitably.\n\nThis is why Google can charge high advertising prices, because there is slim competition in terms of visibility.\n\nThe recent US ruling, alongside the EU rulings, may be the first steps towards opening the tech market up to other competitors. In turn, this may promote more equitable competition, which would be a win for consumers.\n\nCompetition fuels incentives for innovation. When there is only one option available, as often seems to be the case with search engines, this incentive is suffocated under the dominance of one monopolistic player.\n\nWhile antitrust laws are only enforced at domestic levels, hopefully the outcomes of the EU and US rulings will have flow-on effects that extend beyond these markets.\n\nDuring the trial, some concerns were raised around how Google's monopolised position as the default search engine has unfairly benefited it in the artificial intelligence (AI) race.\n\nThe default agreements and terms of conditions of the Google search engine has enabled the organisation to access enormous amounts of user search data, which can be used to train AI models. The easy access to this data may act as a gateway for Google to establish a position of dominance in AI.\n\nDismantling Google as the default search engine on platforms such as Apple and Samsung could shift Google's position in the race for AI supremacy.\n\nAs such, it may also shift the future trajectory of the entire internet.\n\nZena Assaad does not work for, consult, own shares in or receive funding from any company or organisation that would benefit from this article, and has disclosed no relevant affiliations beyond their academic appointment.", "source": {"uri": "foreignaffairs.co.nz", {"uri": "8261154147", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "05:17:07", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T05:17:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T05:16:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://www.arnnewscentre.ae/news/international/google-has-an-illegal-monopoly-on-search-us-judge-finds/", "title": "Google has an illegal monopoly on search, US judge finds", "body": "A judge has ruled that Google violated antitrust law, spending billions of dollars to create an illegal monopoly and become the world's default search engine, in the first big win for federal authorities taking on Big Tech's market dominance.\n\nThe ruling paves the way for a second trial to determine potential fixes, possibly including a breakup of Google parent Alphabet, which would change the landscape of the online advertising world that Google has dominated for years.\n\nIt is also a green light to aggressive US antitrust enforcers prosecuting Big Tech, a sector that has been under fire from across the political spectrum.\n\n\"Google is a monopolist, and it has acted as one to maintain its monopoly,\" US District Judge Amit Mehta, Washington, D.C., wrote. Google controls about 90 per cent of the online search market and 95 per cent on smartphones.\n\nThe \"remedy\" phase could be lengthy, followed by potential appeals to the US Court of Appeals, District of Columbia Circuit and the US Supreme Court. The legal wrangling could play out into next year, or even 2026.\n\nShares of Alphabet fell 4.5 per cent on Monday amid a broad decline in tech shares as the wider stock market cratered on recession fears. Google advertising was 77 per cent of Alphabet's total sales in 2023.\n\nAlphabet said it plans to appeal Mehta's ruling. \"This decision recognises that Google offers the best search engine, but {"uri": "8260730272", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "20:54:26", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T20:54:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T20:53:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://www.afr.com/world/north-america/google-loses-landmark-antitrust-case-over-search-deals-20240806-p5jzud", "title": "Google loses landmark antitrust case over search deals", "body": "\"The trial evidence firmly established that Google's monopoly power, maintained by the exclusive distribution agreements, has enabled Google to increase text ads prices without any meaningful competitive constraint,\" he wrote.\n\nAlphabet shares slipped 4.5 per cent to $US159.13 in New York. Apple, which depending on the remedy could stand to lose billions in payments Google makes to have its search engine be the default browser on iPhones, fell 5.8 per cent to $US207.14.\n\n\"This victory against Google is an historic win for the American people,\" US Attorney General Merrick Garland said in a statement.\n\nGoogle didn't respond to a request for comment.\n\nAntitrust enforcers alleged that Google has illegally maintained a monopoly over online search and related advertising. The government said Google has paid Apple, Samsung Electronics and others billions of dollars over decades for prime placement on smartphones and web browsers. This default position has allowed Google to build up the most-used search engine in the world, and fuelled more than $US300 billion in annual revenue largely generated by search ads.\n\nJudge Mehta found that Google doesn't have a monopoly in the market for general search advertising, noting that competitors like Amazon.com, Walmart and other retailers have begun to offer advertising related to searches on their own websites. But Google does have a monopoly over search text ads, which appear at the top of a search results page to draw users to websites, he said.\n\nThe judge's decision focuses solely on Google's liability, nine months after the Justice Department and a group of states held a 10-week trial in federal court. He plans to hold a separate trial on what remedy to impose at a later date.\n\nThe Justice Department hasn't yet said what changes it will seek, though it presented evidence that efforts by European regulators to require Google to offer users a choice of search engines led few to switch. The agency could demand the separation of Alphabet's search business from other products, like Android or Chrome, which would mark the biggest forced breakup of a US company since AT&T was dismantled in 1984.\n\nAntitrust enforcers separately sued Google for allegedly monopolising the technology used to buy, sell and serve display advertising online. In that case, which is set for trial in Virginia federal court next month, the government is seeking to force Google to sell off some of its advertising technology products.", "source": {"uri": Suit Over Search", "body": "In what could be a ground-breaking victory for the Justice Departments, a federal judge ruled Monday that Google's payments to make its search engine the default on smartphone web browsers violates US antitrust law.\n\nAs Bloomberg reports, Judge Amit Mehta in Washington said that the Alphabet Inc. unit's $26 billion in payments effectively blocked any other competitor from succeeding in the market\n\nThe Justice Department and states had sued Google, accusing it of illegally cementing its dominance, in part, by paying other companies, like Apple and Samsung, billions of dollars a year to have Google automatically handle search queries on their smartphones and web browsers.\n\n\"Google is a monopolist, and it has acted as one to maintain its monopoly,\" Judge Mehta said in his ruling.\n\n\"The importance and significance of this case is not lost on me, not only for Google but for the public,\" he added.\n\nHaving recovered some of the losses overnight, this new DoJ headline has smacked GOOGL shares back down near the lows of the day (down around 6%)...\n\nThe case is the first antitrust trial pitting the federal government against a US technology company in more than two decades.\n\nToday's ruling is likely to influence other government antitrust lawsuits against Google, Apple, Amazon and Meta, the owner of Facebook, Instagram {"uri": "8260669416", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "19:54:35", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T19:54:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T19:54:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://www.wired.com/story/google-search-antitrust-monopoly-ruling/", "title": "Google Search Is an Illegal Monopoly, US Judge Rules", "body": "Google is now 0 for 2 in antitrust trials. US District judge Amit Mehta ruled on Monday that Google has unlawfully maintained its dominance in search by using anticompetitive deals to keep rivals from gaining traction.\n\nThe ruling follows a weekslong trial in Mehta's Washington, DC, courtroom last year in which the US Department of Justice alleged that Google had become the world's most used search engine by paying partners such as Apple and Samsung to promote it on their devices and software. Google had attributed its success to providing the best service and argued that it faced significant competition from the likes of Microsoft and others.\n\nMetha sided with Google on some issues but rejected its overall argument that the company held no illegal monopoly whatsoever. Last year, a jury in federal court in San Francisco had ruled Google's Play app store an illegal monopolist.\n\nHow Google will have to adjust its business in light of the judgments in San Francisco and Washington are yet to be determined. Mehta will hold a separate trial to determine remedies in the search case, and a judge is mulling proposed penalties in the Play litigation. But some changes Google has made in response to antitrust scrutiny in recent years have been costly.\n\nGoogle and the Department of Justice did not immediately respond to requests for comment on Monday.\n\nThe case before Mehta traced back to the increased oversight of the tech industry under then President Donald Trump. The Justice Department sued Google in 2020 before Trump left office, and the lawsuit then became the first of several against Big Tech companies to go to trial.", "source": {"uri": "wired.com",
