{"uri": "8261734004", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "11:53:53", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T11:53:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T11:52:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5176470875740051, "url": "https://dnyuz.com/2024/08/06/how-googles-antitrust-defeat-might-transform-big-tech/", "title": "How Google's Antitrust Defeat Might Transform Big Tech", "body": "The federal court ruling that Google had abused its monopoly in online search threatens to disrupt one of the most valuable businesses in modern history, and Big Tech more broadly.\n\nExpect Google to fight back, which could drag this out for some time. Still, the decision will likely carry a lot of consequences for the internet industry.\n\nWhat happened: Judge Amit Mehta of U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia sided with the Justice Department and several states that had accused Google of illegally cementing its search dominance. In large part that was by paying billions each year to companies including Apple and Samsung to make Google the default search engine on their devices. (Apple alone received $20 billion in 2022.)\n\nThose agreements hurt competition, Mehta found, allowing Google to trample competitors. That dominance -- 94.9 percent of the general search market -- then allowed the company to inflate the prices for some search ads, giving it more money to pay Apple and others, he wrote.\n\nIt's hard to overstate the importance of search to Google's business: The operation represented more than half of the company's $74.6 billion in total revenue for the second quarter.\n\nWhat comes next? Mehta, a President Obama appointee, set a hearing for Sept. 6 to begin discussing potential remedies. The big question is whether the government will push for divestitures (a structural remedy, in antitrust parlance) or some form of operational fix.\n\nGoogle, for its part, plans to appeal.\n\nCould a Trump victory help Google? There is precedent: In 2001, the Justice Department under newly elected President George W. Bush changed course in the federal government's antitrust fight against Microsoft, pursuing a settlement with the tech giant instead of a breakup. The decision came months after a federal appeals court had overturned a lower court's order to break up Microsoft.\n\nBut the politics now are complicated. Vice President Kamala Harris's views on antitrust are unknown. And Donald Trump hasn't exactly been friendly to Google. (Remember that this case began under his presidency.) His running mate, Senator JD Vance, has supported a crackdown on Big Tech.\n\nRegardless of who wins in November, Google must also contend with the states that also had signed onto the lawsuit. They have no obligation to follow the Justice Department.\n\nWhat will this mean for Apple? The ruling threatens to alter one of Apple's most lucrative business arrangements. Would Apple look to Microsoft's Bing or someone else to power search on the iPhone?\n\nOr, as it did with maps, would Apple enter the market itself? Bloomberg notes that the company's plans to integrate ChatGPT and other chatbots with Siri could soften the ruling's blow.\n\nWill this decision bolster other fights against Big Tech? Some experts told The Times that it could help antitrust lawsuits against the likes of Amazon, Apple and Meta.\n\nBut others questioned how transformative the ruling really was. \"There's nothing new here that we are changing antitrust law,\" Doug Melamed, a professor of law at Stanford and a former Justice Department official, told DealBook.\n\nAnticipation builds for Kamala Harris's choice of running mate. The vice president, who officially claimed the Democratic presidential nomination, is expected to reveal her choice on Tuesday, capping a 16-day sprint to vet candidates amid pressure from donors and interest groups. The duo are scheduled to campaign in Philadelphia later on Tuesday.\n\nA trio of OpenAI leaders step away. John Schulman, who oversees a key safety team at the ChatGPT maker, is decamping for a major rival, Anthropic, while Greg Brockman, a close ally of Sam Altman, is taking an extended leave of absence; Peter Deng, a senior product leader, is leaving as well. The moves come amid a wave of turnovers at the high-flying A.I. start-up.\n\nThe Treasury Department is accused of juicing the economy. Republican lawmakers and the economists Nouriel Roubini and Stephen Miran argued that the department was seeking to manipulate the bond market, to boost the government's finances. Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen has pushed back against the accusation. (Scheduled for Wednesday: a closely watched auction of 10-year Treasury notes.)\n\nNvidia's C.E.O. sells roughly $500 million worth of stock this summer. Jensen Huang, who co-founded the chipmaker at the center of the artificial intelligence boom, sold a record $323 million via a prearranged transaction last month. Nvidia's stock has more than doubled in the past year, but investor concerns about whether hefty spending by tech companies on A.I. was sustainable have weighed on the sector.\n\nGlobal markets are bouncing back on Tuesday, as investors return to risky assets, including tech stocks and crypto, that have taken a pounding recently.\n\nBut Tuesday's gains haven't made up for Monday's $1 trillion wipeout. And concerns about a U.S. economic slowdown haven't gone away.\n\nHere's the latest:\n\nThe turmoil raises more questions about the Fed's next move. The futures market on Tuesday was penciling in about a full percentage point worth of Fed interest rate cuts by year's end. That would suggest at least one outsize cut of a half percentage point in one of the three remaining meetings of its rate-setting committee.\n\nTwo regional Fed presidents, Mary Daly of San Francisco and Austan Goolsbee of Chicago, said on Monday to expect cuts, but reiterated that the central bank is still watching the data closely before it acts. That chilled speculation of an emergency inter-meeting cut.\n\nThe market move may have political implications. Donald Trump, who has long fixated on market performance as a measure of economic health, sought to use Monday's sell-off to criticize the Democrats' handling of the economy. (But Fox News's Neil Cavuto noted that some of the biggest market plunges in recent years happened on his watch.)\n\nDoes the stock market actually influence elections? It's a data point worth watching, Adam Turnquist, chief technical strategist for LPL Financial, told DealBook. The S&P 500's performance during the three months before Election Day -- this year, that would mean from Monday -- has often correlated to which party wins. Here are the numbers:\n\nTurnquist likens this S&P 500 gauge to political polls. \"This is intuitive in the sense that this is what the markets are looking at,\" he said.\n\n-- Mike Moritz, the veteran venture capitalist, cautioning peers in the tech industry who have endorsed Donald Trump.\n\nElon Musk's decision to endorse, and raise money for, Donald Trump has made the billionaire a potential kingmaker in the presidential race.\n\nBut it also made him a focal point in an increasingly politically divided Silicon Valley, and is attracting more scrutiny regarding his potential influence in the election and beyond.\n\nSeveral state officials are looking into different Musk operations:\n\nBoth are reminders of Musk's reach, and his unusual outspokenness. Most tech C.E.O.s are staying politically neutral on the election -- aside from Mark Zuckerberg of Meta calling Trump's post-shooting fist pump \"one of the most badass things\" he had ever seen. That's in part because they don't want to draw fire for being seen as putting their thumbs on the political scales.\n\nSuch concerns haven't bothered Musk, even though his ownership of X -- and nearly 130 million followers -- gives him a big megaphone. He has been accused of promoting misinformation and stoking division on the platform before, including by boosting a digitally altered video of Harris.\n\nThese battles aren't only happening in the U.S. A representative for Prime Minister Keir Starmer in Britain criticized Musk for saying civil war in that country was \"inevitable\" amid an outbreak of race riots there. (British leaders and experts have blamed disinformation online for fomenting much of the violence.)\n\nMusk fought back, replying to Starmer, \"Shouldn't you be concerned about attacks on *all* communities?\" That spat comes as X faces a potentially big fine by the E.U. for failing to police disinformation on the platform.\n\nWe'd like your feedback! {"uri": "8260780802", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "21:52:11", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T21:52:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T21:49:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.501960813999176, "url": "https://www.newsweek.com/google-no-monopoly-its-widely-used-because-its-best-opinion-1934914", "title": "Google Is No Monopoly. It's Widely Used Because It's the Best | Opinion", "body": "On Monday, a federal judge ruled that Google violated antitrust law and acted illegally in order to maintain its monopoly in online searches. There's just one glaring problem: Google isn't a monopoly -- not even close.\n\nIn fact, there are over 30 other search engines in the world that are dedicated solely to search functionality, including Yahoo!, Bing, and Duck, Duck, Go. Additionally, websites like Amazon, TikTok, and Pinterest have placed increasing competition on Google in recent years as consumers have begun using these websites for all manner of searches, from products to DIY tutorials to medical advice.\n\nThe ruling marks the first antitrust decision in the modern tech era, and its implications could be far-reaching for our legal framework, our economy, and consumers.\n\nIn the case, the U.S. Justice Department argued that Google acted in an anti-competitive nature by securing agreements with companies like Apple and Samsung that ensured their browsers were auto-downloaded to their devices. They also argued that over 90 percent of web searches are conducted on Google's search engines.\n\nIn reality, consumers have always had the ability to download their preferred search engines to their phones or delete the apps that come pre-programed to their devices. In securing these deals, Google did not block other search engines from being accessible, nor did they force anyone to use their products. They just made them more convenient to access, which is a perfectly reasonable step for a business to take.\n\nGoogle disputes the claim that 90 percent of web searches are done on their engines. But even if they were, the company's popularity indicates one thing and one thing alone: Consumers like Google products and want to use them. The company has in no way harmed consumers, defrauded anyone, or even acted in an unfair way toward their competition. Being smart enough to negotiate such deals simply makes Google better at its job.\n\nFor decades, antitrust law has hinged on conservative legal jurisprudence known as the consumer welfare standard. It's a very good legal precedent that defenders of capitalism and limited government worked hard to enshrine into law following a disastrous period of aggressive antitrust pursuits by the U.S. government in the 20th century that crippled our economy.\n\nThe consumer welfare standard says that in order to have breached antitrust law, three conditions must be met. The company in question must be a monopoly (an extreme rarity), it must have used its monopoly power, and it must have done so in a way that harms consumers. No serious person could argue Google crossed any one of these lines, much less all three.\n\nYet the case against Google is one of many the FTC has launched in the past few years under the aggressive and anti-capitalist reign of chair Lina Khan. Khan's agenda, which has been supported by the Biden administration and populists in both parties such as Senators Elizabeth Warren and Josh Hawley, seeks to overturn the consumer welfare standard and return our antitrust landscape to that of the mid-1900s. According to these types, a business being big means it is bad, rather than the obvious truth that a business becoming big merely means it is popular and offers a product or service consumers quite like. And their solution to \"bad\" big business is always the same: The government needs more control of the economy and private companies in order to \"protect\" consumers from these evil corporations.\n\nBut antitrust enthusiasts always tip their hand, revealing antitrust as a Trojan horse: The same people who openly hate capitalism are always claiming we need more of it in order to \"save\" capitalism. But capitalism doesn't need saving by the government, certainly not from monopolies. In a true free market, system failures come naturally and swiftly as better competitors emerge, products become outdated, or bloat takes over. Monopolies rarely exist at all and never for long under capitalism.\n\nDespite the fact that our economy is more mixed than free market these days, supporters of antitrust are still hard-pressed to identify actual monopolies in existence. In fact, the only long-standing monopolies that come to mind are government created or backed (think the public school system or certificate of need laws that block the infusion of new healthcare suppliers).\n\nGoogle lost its lawsuit, but the real losers are the American people. Not only could this decision prohibit Google from offering quality products millions of us enjoy, it also means it will be even harder for the next competitor to get their foot in the door.\n\nHannah Cox is the President and Co-Founder of BASEDPolitics. She works with Netchoice, a free-market trade organization for the tech industry.", "source": {"uri": "newsweek.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Newsweek"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": It's not quite an ad blocker, but it could be even more useful for sites with video embeds, moving elements and other chaos. Press the Page Menu button in the Search field (where the Reader and Viewer buttons are) and tap Hide Distracting Items to select which parts of a page you want to filter out. {"uri": "2024-08-444932361", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "19:40:32", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T19:40:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T19:35:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4980392158031464, "url": "https://www.pocket-lint.com/google-is-a-monopoly/", "title": "A bombshell court ruling says Google is a search monopoly", "body": "Key Takeaways\n\nGoogle's monopoly on web searches has been ruled illegal by a US federal court. The case, dating back to 2020, involved testimonies from tech giants like Google CEO Sundar Pichai and Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella. A core issue is Google paying to maintain browser dominance.\n\nGoogle is operating an illegal monopoly over the web search industry, according to a Monday ruling by judge Amit P. Mehta of the US District Court for the District of Columbia. The decision, reported by the New York Times, puts an end to a years-long case brought by the Department of Justice and state governments, accusing it of skewing the market through unfair practices. A particular focus was Google's practice of paying companies like Apple, Mozilla, and Samsung to make its search tool the default in web browsers -- making it tough for competitors like DuckDuckGo or Bing to gain traction.\n\nRelated\n\nI tried 7 Chrome alternatives to see which browser is the best\n\nIf you feel like Chrome is a vampire draining data from your computer, there are alternative browsers. I tried these 7 to see what was the best.\n\nThe case dates back to 2020, and peaked with a 10-week trial in 2023, including testimonies by Google CEO Sundar Pichai and Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella. Nadella complained that Google's relationship with Apple is \"oligopolistic,\" and that Google could easily become dominant in the world of AI with Gemini, even though Microsoft has enjoyed a lead thanks to its partnership with ChatGPT creator OpenAI.\n\nThis story is developing. Landmark antitrust ruling  --  and new Northeastern research  --  show that it is", "body": "In what could be the most significant ruling in antitrust law of the modern era, a federal judge ruled Monday that Google illegally used its monopoly in online search to squash competition and hurt innovation.\n\nDuring the trial, the Justice Department argued that Google's dominance of the search market hurt the market at large.\n\nGoogle pursued a different tactic, arguing that it doesn't just compete with other search engines like Bing, it competes with anything that has a search function, from Amazon to Travelocity. {"uri": "2024-08-445160217", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "02:56:40", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T02:56:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T00:14:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4705882370471954, "url": "https://ca.finance.yahoo.com/news/forget-apple-biggest-loser-google-001421247.html", "title": "Forget Apple, the biggest loser in the Google search ruling could be Mozilla and its Firefox web browser", "body": "\"Google is a monopolist, and it has acted as one to maintain its monopoly.\"\n\nWith those words from United States District judge Amit Mehta on Monday, Google suffered a historic antitrust case loss at the hands of the U.S. Department of Justice. Mehta, the judge presiding over the trial, ruled that the tech giant has illegally maintained a monopoly through the billions of dollars in annual payments it makes to partners to secure the default search engine position on popular web browsers and mobile phones. With those dominant positions locked in, the argument goes, other competitors in the search and search advertising businesses have no chance of competing effectively.\n\nThe ruling immediately prompted speculation about the impact to Apple, which receives as much as $20 billion from Google every year in exchange for putting the search engine front-and-center on its iPhones via the Apple Safari web browser.\n\nBut while Apple would certainly take a big hit if the ruling is upheld, Apple is a large, diversified company with many sources of revenue. That's not the case for another partner of Google's located in the fallout zone of Monday's ruling: Mozilla, the non-profit tech org that makes the Firefox web browser.\n\nWhen users of Firefox type a search term into the browser, the query is automatically routed to Google's search engine. The arrangement is vital for Mozilla. According to the Mozilla Foundation's 2021-2022 financial statement, which is the most recent published, $510 million out of its $593 million in revenue came courtesy of Google's search payments.\n\nIf that number $510 million were to go away entirely, Mozilla will have a serious problem on its hands.\n\nMozilla is putting on a brave face for now, and not directly addressing the existential threat that the ruling appears to pose.\n\n\"Mozilla has always championed competition and choice online, particularly in search,\" a spokesperson said in a statement to Fortune on Monday. \"We're closely reviewing the court's decision, considering its potential impact on Mozilla and how we can positively influence the next steps...Firefox continues to offer a range of search options, and we remain committed to serving our users' preferences while fostering a competitive market.\"\n\nFor Mozilla, which first rose to prominence in the late 1990s as a community-driven project to challenge Microsoft's stranglehold on the web browser market via Internet Explorer, Monday's ruling is the latest setback in a quest to find relevance in a market dominated by Big Tech companies. Mozilla laid off about 60 staffers earlier this year and saw its CEO step down.\n\nYou can be sure that critics of the judge's ruling will highlight the potentially devastating impact on Mozilla to make the case that the antitrust ruling will have unintended consequences on smaller tech industry players. Others might argue that Mozilla hasn't done enough with those spoils to differentiate its Firefox browser, or that it could cut a deal with another search engine like Bing if its Google deal goes away completely.\n\nEither way, Google will appeal the suit so a long battle may ensue. And there's another big domino to fall: the judge will rule on the remedy or remedies -- essentially, the business-model penalties -- that Google will face.\n\nEvercore ISI research analyst Mark Mahoney tacked them off in a research note on Monday evening:\n\n\"The exact remedy is key, and so far, it's hard to pick a winning horse among a range of outcomes,\" he wrote. \" i) forbidding payment from Google altogether, ii) a cap on the amount of distribution agreement fees, iii) pushing Apple to implement a \"choice screen\", or iv) something else? In any case, we expect at least another 6 months to a year before we would know the exact remedies (or longer if the judge decides to stay the remedies phase pending GOOG's appeal).\"", "source": {"uri": "ca.finance.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo! {"uri": "8260800824", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "22:12:51", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T22:12:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T22:12:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4666666686534882, "url": "https://www.democraticunderground.com/111698548", "title": "Federal Judge: Google Is a Monopoly", "body": "Applause, applause.\n\nToday on TAP: The Justice Department just won its case against Google.\n\nBY DAVID DAYEN, LUKE GOLDSTEIN AUGUST 5, 2024\n\nJudge Amit Mehta of the D.C. District Court ruled today that Google violated the Sherman Act by buying its way onto browsers and devices and making it nearly impossible to avoid its search engine.\n\n\"Google is a monopolist, and it has acted as one to maintain its monopoly,\" Judge Mehta wrote in his 286-page ruling. \"It has violated Section 2 of the Sherman Act.\"\n\nThe decision in the first major monopolization case in 25 years is a big win for the Justice Department's Antitrust Division, and reinforces the aggressive antitrust policies of the Biden administration. {"uri": "2024-08-445203201", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "04:13:47", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T04:13:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T04:03:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4549019634723663, "url": "https://live-adexchanger.pantheonsite.io/daily-news-roundup/tuesday-06082024/", "title": "Judge Rules Google Search Is A Monopoly; NVIDIA's Unreleased AI Scrapes The Web | AdExchanger", "body": "US District Court Judge Amit Mehta ruled on Monday that Google has been operating an illegal monopoly over online search for years, Politico reports.\n\nIn a 286-page ruling, Mehta says Google is a monopolist in part because it maintains 90% of the search market through exclusive search provider agreements with mobile carriers and device makers, including Apple, Samsung and Verizon. Google paid billions per year to keep these agreements in effect.\n\nGoogle also used its dominance of the search advertising market to fend off challenges from Microsoft, one of its chief competitors, Mehta ruled. However, he stopped short of saying Google has a monopoly over search advertising.\n\nIt remains unclear what methods the government will pursue to rectify Google's search monopoly. That will require separate legal proceedings. But Assistant Attorney General for Antitrust Jonathan Kanter has voiced support for \"structural remedies\" that could include breaking off parts of Google's business.\n\nGoogle plans to appeal the ruling.\n\nBut the decision will no doubt bolster related efforts to crack down on Big Tech monopolies, since it proves existing antitrust law applies in the internet era. Next up is another Google trial centering on its programmatic ad tech, which is set to begin in September. The US also has pending antitrust cases against Apple, Meta and Amazon.\n\nScrape, Baby, Scrape\n\nInternal documents leaked to 404 Media reveal that Nvidia has been scraping video content from YouTube, Netflix and other digital sources to train its AI.\n\nDescribed as \"a video data factory that can yield a human lifetime visual experience worth of training data per day\" by an Nvidia higher-up, the \"Cosmos\" project was intended as a foundational AI model for several products, including even self-driving car systems.\n\nObviously this reopens previous ethical and legal arguments about downloading and using copyrighted content in AI training data sets (YouTube calls this type of scraping a \"clear violation\" of its terms of use), but it also begs the question: Can we trust AI companies when they say their products are compliant with copyright laws?\n\nAs this newsletter previously covered, many advertising agencies are still hesitant to use AI tools without first confirming that their own data will not be used as a training source. More negative press like this won't exactly inspire confidence in these tools going forward - to say nothing of the many lawsuits now being filed against AI companies, Nvidia included.\n\nDitto\n\nWarner Bros. Discovery's flagship service Max just launched a new homepage personalization feature for all US accounts. WBD started rolling it out gradually in December - and it's awfully similar to the content recommendation setup on Netflix, The Verge reports.\n\nBased on viewing history and consumption patterns, Max now recommends titles in content rows that take over the entire homepage, not just part of it. Max also suppresses titles it doesn't think a subscriber would be interested in.\n\nHomepage personalization is one tactic streamers are using to increase time spent on their apps, which can raise ad revenue. But another popular strategy for streamers like Max is copying Netflix, which is steadily growing both ad-supported subscribers and ad revenue.\n\nShortly after Netflix touted all the paid accounts it gained from banning password sharing, for example, Max (and Disney+) announced plans to do the same. And going forward, WBD plans to include more features on Max that encourage user engagement, such as buttons viewers can use to rank the shows they \"like\" or \"love\" - which Netflix has been doing for at least two years.\n\nBut Wait, There's More!\n\nAri Paparo offers a history lesson on how Google built an ads business that's drawing antitrust scrutiny. [LinkedIn]\n\nThe ad job market in New York City is booming - but is that hurting other cities? [Ad Age]\n\nOlympics ads just aren't hitting like they used to. [The Drum]\n\nThe Olympics is increasingly relying on advertising - not media rights - to pay the bills. [Digiday]\n\nWhat marketers need to know about principal media buying. [WSJ]\n\nPetitioners in Israel drop a class-action lawsuit accusing Bright Data of scraping kids' data from social media. {"uri": "8261790422", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "12:28:35", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T12:28:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T12:27:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4509803950786591, "url": "https://www.androidheadlines.com/2024/08/android-headlines-ceo-weighs-in-on-googles-antitrust-trial-verdict.html", "title": "Android Headlines CEO weighs in on Google's antitrust trial verdict", "body": "As many of you know by now, the DOJ won a trial against Google. That news was shared yesterday, as Google has been found guilty of antitrust practices in both search and ads businesses. Google already issued its statement regarding the antitrust trial verdict, and Android Headlines CEO wanted to weigh in as well.\n\nHe felt compelled to share his statement too, as Google's practices have affected Android Headlines too, quite a bit. You can read his statement in its entirety below.\n\n\"As a long-time participant in the digital ecosystem and search industry, I feel it's important to share my perspective on the recent antitrust ruling against Google. While we once admired Google's innovative spirit, particularly during the early days of Android, their dominance in search has created significant challenges for small and medium-sized businesses.\n\nGoogle's frequent algorithm changes and core updates have made it increasingly difficult for smaller companies to compete with large corporations in search results. This constant shifting of goalposts has turned SEO into a resource-intensive game, where only those with substantial means can truly compete. As a result, many small businesses find themselves at a severe disadvantage, unable to afford the teams of experts needed to keep pace with these changes.\n\nThe consequences of this imbalance are far-reaching and very real. Businesses may fail, jobs may be lost, and families may face financial hardship - all because of changes in search algorithms that favor larger, more resourced entities. This power dynamic has effectively transformed the internet into what some might call a \"Googlenet,\" where one company wields enormous influence over online visibility and, by extension, business success.\n\nWe believe this ruling is a crucial step toward creating a more equitable digital landscape. It's imperative that regulations be implemented to prevent any single entity from having such disproportionate control over the online ecosystem. The goal should be to foster fair competition and ensure that businesses of all sizes have a reasonable opportunity to be discovered online.\n\nWhile we acknowledge that Google has contributed significantly to the development of the Internet, we hope this decision will lead to positive changes in the search industry. These changes should benefit not only businesses but also consumers, by promoting diversity in search results and encouraging innovation across the digital space.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8261852109", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "13:06:59", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T13:06:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T13:06:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4470588266849518, "url": "https://macdailynews.com/2024/08/06/in-2022-alone-google-paid-apple-20-billion-to-cement-its-illegal-monopoly/", "title": "In 2022 alone, Google paid Apple $20 billion to cement its illegal monopoly", "body": "Alphabet subsidiary Google is \"a monopolist, and has acted as one to maintain its monopoly\" in violation of Section 2 of the Sherman Act, Judge Amit Mehta of the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia ruled on Monday, August 5th.\n\nJonathan Guilford for Reuters:\n\n\u200e\n\nGoogle now shares an ignominy with Microsoft. Judged by the same legal yardstick, Alphabet's web search colossus is a monopolist just as the software developer was deemed to be in 2001. It might also suffer a similar fate.\n\nRegardless of the remedies, which will be determined later, the victory is a significant one for Jonathan Kanter, the U.S. Department of Justice antitrust chief, and his counterpart at the Federal Trade Commission, Lina Khan. Both have filed a panoply of lawsuits against tech giants, and the findings in this case will be an important signal to courts presiding over the others, including another one against Google's ad-tech business.\n\nMehta's opinion also finesses the uncomfortable finding that Google is the \"highest quality search engine.\" Resources play a part. Google estimated that Apple would need to spend $20 billion to build a similar product and billions more to operate it. The primary concern, however, is establishing ubiquity. In 2022, Google paid about $20 billion to be the default option for iPhone buyers, according to the ruling.\n\nSupport MacDailyNews at no extra cost to you by using this link to shop at Amazon.\n\n\u200e\n\nMacDailyNews Take: This is a decade or so too late, but at least it's finally happening!\n\nAs regular readers know, we've been talking about this issue for years, as ad revenue dwindled - yet Alphabet/Google magically got richer. We've all lost many great sites over recent years as the Google-dominated broken ad-supported model failed. This is the very reason why there are too many ads on the site (cluttered is better than dead).\n\nCandidly, it may be too late for us (but, for now, we're still trying to survive). This will take many years to be rectified and for the once-vibrant digital advertising model to begin working again for publishers, if it ever happens. If you can contribute a couple buck monthly help keep our very independent Apple-focused blog afloat, you can do so here. Thank you in advance!\n\nEven as we attempt to move away from the ad-supported model, we back whatever remedy or remedies will introduce competition back into the online advertising business, which is broken, in part, because far too much power is concentrated with Google/Facebook. This situation is exactly why antitrust laws exist. -- MacDailyNews, February 2, 2021\n\nImagine if your livelihood depended on one company that had not only monopolized web search (and, thereby, basically controlled how new customers find you), but also controlled the bulk of online advertising dollars which funded your business and which they could pull, simply threaten to pull, or reduce rates at any time? Now also imagine if you believe this monopolist basically stole the product of another company that is the very subject of your business? How much would you criticize the monopolist thief's business practices?\n\nYou might guess that it would be a tough road to walk. (We're only imagining, of course!)\n\nThat would be a good example of why monopolies are bad for everyone...\n\nIn the meantime, stop using Google search and Google products wherever possible. Monopolies are bad for everyone. -- MacDailyNews, July 14, 2016\n\nIf you haven't already, give DuckDuckGo a try! https://duckduckgo.com\n\nWith this unprecedented power, platforms have the ability to redirect into their pockets the advertising dollars that once went to newspapers and magazines. No one company should have the power to pick and choose which content reaches consumers and which doesn't. -- MacDailyNews, November 9, 2017\n\nWe'd like to see real competition in the online search and advertising markets restored someday. -- MacDailyNews, March 20, 2019\n\n\u200e\n\nPlease help support MacDailyNews. ex\u00adec\u00adu\u00adtives at Google, Mi\u00adcrosoft and Ap\u00adple dur\u00ading last year's 10-week tri\u00adal, Mehta is\u00adsued his po\u00adten\u00adtial\u00adly mar\u00adket-shift\u00ading de\u00adci\u00adsion three months af\u00adter the two sides pre\u00adsent\u00aded their clos\u00ading ar\u00adgu\u00adments in ear\u00adly May.\n\n\"Af\u00adter hav\u00ading care\u00adful\u00adly con\u00adsid\u00adered and weighed the wit\u00adness tes\u00adti\u00admo\u00adny and ev\u00adi\u00addence, the court reach\u00ades the fol\u00adlow\u00ading con\u00adclu\u00adsion: Google is a mo\u00adnop\u00ado\u00adlist, and it has act\u00aded as one to main\u00adtain its mo\u00adnop\u00adoly,\" Mehta wrote in his 277-page rul\u00ading. He said Google's dom\u00adi\u00adnance in the search mar\u00adket is ev\u00adi\u00addence of its mo\u00adnop\u00adoly.\n\nGoogle \"en\u00adjoys an 89.2% share of the mar\u00adket for gen\u00ader\u00adal search ser\u00advices, which in\u00adcreas\u00ades to 94.9% on mo\u00adbile de\u00advices,\" the rul\u00ading said.\n\nIt rep\u00adre\u00adsents a ma\u00adjor set\u00adback for Google and its par\u00adent, Al\u00adpha\u00adbet Inc., which had stead\u00adfast\u00adly ar\u00adgued that its pop\u00adu\u00adlar\u00adi\u00adty stemmed from con\u00adsumers' over\u00adwhelm\u00ading de\u00adsire to use a search en\u00adgine so good at what it does that it has be\u00adcome syn\u00adony\u00admous with look\u00ading things up on\u00adline. Google's search en\u00adgine cur\u00adrent\u00adly process\u00ades an es\u00adti\u00admat\u00aded 8.5 bil\u00adlion queries per day world\u00adwide, near\u00adly dou\u00adbling its dai\u00adly vol\u00adume from 12 years ago, ac\u00adcord\u00ading to a re\u00adcent study re\u00adleased by the in\u00advest\u00adment firm BOND.\n\nKent Walk\u00ader, Google's pres\u00adi\u00addent of glob\u00adal af\u00adfairs, said the com\u00adpa\u00adny in\u00adtends to ap\u00adpeal Mehta's find\u00adings: \"This de\u00adci\u00adsion rec\u00adog\u00adnizes that Google of\u00adfers the best search en\u00adgine, but con\u00adcludes that we shouldn't be al\u00adlowed to make it eas\u00adi\u00adly avail\u00adable.\"\n\nFor now, the de\u00adci\u00adsion vin\u00addi\u00adcates an\u00adtitrust reg\u00adu\u00adla\u00adtors at the Jus\u00adtice De\u00adpart\u00adment, which filed its law\u00adsuit near\u00adly four years ago while Don\u00adald Trump was still pres\u00adi\u00addent and has been es\u00adca\u00adlat\u00ading it ef\u00adforts to rein in Big Tech's pow\u00ader dur\u00ading Pres\u00adi\u00addent Joe Biden's ad\u00admin\u00adis\u00adtra\u00adtion.\n\n\"This vic\u00adto\u00adry against Google is an his\u00adtoric win for the Amer\u00adi\u00adcan peo\u00adple,\" said At\u00adtor\u00adney Gen\u00ader\u00adal Mer\u00adrick Gar\u00adland. \"No com\u00adpa\u00adny -- no mat\u00adter how large or in\u00adflu\u00aden\u00adtial -- is above the law. The Jus\u00adtice De\u00adpart\u00adment will con\u00adtin\u00adue to vig\u00ador\u00adous\u00adly en\u00adforce our an\u00adtitrust laws.\"\n\nThe case de\u00adpict\u00aded Google as a tech\u00adno\u00adlog\u00adi\u00adcal bul\u00adly that me\u00adthod\u00adi\u00adcal\u00adly has thwart\u00aded com\u00adpe\u00adti\u00adtion to pro\u00adtect a search en\u00adgine that has be\u00adcome the cen\u00adter\u00adpiece of a dig\u00adi\u00adtal ad\u00adver\u00adtis\u00ading ma\u00adchine that gen\u00ader\u00adat\u00aded near\u00adly $240 bil\u00adlion in rev\u00adenue last year. Jus\u00adtice De\u00adpart\u00adment lawyers ar\u00adgued that Google's mo\u00adnop\u00adoly en\u00adabled it to charge ad\u00adver\u00adtis\u00aders ar\u00adti\u00adfi\u00adcial\u00adly high prices while al\u00adso en\u00adjoy\u00ading the lux\u00adu\u00adry of not hav\u00ading to in\u00advest more time and mon\u00adey in\u00adto im\u00adprov\u00ading the qual\u00adi\u00adty of its search en\u00adgine -- a lax ap\u00adproach that hurt con\u00adsumers.\n\nMehta's rul\u00ading fo\u00adcused on the bil\u00adlions of dol\u00adlars Google spends every year to in\u00adstall its search en\u00adgine as the de\u00adfault op\u00adtion on new cell\u00adphones and tech gad\u00adgets. In 2021 alone, Google spent more than $26 bil\u00adlion to lock in those de\u00adfault agree\u00adments, Mehta said in his rul\u00ading.\n\nGoogle ridiculed those al\u00adle\u00adga\u00adtions, not\u00ading that con\u00adsumers have his\u00adtor\u00adi\u00adcal\u00adly changed search en\u00adgines when they be\u00adcome dis\u00adil\u00adlu\u00adsioned with the re\u00adsults they were get\u00adting. For in\u00adstance, Ya\u00adhoo was the most pop\u00adu\u00adlar search en\u00adgine dur\u00ading the 1990s be\u00adfore Google came along.\n\nMehta said the ev\u00adi\u00addence at tri\u00adal showed the im\u00adpor\u00adtance of the de\u00adfault set\u00adtings. He not\u00aded that Mi\u00adcrosoft's Bing search en\u00adgine has 80% share of the search mar\u00adket on the Mi\u00adcrosoft Edge brows\u00ader. The judge said that shows oth\u00ader search en\u00adgines can be suc\u00adcess\u00adful if Google is not locked in as the pre\u00adde\u00adter\u00admined de\u00adfault op\u00adtion.\n\nStill, Mehta cred\u00adit\u00aded the qual\u00adi\u00adty of Google's prod\u00aduct as an im\u00adpor\u00adtant part of its dom\u00adi\u00adnance, as well, say\u00ading flat\u00adly that \"Google is wide\u00adly rec\u00adog\u00adnized as the best (gen\u00ader\u00adal search en\u00adgine) avail\u00adable in the Unit\u00aded States.\"\n\nThe Con\u00adsumer Choice Cen\u00adter, a lob\u00adby\u00ading group that has fought oth\u00ader at\u00adtempts to rein in busi\u00adness\u00ades, de\u00adcried Mehta's de\u00adci\u00adsion as a step in the wrong di\u00adrec\u00adtion. \"The Unit\u00aded States is drift\u00ading to\u00adward the an\u00adti-tech pos\u00adture of the Eu\u00adro\u00adpean Union, a part of the world that makes al\u00admost noth\u00ading and pe\u00adnal\u00adizes suc\u00adcess\u00adful Amer\u00adi\u00adcan com\u00adpa\u00adnies for their pop\u00adu\u00adlar\u00adi\u00adty,\" said Yael Os\u00adsows\u00adki, the cen\u00adter's deputy di\u00adrec\u00adtor.\n\nMehta's con\u00adclu\u00adsion that Google has been run\u00adning an il\u00adle\u00adgal mo\u00adnop\u00adoly sets up an\u00adoth\u00ader le\u00adgal phase to de\u00adter\u00admine what sorts of changes or penal\u00adties should be im\u00adposed to re\u00adverse the dam\u00adage done and re\u00adstore a more com\u00adpet\u00adi\u00adtive land\u00adscape.\n\nThe po\u00adten\u00adtial out\u00adcome could re\u00adsult in a wide-rang\u00ading or\u00adder re\u00adquir\u00ading Google to dis\u00adman\u00adtle some of the pil\u00adlars of its in\u00adter\u00adnet em\u00adpire or pre\u00advent it from pay\u00ading to en\u00adsure its search en\u00adgine au\u00adto\u00admat\u00adi\u00adcal\u00adly an\u00adswers queries on the iPhone and oth\u00ader de\u00advices. Or, the judge could con\u00adclude on\u00adly mod\u00adest changes are re\u00adquired to lev\u00adel the play\u00ading field.\n\n\"Google's loss in its search an\u00adtitrust tri\u00adal could be a huge deal -- de\u00adpend\u00ading on the rem\u00ade\u00addy,\" said Emar\u00adketer se\u00adnior an\u00ada\u00adlyst Eve\u00adlyn Mitchell-Wolf. \"A forced di\u00advesti\u00adture of the search busi\u00adness would sev\u00ader Al\u00adpha\u00adbet from its largest source of rev\u00adenue. But even los\u00ading its ca\u00adpac\u00adi\u00adty to strike ex\u00adclu\u00adsive de\u00adfault agree\u00adments could be detri\u00admen\u00adtal for Google. Its ubiq\u00adui\u00adty is its biggest strength, es\u00adpe\u00adcial\u00adly as com\u00adpe\u00adti\u00adtion heats up among AI-pow\u00adered search al\u00adter\u00adna\u00adtives.\"\n\nRe\u00adgard\u00adless she added, a drawn-out ap\u00adpeals process will de\u00adlay any im\u00adme\u00addi\u00adate ef\u00adfects for both con\u00adsumers and ad\u00adver\u00adtis\u00aders.\n\nLee Hep\u00adn\u00ader, se\u00adnior le\u00adgal coun\u00adsel for the Amer\u00adi\u00adcan Eco\u00adnom\u00adic Lib\u00ader\u00adties Project, be\u00adlieves the tenor of Mehta's rul\u00ading makes it like\u00adly the judge will de\u00adcide to pro\u00adhib\u00adit Google from mak\u00ading de\u00adfault search deals and may even look at sep\u00ada\u00adrat\u00ading some of its dif\u00adfer\u00adent lines of busi\u00adness.\n\nThe ap\u00adpeals process could take as long as five years, pre\u00addict\u00aded George Hay, a law pro\u00adfes\u00adsor at Cor\u00adnell Uni\u00adver\u00adsi\u00adty who was the chief econ\u00ado\u00admist for the Jus\u00adtice De\u00adpart\u00adment's an\u00adtitrust di\u00advi\u00adsion for most of the 1970s. That lengthy process will en\u00adable Google to fend off the like\u00adli\u00adhood of Mehta ban\u00adning de\u00adfault search agree\u00adments, Hay said, but it prob\u00ada\u00adbly won't shield the com\u00adpa\u00adny from class-ac\u00adtion law\u00adsuits cit\u00ading the judge's find\u00adings that ad\u00adver\u00adtis\u00aders were gouged with mo\u00adnop\u00ado\u00adlis\u00adtic pric\u00ading.\n\nIf there is a sig\u00adnif\u00adi\u00adcant shake\u00adup, it could turn out to be a coup for Mi\u00adcrosoft, whose own pow\u00ader was un\u00adder\u00admined dur\u00ading the late 1990s when the Jus\u00adtice De\u00adpart\u00adment tar\u00adget\u00aded the soft\u00adware mak\u00ader in an an\u00adtitrust law\u00adsuit ac\u00adcus\u00ading it of abus\u00ading the dom\u00adi\u00adnance of its Win\u00addows op\u00ader\u00adat\u00ading sys\u00adtem on per\u00adson\u00adal com\u00adput\u00aders to lock out com\u00adpe\u00adti\u00adtion.\n\nThat Mi\u00adcrosoft case mir\u00adrored the one brought against Google in sev\u00ader\u00adal ways and now the re\u00adsult could al\u00adso echo sim\u00adi\u00adlar\u00adly. Just as Mi\u00adcrosoft's bruis\u00ading an\u00adtitrust bat\u00adtle cre\u00adat\u00aded dis\u00adtrac\u00adtions and ob\u00adsta\u00adcles that opened up more op\u00adpor\u00adtu\u00adni\u00adties for Google af\u00adter its 1998 in\u00adcep\u00adtion, the de\u00adci\u00adsion against Google could be a boon for Mi\u00adcrosoft, which al\u00adready has a mar\u00adket val\u00adue of more than $3 tril\u00adlion. At one time, Al\u00adpha\u00adbet was worth more than Mi\u00adcrosoft, but now trails its ri\u00adval with a mar\u00adket val\u00adue of about $2 tril\u00adlion.\n\nIf Mehta de\u00adcides to lim\u00adit or ban Google's de\u00adfault search deals, it could squeeze Ap\u00adple's prof\u00adits, too. Al\u00adthough parts of his de\u00adci\u00adsion were redact\u00aded to pro\u00adtect con\u00adfi\u00adden\u00adtial busi\u00adness in\u00adfor\u00adma\u00adtion, Mehta not\u00aded that Google paid Ap\u00adple an es\u00adti\u00admat\u00aded $20 bil\u00adlion in 2022, dou\u00adbling from 2020. The judge al\u00adso not\u00aded Ap\u00adple has pe\u00adri\u00adod\u00adi\u00adcal\u00adly con\u00adsid\u00adered build\u00ading its own search tech\u00adnol\u00ado\u00adgy, but backed off that af\u00adter a 2018 analy\u00adsis es\u00adti\u00admat\u00aded the com\u00adpa\u00adny would lose more than $12 bil\u00adlion in rev\u00adenue dur\u00ading the first five years af\u00adter a break-up with Google.\n\nGoogle's pay\u00adments have helped Ap\u00adple's steadi\u00adly grow\u00ading ser\u00advices di\u00advi\u00adsion, which gen\u00ader\u00adat\u00aded $85 bil\u00adlion in rev\u00adenue dur\u00ading the com\u00adpa\u00adny's last fis\u00adcal year. Ap\u00adple didn't im\u00adme\u00addi\u00adate\u00adly re\u00adspond to a re\u00adquest for com\u00adment.\n\nThe Jus\u00adtice De\u00adpart\u00adment's an\u00adtitrust di\u00advi\u00adsion has re\u00adcent\u00adly tak\u00aden on some of the biggest com\u00adpa\u00adnies in the world. It sued Ap\u00adple in March and in May an\u00adnounced a sweep\u00ading law\u00adsuit against Tick\u00adet\u00admas\u00adter and its own\u00ader, Live Na\u00adtion En\u00adter\u00adtain\u00adment. An\u00adtitrust en\u00adforcers have al\u00adso opened in\u00adves\u00adti\u00adga\u00adtions in\u00adto the roles Mi\u00adcrosoft, Nvidia and Ope\u00adnAI have played in the ar\u00adti\u00adfi\u00adcial in\u00adtel\u00adli\u00adgence boom.\n\nThe Biden ad\u00admin\u00adis\u00adtra\u00adtion has won some big cas\u00ades, in\u00adclud\u00ading block\u00ading merg\u00aders of some of the world's biggest pub\u00adlish\u00aders as well as Jet\u00adBlue Air\u00adways and Spir\u00adit Air\u00adlines. It's al\u00adso had some no\u00adtable set\u00adbacks, in\u00adclud\u00ading in the sug\u00adar and health\u00adcare in\u00addus\u00adtries.\n\nGoogle faces sev\u00ader\u00adal oth\u00ader le\u00adgal threats both in the U.S. and abroad. In Sep\u00adtem\u00adber, a fed\u00ader\u00adal tri\u00adal is sched\u00aduled to be\u00adgin in Vir\u00adginia over the Jus\u00adtice De\u00adpart\u00adment's al\u00adle\u00adga\u00adtions that Google's ad\u00adver\u00adtis\u00ading tech\u00adnol\u00ado\u00adgy con\u00adsti\u00adtutes an il\u00adle\u00adgal mo\u00adnop\u00adoly. -- WASH\u00adING\u00adTON (AP)\n\n_______", "source": {"uri": This situation is exactly why antitrust laws exist. - MacDailyNews, February 2, 2021\n\nGoogle is an online advertising monopoly masquerading as a search engine. Effective antitrust action against Google that restores competition into the the online search and advertising markets would be very welcome (while we're still here, please)!\n\nThe unfortunately ubiquitous search engine is a mechanism for tracking users in order to deliver targeted advertising to them.\n\nIf you haven't already, give DuckDuckGo a try today (https://duckduckgo.com) or even Bing. Anything to help restore at least some competition to online search. - MacDailyNews, March 17, 2021\n\nWe'd like to see real competition in the online search and advertising markets restored someday. -- MacDailyNews, March 20, 2019\n\nWith this unprecedented power, platforms have the ability to redirect into their pockets the advertising dollars that once went to newspapers and magazines. No one company should have the power to pick and choose which content reaches consumers and which doesn't. -- MacDailyNews, November 9, 2017\n\nImagine if your livelihood depended on one company that had not only monopolized web search (and, thereby, basically controlled how new customers find you), but also controlled the bulk of online advertising dollars which funded your business and which they could pull, simply threaten to pull, or reduce rates at any time? Now also imagine if you believe this monopolist basically stole the product of another company that is the very subject of your business? How much would you criticize the monopolist thief's business practices?\n\nYou might guess that it would be a tough road to walk. (We're only imagining, of course!)\n\nThat would be a good example of why monopolies are bad for everyone...\n\nIn the meantime, stop using Google search and Google products wherever possible. Monopolies are bad for everyone. -- MacDailyNews, July 14, 2016\n\n\u200e\n\nPlease help support MacDailyNews. Click or tap here to support our independent tech blog. {"uri": "8261172516", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "05:33:52", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T05:33:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T05:33:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4431372582912445, "url": "https://www.thestar.com.my/tech/tech-news/2024/08/06/will-googles-historic-monopoly-lawsuit-be-the-death-knell-for-mozilla-and-firefox", "title": "Will Google's historic monopoly lawsuit be the death knell for Mozilla and Firefox?", "body": "Mozilla is putting on a brave face for now, and not directly addressing the existential threat that the ruling appears to pose. -- The New York Times\n\n\"Google is a monopolist, and it has acted as one to maintain its monopoly.\"\n\nWith those words from United States District judge Amit Mehta on Monday, Google suffered a historic antitrust case loss at the hands of the US Department of Justice.\n\nMehta, the judge presiding over the trial, ruled that the tech giant has illegally maintained a monopoly through the billions of dollars in annual payments it makes to partners to secure the default search engine position on popular web browsers and mobile phones. With those dominant positions locked in, the argument goes, other competitors in the search and search advertising businesses have no chance of competing effectively.\n\nThe ruling immediately prompted speculation about the impact to Apple, which receives as much as US$20bil (RM88.96bil) from Google every year in exchange for putting the search engine front-and-centre on its iPhones via the Apple Safari web browser.\n\nBut while Apple would certainly take a big hit if the ruling is upheld, Apple is a large, diversified company with many sources of revenue. That's not the case for another partner of Google's located in the fallout zone of Monday's ruling: Mozilla, the non-profit tech organisation that makes the Firefox web browser.\n\nWhen users of Firefox type a search term into the browser, the query is automatically routed to Google's search engine. The arrangement is vital for Mozilla. According to the Mozilla Foundation's 2021-2022 financial statement, which is the most recent published, US$510mil (RM2.26bil) out of its US$593mil (RM2.63bil) in revenue came courtesy of Google's search payments.\n\nIf that number US$510mil (RM2.26bil) were to go away entirely, Mozilla will have a serious problem on its hands.\n\nMozilla is putting on a brave face for now, and not directly addressing the existential threat that the ruling appears to pose.\n\n\"Mozilla has always championed competition and choice online, particularly in search,\" a spokesperson said in a statement to Fortune on Monday. \"We're closely reviewing the court's decision, considering its potential impact on Mozilla and how we can positively influence the next steps... Firefox continues to offer a range of search options, and we remain committed to serving our users' preferences while fostering a competitive market.\"\n\nFor Mozilla, which first rose to prominence in the late 1990s as a community-driven project to challenge Microsoft's stranglehold on the web browser market via Internet Explorer, Monday's ruling is the latest setback in a quest to find relevance in a market dominated by Big Tech companies. Mozilla laid off about 60 staffers earlier this year and saw its CEO step down.\n\nYou can be sure that critics of the judge's ruling will highlight the potentially devastating impact on Mozilla to make the case that the antitrust ruling will have unintended consequences on smaller tech industry players. Others might argue that Mozilla hasn't done enough with those spoils to differentiate its Firefox browser, or that it could cut a deal with another search engine like Bing if its Google deal goes away completely.\n\nEither way, Google will appeal the suit so a long battle may ensue. And there's another big domino to fall: the judge will rule on the remedy or remedies - essentially, the business-model penalties - that Google will face.\n\nEvercore ISI research analyst Mark Mahoney tacked them off in a research note on Monday evening: \"The exact remedy is key, and so far, it's hard to pick a winning horse among a range of outcomes,\" he wrote. \"i) forbidding payment from Google altogether, ii) a cap on the amount of distribution agreement fees, iii) pushing Apple to implement a \"choice screen\", or iv) something else? In any case, we expect at least another 6 months to a year before we would know the exact remedies (or longer if the judge decides to stay the remedies phase pending GOOG's appeal).\" - {"uri": "8260727823", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "20:51:46", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T20:51:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T20:51:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.43529412150383, "url": "https://www.commondreams.org/newswire/aag-kanters-antitrust-division-beats-google-in-biggest-antitrust-trial-of-the-century", "title": "AAG Kanter's Antitrust Division Beats Google in Biggest Antitrust Trial of the Century", "body": "In response to news that Judge Amit Mehta has sided with the Department of Justice Antitrust Division in its case against Google -- ruling that Google violated Section 2 of the Sherman Act by maintaining its monopoly in general search services and general text advertising through its billion dollar exclusive default deals -- the American Economic Liberties Project released the following statements.\n\n\"This is one of the greatest antitrust victories in history and sends a resounding signal that the antimonopoly movement is here to stay,\" said Nidhi Hegde, Interim Executive Director of the American Economic Liberties Project. \"In finding Google to be an illegal monopolist for its unlawful search default deals, this ruling is a vindication of the Biden Administration's reinvigorated competition agenda and a huge win for consumers, small businesses, and tech innovation. There is now broad recognition of the harm monopoly power poses to markets and a clear validation of the antimonopoly movement's approach to governing -- which sets a powerful precedent for future cases. Make no mistake: Antitrust law is back, and corporate America is now on notice.\"\n\n\"Congratulations to AAG Kanter and the entire Antitrust Division team for delivering this unprecedented win against one of the most powerful companies in the world -- while severely under-resourced in comparison,\" added Hegde.\n\n\"This decision strikes at the core of how hundreds of millions of Americans experience the internet,\" said Lee Hepner, Senior Legal Counsel at the American Economic Liberties Project. \"It illustrates how Google has become one of the most powerful companies in the world while undermining innovation and degrading the quality of its core product. The remedy must match the Court's striking verdict in this case. At a minimum that means an end to Google's exclusive default agreements and breaking up business lines that have allowed Google to extend its monopoly into every corner of the internet\n\n\"The promise of antitrust enforcement is that it will fully restore competition where it has been lost,\" added Hepner, \"and we'll be advocating that the court use all of its power to do so.\"", "source": {"uri": "8261675070", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "11:16:11", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T11:16:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T11:15:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4313725531101227, "url": "https://www.theepochtimes.com/article/news-brief-fed-official-responds-to-market-meltdown-federal-court-rules-against-google-in-landmark-antitrust-case-judge-orders-johns-hopkins-to-pay-millions-5700244", "title": "News Brief: Fed Official Responds to Market Meltdown; Federal Court Rules Against Google in Landmark Antitrust Case; Judge Orders Johns Hopkins to Pay Millions", "body": "Good morning, and welcome to The Epoch Times News Brief for Tuesday, Aug. 6, 2024. I'm Bill Thomas, we have some really pressing stories to share with you today, and here's what's going on.\n\nThe central bank is prepared to step in if the economy gets much worse, a federal judge rules against Google in a landmark antitrust case, and Johns Hopkins University is ordered to pay out millions more in a class action lawsuit. Also, former President Donald Trump faces a couple of legal setbacks, and a man who wants to be president says he's the guy behind the mystery of a dead bear cub.\n\nData that came out last week showed deterioration in the U.S. labor market and manufacturing. The data included an 11-month high in initial jobless filings, with job creation numbers that came in well below expectations, and an unemployment rate that jumped higher than anticipated.\n\nMarket reaction was immediate, with stocks and other risky assets selling off, but recent news sparked further panic when the VIX, the volatility index, jumped to its highest level since the COVID-19 pandemic. The VIX is a measure of stock market volatility, and that's what caused the markets to drop even further.\n\nAustan Goolsbee, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago, told CNBC that the Fed is always prepared to respond if the situation deteriorates, and that their job is to stabilize prices and maximize employment. Goolsbee also went on to warn market watchers not to jump to conclusions from a single jobs report, especially when the job creation number was roughly equivalent to the margin of error.\n\nWhen asked whether he sees any other indicators besides last week's negative manufacturing data and labor market challenges, Goolsbee pointed to the rise in consumer delinquencies and an uptick in small business defaults.\n\nBut, on the flip side, he said that the gross domestic product (GDP) data has come in quite strong, indicating economic growth at a \"fairly steady level.\"\n\nGoolsbee's remarks follow Wall Street's main indexes, which as you know, tanked yesterday, as fears of a nationwide recession rippled through the global markets.\n\nThe ruling, issued by Judge Amit Mehta, ends a years-long legal battle initiated by the U.S. Department of Justice and a coalition of state attorneys general.\n\nMehta's decision states that after having carefully considered and weighed witness testimony and evidence, the court has decided that Google is a monopolist and has violated Section 2 of what's called the Sherman Act.\n\nThe case against Google, which was filed in October 2020, alleged that the tech giant engaged in anti-competitive practices by establishing exclusive agreements with browser developers, mobile device manufacturers, and wireless carriers.\n\nSo you know, those agreements prevented partners from pre-installing rival search engines, leading most U.S. devices to come preloaded exclusively with Google, forcing competitors to find alternative ways to reach users.\n\nThe court said Google's conduct allowed the company to charge companies with what's legally described as \"supracompetitive prices for general search text ads,\" enabling them to earn substantial monopoly profits.\n\nIn defense, Google said that its practices were pro-competitive and justified by the quality of its services.\n\nGoogle said it plans to appeal and that \"this decision recognizes that Google offers the best search engine, but concludes that we shouldn't be allowed to make it easily available.\n\nThe judge's ruling suggests the possibility of structural relief as a remedy, which would involve changes to Google's business operations, including terminating exclusive agreements that make Google's search engine the default option.\n\nYou should know that this case is seen as the most significant antitrust trial of the century, and antitrust lawsuits have also been filed against other big tech companies, including Amazon, Meta, and Apple.\n\nLast week, U.S. District Judge Julie Rubin signed the order after the university and plaintiffs, led by a former student, said they found more than 2,600 students who paid for the 2020 spring semester but did not receive refunds. By the way, court documents state that tuition fees for a semester at that time cost at least $26,150.\n\nNearly 11,000 students or former students have already received or are awaiting payouts from the fund. The amount each person receives depends on a variety of factors, including how much they paid in tuition, along with payments through student loans. Scholarships are exempt from refunds.\n\nJohns Hopkins was ordered to deposit the money into the settlement fund before the end of the year. The school was previously ordered to pay about $8 million into that same fund.\n\nInteresting to note that in addition to the $10 million being paid to students and former students, the university was also ordered to pay $2.2 million to attorneys representing the plaintiffs.\n\nMissouri's Attorney General Andrew Bailey filed a petition weeks ago to the high court, arguing that the New York case infringed on the rights of voters and electors in his state ahead of the election. Bailey also added the case was meant to smear the former president. As you know, Trump is the Republican Party's nominee for president in the general election, which is just a few months away.\n\nBy the way, while Bailey contended that the conviction would likely be overturned on appeal, he added that the constraints that New York put on Trump would \"limit his ability to campaign.\"\n\nTo refresh your memory, Trump was found guilty in May for falsifying business records to cover up a $130,000 payment to adult film actress Stormy Daniels at the end of the 2016 election. Prosecutors said the payment was intended to bolster his presidential campaign at that time.\n\nInteresting to note that New York Attorney General Letitia James wrote that Missouri does not have legal standing to challenge the Trump case.\n\nYou should know that Trump is scheduled to be sentenced on Sept. 18.\n\nIn a video posted on his X account on Sunday, the 70-year-old independent presidential candidate recounted the highly unusual circumstances that stumped the city for the past decade.\n\nAccording to Kennedy, he was driving through New York's Hudson Valley early one morning in 2014 on a falconry trip with a group of friends when a driver in front of him hit a bear cub, killing it. He says he picked up the bear and put it in the back of his van, with the intention of skinning it and saving the meat in his freezer for food.\n\nKennedy said that New York state law allows taking home a roadkill bear, but only after notifying law enforcement or the state's environment authority and getting a special bear tag. The problem for RFK Jr. was that he ran out of time to take the bear back to his home in Westchester before having to catch a flight.\n\nSo he and some of his intoxicated friends thought it would be a good idea to make it look like the bear cub got hit by a bike since there had been several local bike accidents at the park.\n\nThe dead bear cub sparked a media frenzy after it was discovered, including a reporter from the New York Times who happened to be Kennedy's niece, Tatiana Schlossberg.\n\nAccording to Schlossberg's report, law enforcement took the bear for analysis and determined that it had been hit by a car. A wildlife expert also weighed in, saying someone might have killed the bear and taken it to Central Park.\n\nAnd now, it looks like our time is just about up for today, so we're going to call it a wrap for the Tuesday edition of The Epoch Times News Brief.\n\nWhatever you have planned for today, when you're out and about, it would mean so much to us if you could tell some people you know about our program. Thank you in advance for helping us grow the News Brief family, and as you know by now, we are trying to become the biggest brief on the block.\n\nWe heard from Robert, who says he's retired, living the good life, and enjoying the News Brief. Debi Worth dropped us a very lovely note, as did Stellar Jay, Morrow, and Shillon.\n\n*(Don't forget the News Brief Motto): We're portable, affordable, and always on-demand.\n\nAnd finally, as we do each and every day on this program, we wrap everything up with a very notable quote, and this one comes to us from Fr\u00e9d\u00e9ric Chopin, who said: \"Bach is an astronomer, discovering the most marvelous stars. Beethoven challenges the universe. I only try to express the soul and the heart of man.\"\n\nInteresting fact: Barry Manilow's hit song from 1975, \"Could It Be Magic,\" was inspired by Chopin's Prelude in C minor, Opus 28, No. 20.\n\nBefore we go, you should know that today is National Root Beer Float Day! {"uri": "8260717878", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "20:41:28", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T20:41:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T20:40:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4274509847164154, "url": "https://wegotthiscovered.com/tech/what-does-googles-violation-of-antitrust-laws-mean-for-internet-users/", "title": "What does Google's violation of antitrust laws mean for internet users?", "body": "The internet giant's pivot to basically being an ad serving machine is indicative of the decline of online, but will this news change that?\n\nIn an age of excessive corporate power, it's rare to see the courts take on one of the biggest tech giants in the world and possibly win. Yet, Google might be on the verge of being punished for years of aggressive business practices that a United States federal judge has now deemed illegal.\n\nThe ruling from Judge Amit Mehta, states that Google has an unfair monopoly over search services and advertising, which if you look at the state of the internet, is hard to argue against. The judge has said that the specific law being violated is section 2 of the Sherman Act, which is an antitrust law in the U.S. that passed into law in 1980. In his ruling, Mehta said:\n\n\"After having carefully considered and weighed the witness testimony and evidence, the court reaches the following conclusion: Google is a monopolist, and it has acted as one to maintain its monopoly.\"\n\nGoogle currently has a market cap of $2 trillion, and its reach stretches far into various facets of the internet. This decision is one of the biggest antitrust rulings in years, and comes off the back of various governmental agencies across the globe beginning to really look into big tech companies for their practices, especially those deemed monopolistic.\n\nAs per the Justice Department, section 2 of the Sherman Act outlaws any attempt to \"monopolize, or attempt to monopolize, or combine or conspire with any other person or persons, to monopolize any part of the trade or commerce among the several States, or with foreign nations . . . .\"\n\nSince it was passed, the Supreme Court has ruled that not every restraint of trade is prohibited, but only those that are deemed unreasonable. However, there are certain practices, including price fixing, dividing markets, and rigging bids, that are almost always looked into, as they are deemed overly harmful to competition.\n\nWhile most people and companies who fall afoul of the Sherman Act suffer civil penalties, it is technically criminal not to be in accordance with the legislation. However, prosecutable offenses have previously been limited to serious and clear violations that are deemed intentional. The maximum penalties are $100 million for a corporation, $1 million for a single person, and up to 10 years in prison.\n\nHonestly? We don't know yet. Google's monopolistic practices range from their stranglehold over how blogs and websites write content via a murky SEO formula, to its domination of online advertising and ad revenue, to their farming of content to use for AI-generated material, depriving the people who have actually researched and written things valuable eyeballs. And that's not even the tip of the iceberg.\n\nWhat we do know is that Google is likely to fight this decision, and have all the money in the world to pay for lawyers, so even if there are changes, it's likely we won't see them for years to come.", "source": {"uri": "wegotthiscovered.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "We Got This Covered"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-08-444970192", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "20:35:19", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T20:35:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T20:14:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4235294163227081, "url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2024/08/05/technology/antitrust-google-amazon-apple-meta.html", "title": "After Google Antitrust Ruling, Here's Where Other Big Tech Cases Stand", "body": "The U.S. government's landmark antitrust trial against Google's search business concluded on Monday with a federal judge's ruling that the company had acted illegally to maintain a monopoly. But the parade of major federal cases challenging the power of the tech giants is just getting going.\n\nUnder the Trump administration, the Justice Department and the Federal Trade Commission started investigating Amazon, Apple, Google and Meta, the parent company of Instagram and WhatsApp, for monopolistic behavior. The government has since sued all four companies -- Google twice -- in what it says is an effort to rein in their power and promote more competition. The companies have denied the claims.\n\nHere's what's next with the U.S. government v. Big Tech.\n\nAmazon\n\nIn September, the F.T.C. and 17 states sued Amazon, accusing it of protecting a monopoly by squeezing sellers on its vast marketplace and favoring its own services. The practices also harmed consumers, the F.T.C. argued, and resulted in some cases of \"artificially higher prices\" because Amazon prevented those selling goods on its site from offering the same products on other online sites for less.\n\nA judge in U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington set the trial for October 2026.\n\nAmazon has asked the judge to dismiss the case and has argued that it often offers low prices to consumers and doesn't hurt sellers on its marketplace. The lawsuit shows a \"fundamental misunderstanding of retail,\" the company has argued.\n\nThe chair of the F.T.C., Lina Khan, who is famous in certain circles for a 2017 Yale Law Journal antitrust paper on how to rein in Amazon, has vowed to take on tech monopolies.\n\nAmazon has described the lawsuit as \"misguided\" and warned that if the F.T.C. prevailed, it would \"force Amazon to engage in practices that actually harm consumers and the many businesses that sell in our store.\"\n\nApple\n\nThe Department of Justice sued Apple in March, accusing the company of using a monopoly in the smartphone market to block competition, inflate prices for consumers and stifle competition. The department joined 15 states and the District of Columbia in its lawsuit after a nearly two-year investigation.\n\nIn the suit, filed in U.S. District Court of New Jersey, the department said Apple blocked companies from offering applications that competed with Apple products like cloud-based streaming apps, messaging and the digital wallet.\n\nLast week, Apple filed a motion to dismiss the case and said that its business decisions don't violate antitrust laws. It has also argued that those decisions make the iPhone a better experience.\n\n\"This lawsuit threatens who we are and the principles that set Apple products apart in fiercely competitive markets,\" Apple previously said in a statement. \"We believe this lawsuit is wrong on the facts and the law, and we will vigorously defend against it.\"\n\nGoogle\n\nIn addition to the search lawsuit, the Justice Department filed a separate suit against Google in January 2023 over online advertising. That case is scheduled to go to trial in September.\n\nThe department and eight states sued in U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Virginia, saying Google acquired rivals through anticompetitive mergers and bullied publishers and advertisers into using the company's ad technology.\n\nIn the search case that the judge ruled upon on Monday, he will next order changes to the company's business to fix the illegal behavior.\n\nMeta\n\nThe F.T.C. sued Meta in December 2020, accusing the company of creating a monopoly in social media by buying Instagram and WhatsApp. The mergers deprived consumers of alternative social media platforms, the F.T.C. argued.\n\nThe lawsuit has taken more twists and turns than the other Big Tech antitrust cases. It was filed in U.S. District Court of the District of Columbia before the company changed its name to Meta, from Facebook. In 2021, Judge James Boasberg dismissed the complaint, saying the F.T.C. didn't adequately define the market that it accused Meta of monopolizing. But he allowed the agency to refile its lawsuit, and it moved forward the next year.\n\nThe F.T.C. joined 40 states in accusing Facebook of buying both Instagram and WhatsApp more than a decade ago to illegally squash competition that could have one day challenged the company's dominance. The regulators have called for the deals to be unwound.\n\nMeta has argued that it didn't acquire Instagram and WhatsApp to kill competition and that it has invested heavily in developing innovations for the apps.\n\nTripp Mickle contributed reporting.", "source": {"uri": "nytimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The New York Times"}, "authors": [{"uri": "cecilia_kang@nytimes.com", "name":
